file name: join_text_units_to_entity_ids
"""
- size: 855
- columns: text_unit_ids,entity_ids,id

The three basic laws of dialectical materialism can be summarized as follows: "The law of strife and unity of opposites (that is, things are in a continuous process of change because they are made up of opposing forces or elements); the law of transformation of quantity to quality . . . and the law of negation of negation (each qualitative stage becomes negated by a further development)" (Somerville 1945, 24) . N. Ya. Sushko and Stefan Tiuskhevich described dialectical materialism and military thought, saying that "the appearance of new means of struggle always brings into being corresponding counter-means, which in the end also lead to changes of military operations. The \'struggle\' of tanks and antitank means, submarines and antisubmarine means, aircraft and antiaircraft defense . . . this is the axis around which revolves the development of military affairs, including the development of methods and forms of armed conflict" (Sushko and Tiuskhevich 1965, 128) .\nDialectical materialism and holism were the foundation for the scientific drive in Soviet military science.    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;US MILITARY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **US Military** is recognized for its technological superiority, particularly demonstrated during the Gulf War where it outmatched Iraqi forces.  Its MTR/RMA doctrine, later known as network-centric warfare (NCW), has been a subject of interest and debate within both Soviet and contemporary Russian military circles. Analyses comparing and contrasting the strategies employed by the **US Military** and the **Russian Military** further highlight its unique approach to warfare. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">00641f6f7299e02e813e3f9b6264b19e,a19173a530680219eb5e0efd973893c0,cf62fdb14a3fc4c98b15edb2ffdb6dd6,d0c05f8ec94cd42a4727a66ae84be4dd</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;HOFFMAN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Hoffman is a prominent figure in the study of modern conflict, particularly known for his contributions to the understanding of strategic communications and hybrid warfare.  He argues that the term "political war" is an oxymoron because war inherently involves violence, suggesting that the true gray zones exist within our flawed models and education about conflict. \n\nHoffman is cited as one of the originators of the term "hybrid warfare," alongside Mattis. Together, they proposed a four-block war model that incorporates psychological and information operations. Hoffman also summarized the use of "hybrid warfare" by US political and military leaders. His work has significantly shaped our understanding of how strategic communications can transform strategic affairs in contemporary conflicts. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0fa028b232510c552f26de29d99b145b,6cb6b290fc24699cc0581b793cb749cd,a19173a530680219eb5e0efd973893c0,c0ae1b35d101dd5c80796ebcaaa52998,c14363837da220e50f2cbf6793eb94d2,d81d350aa6c9162a49b1eb526ae982b8,ff33e904e4d9308ef4fac68e0de16f71</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;FREEDMAN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">FREEDMAN is an author who has written extensively about war and its evolving nature, particularly focusing on hybrid warfare and the Gerasimov doctrine.  He is widely cited for emphasizing the crucial role of strategic communications in shaping and transforming strategic affairs. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">597b96f29d47f44fa260f97ed43bcb31,6cb6b290fc24699cc0581b793cb749cd,74abf737631531a56e8f3e9456798f10,a19173a530680219eb5e0efd973893c0,c14363837da220e50f2cbf6793eb94d2,f3286050de3ac7fdc74f33ed1403c501</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SOVIET UNION&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The Soviet Union was a former communist state and a major geopolitical entity that existed from its establishment by Vladimir Lenin and Leon Trotsky until its dissolution in 1991. It was a key adversary of the United States during the Cold War, engaging in a nuclear arms race with NATO. The Soviet Union held a distinct understanding of war based on Marxist-Leninist ideology, which was firmly subordinated to the Communist Party. This understanding viewed war as an inevitable tool for accelerating the global communist transformation and as the continuation of class politics by violent means.  \n\nThe Soviet Union believed that all wars stemmed from class struggle and that actions could be justified if they furthered the revolutionary process, differing from Western just war theory. They established control over half of Central Europe during World War II and were a major player in both World Wars. The Soviet Union\'s rise is linked to the revolutionary context. \n\nThe Soviet Union laid the theoretical and methodological foundation for Russian military theory, which persists today.  This foundation was shaped by internal and external threats and heavily influenced by Marxist-Leninist theories about war. The text describes the Soviet Union as the location where understanding of war originated from the Communist Party. It discusses the history and characteristics of military thought within the Soviet Union, its foundational policy and military doctrine, and the nature of war within the context of the Soviet Union.  The dissolution of the Soviet Union led to a decline in Western interest in Russian military thought. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">00e7336d67609903b464740eecc2da73,046f04af090c144a8bd1403c6c5879a4,0b7f36c1efd528460ea8b64f4d00c6a9,0d5bebc49e84be0b136baa2a23ad6119,14442faf092eaecae58a72c1a981a33b,1b996f45c7b397759863385a53361eed,1b9b97610a4a892ffd4aa4057f98a99d,1d1f8fd7a97b7aca3ba71380fbbaa90c,1fdbdba8c71554268a8e4cacad9c056a,2090f56414eebaeb642f4296f8762613,2ced16684237fb065035dffff5afc8b4,31d8ac7fc85d988e67da2c6480208aad,32d948fc460c6d1bb1d9682bfd136dd3,355bb2e7269c004d598030ff8348dda0,39b41cfcdca61ad353853416d904417f,3cd3649d4d82b16c6d105090d8081f6e,4014059e72ca2fb658649cccba153f5e,43cb0f2a8f89f287a9fa0308ed110a3f,4a45316e71cd0e0104c26095efef1a8b,51ed05a44ffcb6ce215b22d1c327ef23,51eee122c2ebcb8b0ffd820ac78cdc7b,5c2f2ed6b167d0c17fcd87e51d62ab85,5f022b2409af8223bf100e9564e5f586,5fe78f79b74aaf92a89687fd492be682,62bc2728250038f93d0bc65c57c2385b,65495eb1bdee1fa1abc9d070c27380fa,67553bf934dfe54e134414e61479f4a5,68e4ed89f41a580e3c58f0f98434cc33,6a43992b9c939ecec99364c660c1ac68,6b7d21eb26a4ec94c42acbaaf3707f2e,6bb6801ed3016e00efcce4b92ed4763d,6bf1c34951771fcd9f2560d72d1dec62,70ffa305d793f894aff7641666c1ab03,73e9dd59e90139f5e98a1ec5152660fd,7457059c696ee5838f2b9889b1412e1f,7496af92a71655ac8c47de41bf43bb65,74b1bd908c22c236bcd8a776ad40cc37,80e2f294b065a7a45175fb7408358c76,83073afaa1def102babae9700cd63bba,8493f884b789159d96b7dab3a7202396,8510ea40cef51fcde12bd266cbc4b6b2,882b4c6f36a621d123f340e538aff0c0,8c7cf0e88b403959479bde7eb44c8654,93d35d9e3f3e82ed3b519b494edfd9b9,9521960b1adb4fffde0f8bca2df87bcb,9e53460bbd021fbbc0a4bc6a17b4286d,9f69cc7e34d605a68963e8a8a83e003f,a15ef9eda68738122db496f9962d6a9f,ad49a894ef8b75f1e79de5a63ec78b85,b1b64ef207d42a2b81118c978ce1f222,b3aa1ac66a5e25e270fce196c19d325e,b4cf9c163a2ba0d0db3385c6741457ac,b5e3ea78bd8f6699e982039ddaf0e2f6,b6c3e0690d7a726e219124a91c516e65,b8fd807f07f8a2af89aa236339a7bc45,b90af97596777a0400f9c331a5d96a40,bab940f0cf76af894b6edb440a57b5f8,c0ae1b35d101dd5c80796ebcaaa52998,c2792fdb292ab4fe367f71a4089bf78c,c57482161043b2c5d5a644c558fb2fa6,cb8b8a24ee435442f42e5aa0feacb291,cc801e9b36ee6b6cbcb589ad5d6eb592,dcb36e1f25d08b0eeffb649bc3a7860f,e3f78e84ba947ada447e7a0b46389605,ee04ae10c40b706b74a05b7fffa01876,fb8a4e3d89439bd18b6f6ecae81d6d7c,fc20acf548ac287cb2de74e6e1ea4d6e,ff33e904e4d9308ef4fac68e0de16f71</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;RUSSIAN MILITARY THOUGHT&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">**RUSSIAN MILITARY THOUGHT** refers to the evolving ideas and strategies within Russia\'s military doctrine.  It encompasses both military and nonmilitary strategies, and is described as distinct from Western approaches, shaped by Soviet influences. Russian military thought emphasizes kinetic activity in competition, meaning it prioritizes direct military action over other forms of engagement. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">452741c3c9d866e070dc0fcef9650ce1,4ecd2e58c6e1a2b279d5f93a8f00f091,6a43992b9c939ecec99364c660c1ac68,6b408afcf04121f1365ead7989dc8265,83073afaa1def102babae9700cd63bba,8c989fc0d3fc136d27a9f97d0fe40c82,ef9b79c1a74e5e82e587612a6b3f3ada</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;WESTERN EQUIVALENT&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"The text contrasts Russian military thought with its Western counterpart."</data>\n      <data key="d2">6a43992b9c939ecec99364c660c1ac68</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;VLADIMIROV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">VLADIMIROV is an author and expert on modern warfare.  He emphasizes the importance of consciousness and ideas in contemporary conflicts. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">636188fef27c7af85e7dda3cc59e512f,b885945824139b7bec06a1a78158b190,fdc2c2b29672f18ffe9ae9fb2f1da756</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MESSNER&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">MESSNER is a military theorist and author whose ideas have significantly influenced Russian military thought. He specialized in propaganda during his time as a former military officer and developed the concept of "subversion-war" based on Trotsky\'s theories. MESSNER argues that modern warfare increasingly focuses on psychological dimensions, a concept he termed "myatezhvoina," which he differentiates from traditional guerrilla warfare and insurgencies. \n\nHis writings explore the blurring lines between war and peace in the context of "subversion-war" and provide insights into the nature of revolutions. MESSNER\'s theories have been influential in shaping perspectives on modern war, particularly within schools of thought like "wars of consciousness." His work is also cited by thinkers like Vladimirov, who draws upon MESSNER\'s ideas regarding the manipulation of mass consciousness.  MESSNER emphasizes the growing importance of psychological warfare and observes the changing nature of war, highlighting its increasingly psychological dimensions. He has even proposed ideas about state disintegration. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0fe8cfd6fb9698ac419d99a30f7c00d6,276f8550d758346b203160a32cd885b6,3090c7597ab8b380afd48c1498709019,39b41cfcdca61ad353853416d904417f,4731d7c63be856e43075fe3d3c707e95,5efb9f04dcb379bafb98f7295b6ee16c,636188fef27c7af85e7dda3cc59e512f,6750bb4a2ab8af556c6cade73a275a95,69ab3a134854d40cbd893d37335cd7a2,6f3507b03c5fb34990029b28366363fe,83b0087e03908565fbbc54e5d4e331b1,9b9ff0b9cc19b0ace380f06dff0ce7bd,be99ed0e0a0f22dc215ec3d77e26d299,c95f509936d591070b3df6db009432bc,d0b738b8d19afd8178c28b7e67d984cd,dc1e9a19fbd380396d94e6e7c3bc5a52,ed5d6fd72ab9c8ddfc773830620174ab,faeec4fac390184ebb4bfcfdefc13e11,fdc2c2b29672f18ffe9ae9fb2f1da756</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;LEONID MALTSEV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Leonid Maltsev, the Belarusian Minister of Defense, argues that modern warfare has evolved beyond traditional forms. He is a speaker on nonclassical forms of warfare and presented on this topic at a recent event. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">636188fef27c7af85e7dda3cc59e512f,7ad7b26d5e91bbe2e2df1b6e7a30b199,f1ea10917ad6f50fda3a92586fe998dc</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;PAVEL BRUNTALSKY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Pavel Bruntalsky is an author and frequent contributor to VPK. He is known for summarizing Leonid Maltsev\'s arguments in his articles. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">636188fef27c7af85e7dda3cc59e512f,7ad7b26d5e91bbe2e2df1b6e7a30b199,f1ea10917ad6f50fda3a92586fe998dc</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;VPK&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">VPK is a publication that focuses on military and strategic affairs. It features articles on various military and strategic topics, providing a platform for discussions and analysis within these fields. Notably, VPK has published works by prominent figures such as Gareyev, who explored the evolving nature of warfare, and Pavel Bruntalsky, who wrote about Leonid Maltsev\'s arguments on military strategy. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">3335c606e0de431e14afc7e61f86dfa8,636188fef27c7af85e7dda3cc59e512f,7ad7b26d5e91bbe2e2df1b6e7a30b199,f1ea10917ad6f50fda3a92586fe998dc</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MODERN WARFARE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">"Modern Warfare" is described as a qualitatively new phenomenon. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">636188fef27c7af85e7dda3cc59e512f,cb9c7871784fe7e0541e9f25929b9435</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;BELARUSIAN MINISTER&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"The Belarusian minister is the speaker who sees \'bloodless clashes\' as efficient and impressive."</data>\n      <data key="d2">7ad7b26d5e91bbe2e2df1b6e7a30b199</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;BRUNTALSKY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Bruntalsky is an author who believes that modern warfare has transformed and no longer solely relies on armed violence. This perspective aligns with Maltsev\'s view on the nature of war in contemporary times.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">a5ccc3b4de720472fb0ba6dbc764cdba,c2792fdb292ab4fe367f71a4089bf78c</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MALTSEV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">MALTSEV is an author whose perspectives on the evolving nature of war align with those of Bruntalsky.  Both Maltsev and Bruntalsky offer insights into how warfare is transforming. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">a5ccc3b4de720472fb0ba6dbc764cdba,c2792fdb292ab4fe367f71a4089bf78c</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SERGEI BREZKUN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Sergei Brezkun is a professor at the Academy of Military Science who disagrees with Bruntalsky and Maltsev\'s perspective on modern warfare."</data>\n      <data key="d2">c2792fdb292ab4fe367f71a4089bf78c</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;ACADEMY OF MILITARY SCIENCE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **Academy of Military Science** is a Russian military institution responsible for institutionalizing strategic thought in the officer corps.  It collaborates with the General Staff by contributing to the military journal *Voyennaya Mysl* and disseminating military-theoretical works. Notable individuals associated with the Academy include Vladimir Slipchenko, Sergei Brezkun, and Vladimir Mikryukov. In 2013, Chief of the General Staff Valery Gerasimov delivered a speech at the Academy about the changing nature of war.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">068fed974175a4460923174d7ce00bbf,071a706dfd6647edd4993031ec85beb9,2629bcda8b7f4f253acfd0d116bd739d,36344580abcc867bedcaf20027655b68,389e48907c50cbd0638418cda16b9938,5b098687cb656d98c6bb419d0ec6fd75,5bc1d54f3233915280db63e273e03592,5cd9f4f78cb2dfdfcb512cc36ac0202f,8501d99fb9d704c9315278702413ee9e,c2792fdb292ab4fe367f71a4089bf78c,da02795f9d537326bfadcd006a8bcc92,e0053ef676c35b3b5e2e0225190d6463</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;WARFARE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">Warfare is a term sometimes used interchangeably with "struggle" by Russian experts.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">4ecd2e58c6e1a2b279d5f93a8f00f091,c2792fdb292ab4fe367f71a4089bf78c</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;BRUNTALSKY &amp; MALTSEV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1" />\n      <data key="d2">c2792fdb292ab4fe367f71a4089bf78c</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;AGGRESSOR&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"**AGGRESSOR**" refers to the party that initiates a conflict, potentially violating international law.  This entity, which can be a country or other organization, engages in hostile actions such as manipulating international relationships and launching attacks. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">98af93d8eaa2b05d821947ec140a3584,b5e3ea78bd8f6699e982039ddaf0e2f6</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;BREZKUN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Brezkun is an author and expert who specializes in hybrid warfare.  He published work on the subject in 2007 and argues that the Soviet Union could be a result of a nonclassical war. Brezkun emphasizes the importance of classical military means in countering aggression, presenting the argument about the Soviet Union\'s origins as a case study. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">b5e3ea78bd8f6699e982039ddaf0e2f6,f9cd1d8b7cbb13deeabb75de223a5c6c,fc20acf548ac287cb2de74e6e1ea4d6e</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;GERASIMOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Valery Gerasimov is a high-ranking officer in the Russian Armed Forces and the Chief of the General Staff. He is a prominent figure in Russian military theory, known for his concept of the "adaptive approach to warfare" and emphasizing non-military means.  Gerasimov argues that the nature of war has changed, with non-military means becoming as important as traditional military force. He believes the lines between war and peace are blurring due to the effectiveness of these non-military tactics, such as "color revolutions," which he views as a new form of warfare instigated by the West. \n\nGerasimov\'s writings and speeches have significantly influenced the understanding of modern warfare, particularly his concept of "hybrid warfare" which combines both military and non-military means. He is considered a key figure in expressing Russia\'s stance on information warfare and advocates for changes in the laws of war to reflect this evolving landscape. His ideas have been referenced by other prominent figures like Andrew Korybko and Bartles, solidifying his influence within military theory circles. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0020352f5979749f81254faea53ba1dd,0130a2e44046b07aa1a2eac85562f8aa,0ac95daa24b8448799785bd3afba6112,0b053af0a82e321c5ad32e0e5014114d,0f6caa8f2e4b146cbd71b583add938f8,17ec79bdb3de589c18eab04fab860d2c,22b661e49114bda37400701e79292197,26bcdb76c6596b963d2e36a4147ef816,273d16ede7c2ef0b280a8c35ddd2ad71,29af440463776490596d1cedcfe1b068,2a095cc3e0a26865ad75d88bf966ff8e,2d96d25d0022a1193382ea88b904435a,2d9ebc26c09a31bc04991b6efe8272bf,330a15c48db3e65aec3147e6dd5632c9,358c867d3a7c5e13a54f3d519fad1603,35fa4f03c6bbb412d22ff5f494e83329,36344580abcc867bedcaf20027655b68,38bf7298856b8fd4341bb0998b803ee0,3a60589a99ac9cde8a25daf1571620f6,4988f2a5f074560f53ed5ddfe5e100b2,4a396711762b9d23dfa301a027d2737e,4f7f4f6fe9d288255da50532faa25f53,5001e715f5ba5243fcabb020b7615069,54e5f6035998ada7e8e6f4188995aec5,5bb2f411436cd9fd01cf7697e33fec75,5c79cd610c718db1aa2cf27f837d00c8,68355cf380d714ea713e77efbe44d3ac,6e050b4fa47547d59d934e304f199d4a,6e49482d37bfe8a11381f5fd9b2bf9ab,7762d8e435ee0e72467ae2468b71323e,7cc72471bf4edd02ae4d6b43dd505467,803cf3c02920d14a7bb0447fc1c76140,81610c5774616913fcb1d17e45b9c19b,83d8321db4baeb9dd56aa1e91eb29a39,84b65c4d676043766aeebfc93b776ae6,8501d99fb9d704c9315278702413ee9e,850631a820a8158d8c7bff68e8f7fea5,94a2bf999aec8597aae3db5d3633891d,988cfd2c3c636c6bc23a2455381cfe57,a1d5b70180c35b1c12fa0a5a6e0f0a8a,a3a7513f41e4fd6cb9e4f0decdbc615d,a8ab56e6e419d570a195fd2ea167899d,aa5d990b03c9214c4c3a37412d5cf0d1,ac08e98f560a5dcdd378a622eca69f06,b04e155024b2e24838d7dba80a934c81,b11c3e5c041763bf480a5b17676c7ef3,bd400dbd8e753ab71c9394fe8b1f07ce,c06a4e03818e9f2586a6cd014a2408b7,d494718117eae6e351eff5873eca32c0,d8383d735e3d4dedd141bc4b08e3eeaa,db7fc162ad9590d171cb7d6fc1ef0fc2,dd68126420b24cd563d457fdb5356a33,ddd0a3f72f4191a04998e4fe73f788b7,e0927b91be8f756165d5fca82ca84107,e422579fa9c3017302c510d218e0fc09,f6e01d03f8c01910c2d8de5e8dd3a40f,fa6f1322c861f018219ae4741df2bae1</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;ARAB SPRING&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"EVENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **Arab Spring** refers to a series of pro-democracy uprisings and protests that occurred across the Middle East and North Africa in 2010-2011. These events, initially perceived as successful "color revolutions," involved both peaceful protests and instances of violence. The Arab Spring significantly influenced Russia\'s initial reaction towards the West, prompting concern and suspicion from Russian officials who viewed it as a potential threat.  \n\nThe Arab Spring is cited as a catalyst for renewed concerns about color revolutions within Russia, influencing their perceptions of such movements and contributing to the 2011-12 Russian elections and the Euromaidan revolt. It is also mentioned as a potential example of a new type of warfare in the 21st century, characterized by nonmilitary means and disruptive technologies used by the West.  \n\nFurthermore, the Arab Spring is presented as a significant historical event used to illustrate the nature of 21st-century warfare, highlighting the impact of information warfare and regime change on global power dynamics. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">127b37863425efc735533b75512a27a3,158ce52b95681a52d3cd554e67e50c0b,1b2ff8a47843f9eaa296b8dbc90d9179,2528b45270d95680a57bc9094766201c,273d16ede7c2ef0b280a8c35ddd2ad71,2ed01d91a2d5804af478b65fbd4fff17,330a15c48db3e65aec3147e6dd5632c9,3567049070ba54eb1c8cfbc3d5aef2b3,3972337bda3ba01f49da971ec696ce50,46a8120d658a422a13cbf4af4bac874c,47cbbe56d55fbd552f238ecfef64e24b,4988f2a5f074560f53ed5ddfe5e100b2,4ff9923cce9727a0cb4b60f7ec70b2cc,68d539054aaa9dcc75ed59e59850468c,79642481b2ae6a1e1e62350b8f9872b5,841ac43154acf1df4c5e3af00e7d0360,8501d99fb9d704c9315278702413ee9e,882b4c6f36a621d123f340e538aff0c0,8c989fc0d3fc136d27a9f97d0fe40c82,a7f0f3bd43f5142bb1728f4adacde5b0,a8ab56e6e419d570a195fd2ea167899d,b04e155024b2e24838d7dba80a934c81,b27bfe84ab787e179b1320553dc4146a,ba4314d7dde31a9a3de140b03d964db0,be14354d183b860e7bd2a06d1c731a17,c06a4e03818e9f2586a6cd014a2408b7,d0c05f8ec94cd42a4727a66ae84be4dd,e216e7f3ed5bf3208c1f51eaa41603b8,f04349eccb7697c6652f0d01b6622514,f35ced22e0b916ab11822dd7acc16502,f377212178ff5952443726ce112faac6,f5693f51d4c418b01643d1524837e46b,fcf6292acd4060dcb8b6f555eeebabe3,ff779b872510c138da68523b69265b0e</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;UKRAINE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"GEO"</data>\n      <data key="d1">## Ukraine: A Country at the Center of Conflict and Geopolitical Tensions\n\nUkraine is a country located in Eastern Europe that has become a focal point for international conflict and geopolitical tensions.  Since 2014, Ukraine has experienced significant unrest and political instability, culminating in a war initiated by Russia. This conflict has been widely described as an example of "hybrid warfare," which capitalizes on indirect action, informational campaigns, and the use of non-state actors like NGOs and private military companies.\n\nThe events in Ukraine have been interpreted differently by various parties. While some view the Ukrainian situation as a "color revolution" instigated by external forces, others see it as a legitimate struggle for self-determination against Russian aggression.  Russia has accused Ukraine of receiving support from the US and EU, further escalating tensions. \n\nThe conflict in Ukraine has had a profound impact on global discourse. It has brought attention to the work of military theorists like Chekinov and Bogdanov, who have analyzed the evolving nature of warfare. Additionally, Ukraine serves as a testing ground for Russia\'s military capabilities and a site where its military theories are being applied. \n\nThe ongoing conflict in Ukraine highlights the country\'s geopolitical significance and its role as a flashpoint between Russia and the West.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">00a8e6977b8cc35ff2706d718367759f,02a6df0665914ec51da4921e5dd94d40,09d7c6af55f6f4b82f041f3f22e4670b,16a295a1b82cfcc452e208d5c3376783,181231ad89fa361ed50977f8c31ba68e,2cb1e7782df146c829e143995efaa5ea,30032f8bc461471f2472db1803deb493,358c867d3a7c5e13a54f3d519fad1603,36f660fdb6caa5548aa91058f2a84b25,3858893d4e6c348056e49fd3ae011704,398eeca696092e2043e85b335804a06b,3e06cb0ad46a2e027bad24715e248b03,4124151e2fc00b9b0fa6084138b8a7ef,536b48540ca934fd046a103198ab417e,5e6fb3a3adc710bacf237b23b8de5cdb,61ac280201ff550c532fdc0a622b220c,66363736a89b60d4a0809ceb037cbec1,6868f009e28c0d98518a108a15141a47,68d539054aaa9dcc75ed59e59850468c,78e0d14c1d381cdf093e4f7873c77b1c,79642481b2ae6a1e1e62350b8f9872b5,806203f9ac3bb5daf5713237ac7d114e,841ac43154acf1df4c5e3af00e7d0360,882b4c6f36a621d123f340e538aff0c0,8ff158575b84b0887eb77b85bf41802d,931a3799d962bbcfc294a670caa94cdc,94a2bf999aec8597aae3db5d3633891d,9a094936a37bf4a3f685de90bc51b680,a43f5e6fd71202a7ed7c45243f550e1e,ac08e98f560a5dcdd378a622eca69f06,ad3a9a7eec5a9d65028ce8f7f95ab827,b04e155024b2e24838d7dba80a934c81,b11c3e5c041763bf480a5b17676c7ef3,b27bfe84ab787e179b1320553dc4146a,b97617707d0f13c32b85f07ae1407b77,c06a4e03818e9f2586a6cd014a2408b7,c2736d15fad21b52584eeabefdf7f2da,d7db417821a9ecdbb04ad34de78b0244,e0927b91be8f756165d5fca82ca84107,e0bc114dfaebe00d71bbcf19b4d41f1d,e8b2ce2c1fd2c098e0876122cefde0bb,e9def1a80602f476ecce04216e4a8a03,ed5d6fd72ab9c8ddfc773830620174ab,ee01bd14651295a2b77fcb67ebdc098b,f131e67e4b2ea2d98c5968dd6c57cda5,fa1f745b441f0a8da9c96e5184733ab7</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;LIBYA&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"GEO"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Libya is a country in North Africa that has been cited as an example of a "color revolution" escalating into large-scale military action.  \n\nThe country experienced internal instability provoked through subversive actions and "controlled chaos," which was further destabilized by the use of "soft power" against the government. Information warfare, specifically targeting Libya, was used to promote civil war. This ultimately led to a Western military intervention following the color revolution, events that were significant for Russia. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">127b37863425efc735533b75512a27a3,16a295a1b82cfcc452e208d5c3376783,330a15c48db3e65aec3147e6dd5632c9,4a4127fa2d140cfe4bba76e93169d035,4ff9923cce9727a0cb4b60f7ec70b2cc,84b65c4d676043766aeebfc93b776ae6,84fbeb27b48ec1426740369d4f5b851e,9a094936a37bf4a3f685de90bc51b680,c06a4e03818e9f2586a6cd014a2408b7,e0927b91be8f756165d5fca82ca84107</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SYRIA&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"GEO"</data>\n      <data key="d1">## Syria: A Geopolitical Flashpoint\n\nSyria is a country that has become a significant geopolitical flashpoint, drawing international attention and involvement.  It is frequently mentioned as an example of a "color revolution" &#8211; a popular uprising often fueled by external actors &#8211; which escalated into large-scale military conflict. This conflict has seen the involvement of both Russian and Western forces, generating considerable tension between the two sides. \n\nRussia\'s military intervention in Syria, first initiated in 2015, has been cited as an example of "cross-domain coercion" and a new type of warfare outlined by General Valery Gerasimov.  Gerasimov\'s speech highlights the use of various tools beyond traditional military force, including NGOs, private military companies, and information warfare, to achieve strategic objectives. \n\nSyria has also been described as a location where "soft power" was allegedly used to influence events, and where "controlled chaos" tactics were employed. The country\'s ongoing instability and the presence of armed groups have created a volatile environment marked by threats and challenges for both regional and international actors.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">00a8e6977b8cc35ff2706d718367759f,127b37863425efc735533b75512a27a3,2ed01d91a2d5804af478b65fbd4fff17,330a15c48db3e65aec3147e6dd5632c9,358c867d3a7c5e13a54f3d519fad1603,3fe4dd62a032b1a281c925fbec9cbc6a,4a4127fa2d140cfe4bba76e93169d035,61ac280201ff550c532fdc0a622b220c,68355cf380d714ea713e77efbe44d3ac,841ac43154acf1df4c5e3af00e7d0360,84b65c4d676043766aeebfc93b776ae6,84fbeb27b48ec1426740369d4f5b851e,94a2bf999aec8597aae3db5d3633891d,9a094936a37bf4a3f685de90bc51b680,acb49396b9072d77515a295d612faf84,b04e155024b2e24838d7dba80a934c81,b27bfe84ab787e179b1320553dc4146a,ba6cc1cd4e196ad5c9a6ed672f497d19,c06a4e03818e9f2586a6cd014a2408b7,d7db417821a9ecdbb04ad34de78b0244,f131e67e4b2ea2d98c5968dd6c57cda5</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;ZARUDNITSKY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Zarudnitsky is the Chief of the Main Operational Directorate of the General Staff. He is an expert who analyzes "color revolutions" and their impact on warfare, believing they represent a significant change in world politics. Zarudnitsky compares these revolutions to military aggression in his analyses. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">053fc6b7d54ff33c0865e0ad0ff30b52,5aee82bdd503dba2501bafd6ec8b2ccd,9a094936a37bf4a3f685de90bc51b680,c06a4e03818e9f2586a6cd014a2408b7,eaaa469362a385cbba23c49fc926a216</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;COLOR REVOLUTIONS&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">"Color Revolutions" are a series of political upheavals perceived by Russia as engineered by Western states. These events involve popular uprisings, often fueled by ideological and social movements, that aim to overthrow governments through nonviolent protests and information campaigns. \n\nThe term "Color Revolutions" was first used to describe the events in Georgia (Rose Revolution), Ukraine (Orange Revolution), and Kyrgyzstan (Tulip Revolution) between 2003 and 2005.  They are characterized as a "soft coup," a method for regime change involving political, economic, and humanitarian pressure, often with external support from Western powers.\n\nColor Revolutions are seen as a significant threat by Russian leadership, who view them as a form of Western aggression aimed at destabilizing their influence and undermining traditional military power.  They are described as a major shift in global security threats, involving political-diplomatic, economic, and information influence, and are considered a tool used within hybrid warfare strategies. \n\nThe concept of Color Revolutions has gained prominence on the Russian agenda since the early 2000s, becoming mainstream among military theorists by the mid-2010s.  They are understood as a nonmilitary form of action that significantly impacts the Russian understanding of war and poses a perceived threat to their national interests.\n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">053fc6b7d54ff33c0865e0ad0ff30b52,0ac95daa24b8448799785bd3afba6112,0f6caa8f2e4b146cbd71b583add938f8,127b37863425efc735533b75512a27a3,17ec79bdb3de589c18eab04fab860d2c,181231ad89fa361ed50977f8c31ba68e,19d9f093df260f1df1d036a42926a00d,1b2ff8a47843f9eaa296b8dbc90d9179,1c170b6b1c8851bba14e24b8af15b481,22b661e49114bda37400701e79292197,273d16ede7c2ef0b280a8c35ddd2ad71,29af440463776490596d1cedcfe1b068,2cb1e7782df146c829e143995efaa5ea,34b0078e74299e6a200a4ef43f0bdc9c,3567049070ba54eb1c8cfbc3d5aef2b3,3747b8d7981bef88cd93023a9282583b,3a60589a99ac9cde8a25daf1571620f6,3d9254865502f679af6fa7a0b77a6cbe,4a396711762b9d23dfa301a027d2737e,4b3b407bbe1ac2b90a3980545cb66a39,4f7f4f6fe9d288255da50532faa25f53,54e5f6035998ada7e8e6f4188995aec5,5aee82bdd503dba2501bafd6ec8b2ccd,5bb2f411436cd9fd01cf7697e33fec75,5eebe2681ef1e72ddfec4046d181b179,641dba1d5b7b52f8b0e286f427afecc3,677c7a0f4f60503badb0a4d899c21d74,68355cf380d714ea713e77efbe44d3ac,6b82eafaf18f777bfa19dd36a0a5c327,6d223c86a361242683a4bd296d60b502,752e31eca4dc5d94da820c3cb84cf6e9,7762d8e435ee0e72467ae2468b71323e,7e6f4059311f39a717a9ef7d076868ad,806203f9ac3bb5daf5713237ac7d114e,8196d4fb9caac5c7ffd87f465eac8c12,8beec46e554e40907188a8b4eadfb7f8,8cbc35e22aa8edad712072d4efe491f1,903acba04eef215a12972c10ee95560b,972ad08450d40acba47394c99e434c56,98d0fa6298be2a61d9cff2a2acb23924,9a094936a37bf4a3f685de90bc51b680,9a2dcbe9b0d27f8917dd3fe660260425,9c59a1134d84949c9c4c2d4510c2fbfb,9d078dbf3cd9f132d9d452509bd774f1,a1c7cc7a633d4eb0010929797ae264c5,a1d5b70180c35b1c12fa0a5a6e0f0a8a,a65201d3ece3a85bc85fabedd884b7e7,a66026abef50d4b6b00ca0f933f6be0f,ad3a9a7eec5a9d65028ce8f7f95ab827,bb79f01fab18fe7d28c221337b6e09c0,c06a4e03818e9f2586a6cd014a2408b7,c57482161043b2c5d5a644c558fb2fa6,c6f139f4eaa3828baab624dad7b83c88,cb50fafd31d07b9e8f9e52f658937913,d0c05f8ec94cd42a4727a66ae84be4dd,d42e19095522f9d2df7dc1499cedc5ca,eaaa469362a385cbba23c49fc926a216,ef9b79c1a74e5e82e587612a6b3f3ada,f35ced22e0b916ab11822dd7acc16502,f9b181b3ff2171e547897575c5e4d562,fcf6292acd4060dcb8b6f555eeebabe3</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;THE WEST&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The West, a geopolitical entity often referring to a collective of countries primarily including the United States and European Union states, though sometimes solely meaning the United States, is a key actor in international relations.  It is portrayed as viewing color revolutions as a nonviolent tool for regime change and responds to actions taken by Moscow, potentially contributing to miscommunication in the process. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">3567049070ba54eb1c8cfbc3d5aef2b3,5aee82bdd503dba2501bafd6ec8b2ccd,f131e67e4b2ea2d98c5968dd6c57cda5</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;WESTERN MILITARY THOUGHT&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Western Military Thought refers to the ideas and strategies employed by Western militaries.  This school of thought places a strong emphasis on kinetic activity during periods of competition. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">4ecd2e58c6e1a2b279d5f93a8f00f091,6b408afcf04121f1365ead7989dc8265</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;STRUGGLE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"STRUGGLE" refers to a broad range of strategic interactions that encompass various domains such as information, diplomacy, and economics.  As understood by Russian experts, "STRUGGLE" holds a broader meaning than just wartime conflict and relates to comprehensive competition across multiple spheres. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">245c8a66b7fbfb155c4ea1253d66dad9,4ecd2e58c6e1a2b279d5f93a8f00f091</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;CROSS-DOMAIN COERCION&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">**CROSS-DOMAIN COERCION** is a military strategy employed by Russia that integrates conventional, cyber, and nuclear capabilities to achieve its strategic objectives.  \n\nIt involves exerting pressure on adversaries across multiple domains, encompassing both deterrence and compulsion tactics. This approach, described as the most recent evolution in Russian strategy, aims to influence and deter opponents through a combination of informational warfare, conventional military force, and nuclear threats. While initially a Western concept, "cross-domain coercion" aligns with Russian notions of "struggle" and "strategic deterrence."  It is presented as an alternative term to strategic deterrence, emphasizing its focus on non-nuclear aspects. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0f11f27d252b4419076b47cf4dfcb20d,23a741082731d52f254cf6d6f54eb58c,39936b87b632c096c061641c0490c2af,4ecd2e58c6e1a2b279d5f93a8f00f091,59f9360f2decd637139d6b869529c2ad,6fe4faca1e39cc57f7c84b772a87fd4d,7513c4dbf8819739ed9f826ecda085dc,76815ae7d94d779bb7060d241c9903fc,7ae0f631f330850ca53d02c933c953ce,85f4f3b5379c5738a70e9fb5bc359ae0,8651bdb6a227bf3bca82a80a06ed712a,cf70ea3dd32b83dd2249d0d0987956a7,d872d9d72fd45f9dfaac95c56c2b8b39,d9cfb6f6d55260607c7b88c1f675e224,eaf0d08dbd97c1a7311aa7c886044509</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;COMPETITIVE STRATEGY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Competitive strategy envisions long-term competition in both peace and war."</data>\n      <data key="d2">4ecd2e58c6e1a2b279d5f93a8f00f091</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;RUSSIAN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">**RUSSIAN** refers to the geopolitical entity of Russia, a nation often described as an "adversary" employing strategic influence tools.  The term also encompasses a distinct cultural sphere and military thought analyzed in the text. Discussions within the text include Russian military strategies and tactics, further solidifying the context of "Russian" as referring to the nation of Russia and its associated aspects. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">46560acff919ef6253fd1d861d00ae9c,7513c4dbf8819739ed9f826ecda085dc,8af314428c563e0a26a74d9083e89198,d760565312fa739ff154c8ebd38fe95d,d872d9d72fd45f9dfaac95c56c2b8b39,ddb28f923ecb6b1e19f7dff7c9b34211,f1a146e421e297be23156a46a12345c5</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;ADMINISTRATIVE ORGANS DEPARTMENT&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **Administrative Organs Department** was responsible for controlling all appointments of military and security personnel. This role highlighted its importance in ensuring party influence over the military apparatus.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">6388873944a12dfd98e41c61c757f3d8,6ea7bd4508f84402392b3119dfa1aa6d,ee2a956c830712b74c912b175f90afdd</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MILITARY-POLITICAL ADMINISTRATION&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **Military-Political Administration** wielded significant power by controlling military messages and dispensing party patronage. This influence extended to both internal affairs, shaping communication within the organization, and external audiences, disseminating information and favors to those outside its ranks.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">6388873944a12dfd98e41c61c757f3d8,6ea7bd4508f84402392b3119dfa1aa6d,ee2a956c830712b74c912b175f90afdd</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;KGB\'S THIRD CHIEF DIRECTORATE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"The KGB\'s Third Chief Directorate used informant networks to control the military covertly."</data>\n      <data key="d2">6ea7bd4508f84402392b3119dfa1aa6d</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;KRASNAYA ZVEZDA&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"GEO"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Krasnaya Zvezda" is a weekly military newspaper controlled by the Military-Political Administration.  Its role as a journal indicates its influence in shaping military discourse. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">389e48907c50cbd0638418cda16b9938,6388873944a12dfd98e41c61c757f3d8,6ea7bd4508f84402392b3119dfa1aa6d</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;VOYENNAYA MYSL&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"GEO"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"**Voyennaya Mysl (Military Thought)**" is a military journal established in the late nineteenth century. Published by the General Staff, it serves as the primary platform for military-theoretical works and is controlled by the Military-Political Administration.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">389e48907c50cbd0638418cda16b9938,5b098687cb656d98c6bb419d0ec6fd75,5bc1d54f3233915280db63e273e03592,6ea7bd4508f84402392b3119dfa1aa6d</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SOKOLOVSKY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">SOKOLOVSKY is a Soviet military theorist who authored influential works such as "Voyennaya strategiya" and "Marksizm-leninizm o voine i armii," providing authoritative perspectives on war within the Soviet Union.  He emphasizes the principle of complete subordination of military strategy to policy, refuting claims that war had ceased to be an instrument of policy. While SOKOLOVSKY acknowledges that nuclear weapons represent a change in the character of war, he maintains that they do not fundamentally alter its nature, as opposed to those who argue for a complete shift in the definition of war.  SOKOLOVSKY holds a narrower view of war, defining it solely by armed violence. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">1b996f45c7b397759863385a53361eed,2cb92533547d702e1894fcea545257ee,313dc3be1190b1a10a2579c621091156,489aeca592784f5f7be0a754beb4f575,4d3bd4beec226501211dcd3560fd6fba,6ea7bd4508f84402392b3119dfa1aa6d,7be505fea57e0dbd921a3c195dd29aac,ee2a956c830712b74c912b175f90afdd</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;NIKOLSKY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Nikolsky is cited as an author who argued that war had ceased to be an instrument of policy."</data>\n      <data key="d2">2cb92533547d702e1894fcea545257ee</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;TALENSKY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Talensky is cited as an author who argued that war had ceased to be an instrument of policy."</data>\n      <data key="d2">2cb92533547d702e1894fcea545257ee</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;GARTHOFF&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Garthoff is cited as an author who provided evidence for the claim that war had ceased to be an instrument of policy."</data>\n      <data key="d2">2cb92533547d702e1894fcea545257ee</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;VOYENNAYA STRATEGIYA (MILITARY STRATEGY)&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"EVENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"**VOYENNAYA STRATEGIYA (MILITARY STRATEGY)**" is a seminal work by **Vasily Sokolovsky**.  In this book, Sokolovsky refutes existing claims about the nature of war and defines it as armed violence employed between different groups to achieve political objectives. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">2cb92533547d702e1894fcea545257ee,b90af97596777a0400f9c331a5d96a40,e8d8461aeecbc6801361ca4fa5c3e2e2</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;WAR&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">## War: A Multifaceted Concept\n\n**War**, transliterated as \'voina\' in this book, is a central concept explored throughout the text.  It is defined and analyzed from various perspectives, highlighting its complexity and multifaceted nature. \n\nWhile often understood as a conflict involving armed force, as defined by Kvachkov and Gareyev, war encompasses a broader range of activities beyond physical violence. Soviet scholars, as well as other sources, define war as "the continuation of politics by means of armed force," emphasizing its strategic and political dimensions.  \n\nThe text presents diverse interpretations of war. It is discussed both as an evil to be eradicated and as a necessary tool for achieving communist goals. Additionally, it is presented as an instrument of politics, strategically employed by the Soviets. \n\nAuthors like Malyshev delve into various forms of warfare, including economic, psychological, and information warfare, expanding the traditional understanding of armed conflict.  Gorbunov and Bogdanov argue that the nature of war is constantly evolving, while Kazarin focuses on defining and analyzing its core characteristics. Clausewitz\'s ideas on achieving victory are discussed within the context of war, further emphasizing its strategic significance. \n\n\nUltimately, "War" refers to armed conflict between nations or groups, but the text delves deeper into its complexities, exploring its political, social, economic, and ideological implications.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">08b5b9a81f792e1a63e929dc06a81d50,112509ae19803edd47655e5f2fc22ae1,1507b417cf61f29030428f95a1c2dc08,1a860ae7b783d3a1eb78fb862dd64138,1b996f45c7b397759863385a53361eed,266688aac47e8134554bad1ee6e6ccba,2836f2f0365794d9fae3abfa350f2311,2cb92533547d702e1894fcea545257ee,2ed01d91a2d5804af478b65fbd4fff17,30386c4e76d744b895d430847b713f0a,3060e5a3570413999878edce8065dc2b,313dc3be1190b1a10a2579c621091156,31d8ac7fc85d988e67da2c6480208aad,342381013c3f61db48a3a2b2bc77370c,37215a6c4810a7b385fb17417f94fbe0,39786aa4012dd6b57506633a91deaeca,3bd04ac8a624fe79e353bb14221b8554,3cd3649d4d82b16c6d105090d8081f6e,48e310bd8a37fd938fc512819430d5f7,4e2896fd5b6f31d006ca18e1a3299553,51eee122c2ebcb8b0ffd820ac78cdc7b,68355cf380d714ea713e77efbe44d3ac,7567750cec0624c2e9f362f989d8b1bc,7aef3b8e0c0a9cd9f240dfbe12e02c38,7be505fea57e0dbd921a3c195dd29aac,7e482cb10632a3cf72d58679114ee7f7,81610c5774616913fcb1d17e45b9c19b,84ac1ed20f03c3394c67671cb479f7db,8501d99fb9d704c9315278702413ee9e,96de73e76077a8dbde7d1d4e185a69bb,a5ccc3b4de720472fb0ba6dbc764cdba,b04e155024b2e24838d7dba80a934c81,b1b64ef207d42a2b81118c978ce1f222,b39e3b697d5d9ed3835d622486095c96,be99ed0e0a0f22dc215ec3d77e26d299,beabdeed11a36088777fbee158b3a3f5,bfa15fcd5d4a19aa65f946d1af780d5f,c0ae1b35d101dd5c80796ebcaaa52998,c4d611eafc5e900466e378a2742c03bf,c8c68899e22ee8c693d6e73e47d38c9e,ce0f551566143f746d8ff46f4a021065,cfae2a9660e62a12a25d2678a2931f34,d62c24f2a958cdd90af90b2fee315132,f6e8b902329dc6f6dbef5fc7fd397474</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MARXISM-LENINISM&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Marxism-Leninism is a political and economic ideology that served as the foundational ideology for military strategy in the Soviet Union.  It shaped both tactical approaches and overall worldview, becoming the basis for all war and society science within the country. Lenin himself desired Marxism-Leninism to be the foundation for Soviet military science. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">2a4b75db8fdd23483fc6c4f097c7f56f,645ce27900f66a0b633be93f0e5d6399,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,e90da29be1148d9844e3ed777db08bf6,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SOVIET IDEOLOGY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Soviet ideology encompassed the beliefs, principles, and values that guided the Soviet Union. It referred to the political, economic, and social beliefs that dominated the country.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">65a1bf9e5672afc1a7011ffa78b1c211,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;NATIONAL SECURITY CONCEPT OF THE RUSSIAN FEDERATION&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"DOCUMENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"**NATIONAL SECURITY CONCEPT OF THE RUSSIAN FEDERATION**" is a document that outlines Russia\'s security policy.  It details the nation\'s national security priorities and strategies. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MILITARY DOCTRINE OF THE RUSSIAN FEDERATION&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"DOCUMENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **Military Doctrine of the Russian Federation** is a document that outlines Russia\'s military strategy. It defines Russia\'s military objectives, principles, and methods of warfare.  This doctrine serves as a guide for the country\'s military strategy and aims to achieve its strategic goals through defined principles and approaches. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">ade36c9f71918172a6ce043f5b3b2dc8,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;FOREIGN POLICY CONCEPT OF THE RUSSIAN FEDERATION&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"DOCUMENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **FOREIGN POLICY CONCEPT OF THE RUSSIAN FEDERATION** outlines Russia\'s goals and approaches in international relations. This document articulates Russia\'s vision for its role on the global stage and how it intends to interact with other countries.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;COMMONWEALTH OF INDEPENDENT STATES (CIS)&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"The CIS is a political and economic union of former Soviet republics."</data>\n      <data key="d2">bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MINISTRY OF DEFENSE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The MINISTRY OF DEFENSE is a governmental organization responsible for Russia\'s military affairs. It defines military doctrine and strategy, outlining the core tasks for the armed forces and issuing military doctrines.  \n\nThe Ministry is considered the source of information about military dangers, capabilities, doctrine, and political goals. It published the 2000 Military Doctrine and the 2010 Military Doctrine, as well as a Military Encyclopedic Dictionary defining terms like "myatezhvoina." The Ministry also provided a definition of war in 2007, emphasizing its characteristics and core content.  \n\nFurthermore, the Ministry defines subversion-wars as armed fighting by insurgent or rebel forces. Vasily Burenok is a high-ranking official within the Ministry of Defense. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">00e7336d67609903b464740eecc2da73,0da7185a3277e6969d5f94e97613b636,0e40df5d22db6584ec7e05b07c3d9b66,10779701d4d4bad771a7c8e3bdf664e0,1838769a055e042d335b716b927ac517,2528b45270d95680a57bc9094766201c,276f8550d758346b203160a32cd885b6,2836f2f0365794d9fae3abfa350f2311,287b17a01df64083a49c84828ae77591,3060e5a3570413999878edce8065dc2b,30ff2b3a1ac3fddc8b200986ef1f24f4,390e6b6bbf2dbf4ee3678f7e9b5afaed,4c0b295b06b41e7a8105d7587f0ad731,5430e32b1beaf2a36fbde8a1b9b3074f,606328f81d69fee27f0d5b308252d4db,7021759b813120aabd337b4757a1e83a,7357dc206ba88482f202ea79850252f2,927ecbbd9a7b08760bb62d394dcd75e9,9976fb85179c1c48e3cfe309be6108c7,9d9628ed6f319fa3c7a74e5a5971aad6,a9f11317bfb1cbac1d72052738a6bfd0,b39e3b697d5d9ed3835d622486095c96,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,d3c8f104bbf738655c44e9993cb8f0f7,df2540cf569ce35f7b90708e5da0b01d,fdc2c2b29672f18ffe9ae9fb2f1da756</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SECURITY COUNCIL&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **Security Council** of Russia is an organization that advises the President on national security matters. It is also involved in producing military doctrines and documents, as evidenced by its adoption of a document outlining Russia\'s long-term vision for information security until 2020.  Furthermore, the Security Council held a session to discuss the essence of war, highlighting its role in shaping strategic thinking within the Russian government. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">26fe7e732ff9b3d2e54b43110076216a,7cc72471bf4edd02ae4d6b43dd505467,94bbacb0bb8aa50088b2c5d541d33537,997fce38d3477147a111b2fbe4e1433a,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,fcbe7cb6c5543166265ebbc898ee34ba</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MINISTRY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **MINISTRY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS** is the primary institution responsible for handling Russia\'s diplomatic relations and shaping its information security policy.  It plays a crucial role in outlining Russia\'s foreign policy goals and strategies, as evidenced by its publication of the Foreign Policy Concept in 2000 and the updated version in 2008. The Ministry is also involved in producing various documents related to foreign policy, including concepts and strategies. It serves as the source for quotes attributed to Lavrov, who represents the Ministry within international affairs.  The Ministry\'s activities and publications are considered key sources of information regarding Russia\'s approach to global security policy. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0fbf2c2d34dfce0579218bcd864902ec,20d87cdf1f465c50311a5731b700eb92,26fe7e732ff9b3d2e54b43110076216a,287b17a01df64083a49c84828ae77591,55c4942e8de72064af2356010994efd9,5910165c2ae0e582998b2c2de2b57f54,9976fb85179c1c48e3cfe309be6108c7,997fce38d3477147a111b2fbe4e1433a,9a4e544128564ba75a290bb651a8ccfc,b39e3b697d5d9ed3835d622486095c96,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,c2324291b2afa91371cc2c27eeb6979e,c243ab6f4e5afba61f79b9d15e7dc288,c67d4ba720d6b7d15c6d3b4c82538634,fcbe7cb6c5543166265ebbc898ee34ba</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MILITARY STRATEGY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">Military Strategy refers to the planning and execution of military operations, encompassing both traditional and non-traditional methods.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">3bd04ac8a624fe79e353bb14221b8554,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;NATIONAL SECURITY CONCEPT&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">The **National Security Concept** is a document outlining Russia\'s security strategy.  Two notable versions were discussed: one from the late 1990s and another adopted in 2000. Unlike Military Doctrine, which primarily focuses on external threats, the National Security Concept emphasizes internal threats such as terrorism and ethnonational struggles. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">28cb703fdc157a4e1b984d6601e37170,3f1469dfb6c218c8c3c64069b7a2495c,663fcd1c899cf2232bc4bbdebe560f19,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,da8ce201ab8466858c322bea48bb9804,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;RUSSIAN FEDERATION&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">The Russian Federation, emerging from the dissolution of the Soviet Union,  inherited military thinking from its predecessor. While seeking to establish new security policies, it faces both military and nonmilitary threats according to documents like the Military Doctrine and National Security Concept. The country identifies itself as a target of potential hostilities and destabilization, as outlined by Gareyev.  \n\nThe Russian Federation\'s military doctrine is subject to analysis and undergoes significant changes in structure and capabilities.  Internal military dangers and long-term information security are also discussed within the context of the nation\'s evolving security landscape. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">00e7336d67609903b464740eecc2da73,28cb703fdc157a4e1b984d6601e37170,2ced16684237fb065035dffff5afc8b4,31d8ac7fc85d988e67da2c6480208aad,38a5a22d04aa221997f0aa343f0a29ac,74b1bd908c22c236bcd8a776ad40cc37,78e0d14c1d381cdf093e4f7873c77b1c,841ac43154acf1df4c5e3af00e7d0360,927ecbbd9a7b08760bb62d394dcd75e9,94bbacb0bb8aa50088b2c5d541d33537,9a10a038173b1ded524749f03c661495,b150f2af73252fedbdd595a3de157238,b27bfe84ab787e179b1320553dc4146a,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,beb665481df870fd27048e10898e8bac,cb233c91ebbe8b4085763d57986b71ca,cdb1d6abbb222058b92413663953ef84,da8ce201ab8466858c322bea48bb9804,e9def1a80602f476ecce04216e4a8a03,ed99845841304bd47e2d825a071ab187,ef02fb1d1f0e7f58d70ebfec17d8b392,f6f3bf4797ee25c5c62c11e81fb4fa83</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MILITARY DOCTRINE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">## MILITARY DOCTRINE\n\nMilitary Doctrine is a formal document outlining Russia\'s military strategy and objectives. It serves as a key document that defines Russia\'s understanding of war and security, encompassing strategic principles and guidelines governing military action.  \n\nFirst established in the Soviet Union, the doctrine has been updated several times, most notably in 2000 and 2010. The 2010 Military Doctrine, for example, defines five concepts of war and conflict: military conflict, armed conflict, local war, regional war, and large-scale war. It also outlines the objectives, methods, and characteristics of contemporary military conflicts.  \n\nPrevious iterations of the doctrine held a traditional view on military threats facing Russia, including local wars, weapons proliferation, and terrorism. However, the document is continually being updated in response to perceived threats and evolving geopolitical landscapes. \n\nThe Military Doctrine closely aligns with Russia\'s Foreign Policy Concept of 1993 and includes references to non-nuclear deterrence as a key aspect of its strategy. Notably, it also acknowledges the potential for protest within the Russian population.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0b053af0a82e321c5ad32e0e5014114d,26bcdb76c6596b963d2e36a4147ef816,28cb703fdc157a4e1b984d6601e37170,38a5a22d04aa221997f0aa343f0a29ac,48406587f16687aac4c95e6b442fc461,5bb2f411436cd9fd01cf7697e33fec75,63ae1b36ecf8efb01b9a95f7abdd4033,68a51313b3812e3e2ae80473d4579a10,7357dc206ba88482f202ea79850252f2,81610c5774616913fcb1d17e45b9c19b,833fcef2d336802f17cac21855d9386e,841ac43154acf1df4c5e3af00e7d0360,997fce38d3477147a111b2fbe4e1433a,9d9628ed6f319fa3c7a74e5a5971aad6,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,c243ab6f4e5afba61f79b9d15e7dc288,c57764869d0b7caa0abcd0a9e7b856aa,c6f139f4eaa3828baab624dad7b83c88,cc801e9b36ee6b6cbcb589ad5d6eb592,da8ce201ab8466858c322bea48bb9804,df2540cf569ce35f7b90708e5da0b01d,ed75045fde0e8bf203850ee3b096166f,ee529e2d08063744d6a3cc51b8b4775b,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967,fcbe7cb6c5543166265ebbc898ee34ba</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;FOREIGN POLICY CONCEPT&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">**FOREIGN POLICY CONCEPT**\n\nForeign Policy Concept defines a country\'s goals and objectives in its relations with other nations.  Specifically, it outlines Russia\'s foreign policy strategy and goals within international relations. The concept is considered an official document, first established in 1993, which emphasizes traditional views on military threats as outlined in the Foreign Policy Concept of 1993. It serves as a guide for Russia\'s interactions with other countries, defining its perspectives and approaches to global affairs.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0fbf2c2d34dfce0579218bcd864902ec,5910165c2ae0e582998b2c2de2b57f54,833fcef2d336802f17cac21855d9386e,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,c243ab6f4e5afba61f79b9d15e7dc288,da8ce201ab8466858c322bea48bb9804,ee529e2d08063744d6a3cc51b8b4775b</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SOVIET TIMES&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1" />\n      <data key="d2">bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SOVIET MILITARY ENCYCLOPEDIA&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"EVENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **SOVIET MILITARY ENCYCLOPEDIA** acknowledged the possibility of war despite advocating for peaceful coexistence.  It served as a significant source of information for the development of the 1993 Russian Military Doctrine, influencing its content and shaping its perspective. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">91056b62e7f13dbe730a526d696cbf28,997fce38d3477147a111b2fbe4e1433a,ce0f551566143f746d8ff46f4a021065,fcbe7cb6c5543166265ebbc898ee34ba</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;CHEKINOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">CHEKINOV is a military theorist and analyst who emphasizes the importance of unconventional warfare and controlled chaos in international relations. He co-authored several articles with Bogdanov, including "The Nature and Content of a New-Generation War," focusing on the nature of modern warfare and arguing that military security is intertwined with other forms of security, particularly information security. \n\nChekinov believes that information resources are effective weapons in modern warfare and advocates for the use of propaganda and information operations as key to victory. He also argues that nonmilitary means, such as color revolutions, should be prioritized over traditional military force.  His work explores the impact of informatization and automatization on conventional armed forces and highlights the shifting understanding of war in the contemporary world. Chekinov\'s ideas are influenced by Slipchenko and he is considered a relevant figure in discussions about modern warfare strategies. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0f6caa8f2e4b146cbd71b583add938f8,3e06cb0ad46a2e027bad24715e248b03,3e6ab14e2f0c4f2a8a611ac169b8dc44,5599962db5be274ac157280f1faa4590,677c7a0f4f60503badb0a4d899c21d74,82893599bbdf88d7635db30797b87987,8e59b8e09a13e3b59b06fd4c22fd9a1e,988cfd2c3c636c6bc23a2455381cfe57,a3a7513f41e4fd6cb9e4f0decdbc615d,a8ab56e6e419d570a195fd2ea167899d,b45be955e924377403f02def4244bbcf,ba4314d7dde31a9a3de140b03d964db0,bd400dbd8e753ab71c9394fe8b1f07ce,d8383d735e3d4dedd141bc4b08e3eeaa,db7fc162ad9590d171cb7d6fc1ef0fc2,e216e7f3ed5bf3208c1f51eaa41603b8,fa6f1322c861f018219ae4741df2bae1</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;BOGDANOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">**BOGDANOV** is a prominent Russian military theorist and strategist who has significantly contributed to the discourse surrounding modern warfare.  He is known for his co-authorship with **Chekinov** on numerous articles and studies exploring the nature of new-generation warfare, emphasizing the importance of information operations and unconventional strategies in achieving strategic goals. \n\nBogdanov\'s views have evolved over time, reflecting a shift towards recognizing the impact of informatization and automatization on conventional armed forces. He argues that nonmilitary means, such as color revolutions, can effectively address military threats, a perspective he shares with **Chekinov**.  \n\nHis work has been influential in shaping Russian military theory, particularly during the 2010s when he played a key role in debates surrounding National Security Concepts and unconventional warfare. Bogdanov\'s research at the Center for Military-Strategic Studies further highlights his expertise in contemporary armed conflict. He is also recognized as an analyst who discusses the influence of technology on military strategies and a researcher who explores 21st-century armed confrontations.  \n\nBogdanov\'s writings have been cited by other scholars, solidifying his position as a key figure in understanding the evolving landscape of warfare. His work has been influenced by **Slipchenko**, demonstrating the interconnectedness of ideas within Russian military thought.\n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0f6caa8f2e4b146cbd71b583add938f8,2a095cc3e0a26865ad75d88bf966ff8e,3e06cb0ad46a2e027bad24715e248b03,3e6ab14e2f0c4f2a8a611ac169b8dc44,5599962db5be274ac157280f1faa4590,663fcd1c899cf2232bc4bbdebe560f19,677c7a0f4f60503badb0a4d899c21d74,6e49482d37bfe8a11381f5fd9b2bf9ab,7be505fea57e0dbd921a3c195dd29aac,82893599bbdf88d7635db30797b87987,8b92cdcfa04a1ea8203cde59478b7bf8,8e59b8e09a13e3b59b06fd4c22fd9a1e,94370d1d5947827c2063332f75adfb60,988cfd2c3c636c6bc23a2455381cfe57,a3a7513f41e4fd6cb9e4f0decdbc615d,a8ab56e6e419d570a195fd2ea167899d,b45be955e924377403f02def4244bbcf,ba4314d7dde31a9a3de140b03d964db0,bd400dbd8e753ab71c9394fe8b1f07ce,d8383d735e3d4dedd141bc4b08e3eeaa,db7fc162ad9590d171cb7d6fc1ef0fc2,e216e7f3ed5bf3208c1f51eaa41603b8,e76184cff7bad45cbad7c9b1d3777f30,e89037639c79dd9077a756282d6c2a7d,ef55602335bea29d08150b6649fad897,fa6f1322c861f018219ae4741df2bae1,fc20acf548ac287cb2de74e6e1ea4d6e</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SLIPCHENKO&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">**SLIPCHENKO** is a significant Russian military theorist who is widely recognized as a key figure in the development of concepts surrounding sixth-generation warfare.  \n\nHe first introduced his ideas on generations of war in 1989, and his work has heavily influenced prominent military thinkers like Bogdanov, Chekinov, and Orekhov. Slipchenko\'s writings focus on the evolving nature of conventional warfare, particularly emphasizing the increasing importance of high-precision, long-range weapons and reconnaissance-strike systems. He argues that these systems hold overwhelming superiority in modern conflict. \n\nSlipchenko is also a leading proponent of "remote/contactless war," defining it as warfare conducted through precision strikes and information manipulation, viewing information itself as a destructive weapon. His theories on non-contact warfare and information dominance have been influential in shaping Russian military doctrine.  He is considered a significant expert on military history and the concept of generations of warfare, with his work cited extensively in academic and military circles. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">04b87a5b565ec557540bb2b0bf38763f,068fed974175a4460923174d7ce00bbf,0ac95daa24b8448799785bd3afba6112,12575d1b6f02a59280ed0326b418f907,12ae590d68b54130fcdd8b11cda495b2,276f8550d758346b203160a32cd885b6,2d96d25d0022a1193382ea88b904435a,3ff11360ddc5bd1fa296a784da747a6e,51b868d40e3701709987e796369fbf69,5599962db5be274ac157280f1faa4590,59b16bcd3d0d008e7066303a0111b65a,6cd14cb301caba80aed605f5aad6fc2e,7be505fea57e0dbd921a3c195dd29aac,83d8321db4baeb9dd56aa1e91eb29a39,85e4e298e365df474828bb853c808db1,8b92cdcfa04a1ea8203cde59478b7bf8,8c989fc0d3fc136d27a9f97d0fe40c82,8e59b8e09a13e3b59b06fd4c22fd9a1e,988cfd2c3c636c6bc23a2455381cfe57,a1fc196183277908b1cc6e1504847875,ac08e98f560a5dcdd378a622eca69f06,b29675ce5cc82b245a129a47bcd9a3d5,b7d2323e75cae9a4221b0eb05c65b171,ba4314d7dde31a9a3de140b03d964db0,c1fde4292cf13cc0042a258ed0932fb6,cd472d2664acb377dd498e88b7ed8d58,d494718117eae6e351eff5873eca32c0,d8383d735e3d4dedd141bc4b08e3eeaa,dcdc940fd2d0b50a2cd9e38ec0d2d76f,e216e7f3ed5bf3208c1f51eaa41603b8,ee529e2d08063744d6a3cc51b8b4775b,f773883fc42cbafe5e0268d526176d80,fb8a4e3d89439bd18b6f6ecae81d6d7c</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;THOMAS&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Thomas is a Western scholar and analyst who has been specializing in Russian information warfare since 1996. He is known for his research on Russian military thought, particularly focusing on continuity within it. Thomas argues that the US often neglects this continuity when analyzing Russia\'s approach to conflict through the lens of hybrid and gray area concepts.  \n\nHis work delves into the writings of prominent Russian military theorists like Chekinov and Bogdanov, identifying Slipchenko as a key influence. He has also examined the concept of Non-Governmental Warfare (NGW) in Russian military literature, noting its apparent disappearance from recent texts. Thomas\'s publications cover a range of topics related to Russia\'s view of warfare, including propaganda, hybrid warfare, and the Gerasimov doctrine.  He is recognized as an expert who has contributed significantly to understanding the evolution of war and Russia\'s role within it. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0a127d33c040b6f998a650ee92decc96,0d5bebc49e84be0b136baa2a23ad6119,3ac56cedae22345797ec130c512cc5b9,46383c461d50b84aa5f19d44407b0924,597b96f29d47f44fa260f97ed43bcb31,61fe19114215de9edf4b2df2fb6f0fb0,74abf737631531a56e8f3e9456798f10,850631a820a8158d8c7bff68e8f7fea5,ba4314d7dde31a9a3de140b03d964db0,d81d350aa6c9162a49b1eb526ae982b8,e216e7f3ed5bf3208c1f51eaa41603b8,e97880df6b33eecb3147aea6e798be7d,f3286050de3ac7fdc74f33ed1403c501</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;CHEKINOV &amp; BOGDANOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1" />\n      <data key="d2">3e6ab14e2f0c4f2a8a611ac169b8dc44,db7fc162ad9590d171cb7d6fc1ef0fc2,e216e7f3ed5bf3208c1f51eaa41603b8</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;KIRSHIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">KIRSHIN is an author who critiques traditional definitions of war, arguing that they are insufficient for comprehending modern global issues.  Their work centers on a debate surrounding Clausewitz\'s definition of war and its perceived limitations. KIRSHIN proposes a new understanding of war in their text, directly challenging existing paradigms. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">3e06cb0ad46a2e027bad24715e248b03,3e6ab14e2f0c4f2a8a611ac169b8dc44,82893599bbdf88d7635db30797b87987,f008ece3160552dbbd23842a0d13f1f7</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;CLAUSEWITZ&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">## Clausewitz: A Military Theorist Whose Ideas Continue to Spark Debate\n\nClausewitz, a Prussian general and military theorist, is widely recognized for his influential ideas on war. He is best known for his dictum, "war is merely a continuation of politics by other means," which suggests that war is an extension of political objectives pursued through violence. Clausewitz defined war as "an act of force to compel the enemy to do your will," emphasizing the use of force to achieve desired outcomes. \n\nHis work has been both praised and criticized by subsequent military theorists. While some, like Lenin and Stalin, found his emphasis on the relationship between politics and war influential, others, such as Kirshin, Kvachkov, and Orekhov, considered his definition too narrow.  Soviet theorists, while acknowledging Clausewitz\'s influence, often contrasted his traditional understanding of war with their own Marxist-Leninist perspectives. \n\nClausewitz\'s ideas continue to be debated and analyzed today. His work is referenced in discussions about modern warfare concepts, and his views on achieving victory in war are still considered relevant by military scholars like Gorbunov and Bogdanov. Despite the passage of time, Clausewitz remains a significant figure in military history, whose theories continue to shape our understanding of war and its relationship to politics. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">046f04af090c144a8bd1403c6c5879a4,08b5b9a81f792e1a63e929dc06a81d50,0b7f36c1efd528460ea8b64f4d00c6a9,11b09d5fddbfffd21c2a75e43b225a4a,135bc11aa823b69772040362565fae86,137a23ec0a6c30f2d104480a42ca716b,1b996f45c7b397759863385a53361eed,1cce175e6c7003db4a0791abde031a39,1d746c1fd3ea7d25a42568701611f772,2999e2ab9620ec881fdf22361f3bb121,2be40bedc401aa74026067cbca67b681,2f7216242ac705ab8c989c77c74d477b,3215346816955c73a119fe8038088c8e,37215a6c4810a7b385fb17417f94fbe0,38c01208da0359baa45c7640d7a2285c,3e06cb0ad46a2e027bad24715e248b03,3e6ab14e2f0c4f2a8a611ac169b8dc44,4424ff0552ddcfee2317f7caf01db070,4640d14036dc3924713f8e3da33466d6,4d3bd4beec226501211dcd3560fd6fba,4e2896fd5b6f31d006ca18e1a3299553,54841d8827acc62d9af1b1f976a8c99f,5f022b2409af8223bf100e9564e5f586,7aef3b8e0c0a9cd9f240dfbe12e02c38,82893599bbdf88d7635db30797b87987,83d8321db4baeb9dd56aa1e91eb29a39,86135dd72edc8f7cfa522d2093158942,897b3e3eedf4e832571846d6ff67fabe,962347193b87926e833cb5e1de7ff4e2,a15ef9eda68738122db496f9962d6a9f,b1b64ef207d42a2b81118c978ce1f222,bab940f0cf76af894b6edb440a57b5f8,bfa15fcd5d4a19aa65f946d1af780d5f,c4d611eafc5e900466e378a2742c03bf,cca1605d479526e189239aac472c3e7e,d1330c3cbc7e7877db9ba902371af4d9,db7fc162ad9590d171cb7d6fc1ef0fc2,e847464375c697471e8db8e76b49b6d1,f008ece3160552dbbd23842a0d13f1f7,f196fc7516d60a5e95b2a477d1f0b3f7,f1ea10917ad6f50fda3a92586fe998dc,fb8a4e3d89439bd18b6f6ecae81d6d7c</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;CRIMEAN OPERATION&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"EVENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"The Crimean operation is described as an example of new-generation warfare."</data>\n      <data key="d2">3e06cb0ad46a2e027bad24715e248b03</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;CHEKINOV AND BOGDANOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Chekinov and Bogdanov are a pair of authors and scholars who have significantly contributed to the evolving understanding of modern warfare. They argue that the nature of war has shifted, emphasizing unconventional tactics, information warfare, and psychological operations as crucial elements in contemporary military strategy. \n\nTheir work highlights the importance of information operations and reconnaissance-strike systems, contending that wars in recent decades have been characterized by "controlled chaos."  They believe that information-psychological warfare will be increasingly vital in future conflicts, aiming to influence populations, erode morale, and control troops. Chekinov and Bogdanov also explore the role of foreign grants in potentially destabilizing a country\'s social system through attacks. \n\nInfluenced by Slipchenko\'s ideas, they have published articles and conducted research on these topics, contributing to the broader discourse on security doctrines and the changing face of warfare.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0d5bebc49e84be0b136baa2a23ad6119,1907c51ffd4a90ea75fb1ba62cee3e69,2d96d25d0022a1193382ea88b904435a,38bf7298856b8fd4341bb0998b803ee0,3bd04ac8a624fe79e353bb14221b8554,406ecd4768447aa06d26731538246770,4f7f4f6fe9d288255da50532faa25f53,68355cf380d714ea713e77efbe44d3ac,68e4ed89f41a580e3c58f0f98434cc33,6b6ac6cc3ec6eac44948fcf6afcb38d9,757d82782cf6930b803cbaa29e0f5a1a,8107ca436cb6585337e956c4238a346c,8196d4fb9caac5c7ffd87f465eac8c12,83d8321db4baeb9dd56aa1e91eb29a39,b29675ce5cc82b245a129a47bcd9a3d5,b3066af57efb89b0569dbadaba8b79bc,bd0d9bfb86c0dbbc88767c3e5a743934,beb665481df870fd27048e10898e8bac,cb50fafd31d07b9e8f9e52f658937913,d494718117eae6e351eff5873eca32c0,ff55559376e5dd4c5e5cb9f53d33e241,ff779b872510c138da68523b69265b0e</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;INSTITUTIONS&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">## Institutions\n\nInstitutions are established organizations with a defined purpose. They often play a role in shaping strategies and can encompass a wide range of entities.  Some institutions, particularly those involved in research, may receive funding from foreign sources and could potentially participate in distributed attacks. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">8107ca436cb6585337e956c4238a346c,8c89f749cd4aa8e422be2a970f803bec</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SCHOLARS&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Scholars are individuals who conduct research and analysis in the field of strategic theory. They are experts who agree on the effectiveness of limited nuclear use in deterring conventional hostilities, often engaging in research on foreign grants and their potential impact.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">37a79c861cb20a05659b6f1b76b007ba,5df832f6cec6c27ae77e370f07cac8d6,8107ca436cb6585337e956c4238a346c</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;ARAB SPRING REVOLUTIONS&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"EVENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **Arab Spring Revolutions** are described as both applications of Western technology and spontaneous uprisings, reflecting conflicting perspectives on their nature. Some argue that they serve as evidence for a new military age characterized by "high-tech wars," citing the use of advanced technology in these uprisings.  Others emphasize the organic and grassroots nature of the revolutions, suggesting they were primarily driven by popular discontent rather than sophisticated military strategies. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0d5bebc49e84be0b136baa2a23ad6119,465274671b741f3ad76a316d27207a5f,8107ca436cb6585337e956c4238a346c</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;OV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">OV is a commandant at the Academy of the General Staff and holds a high position within the Soviet Armed Forces.  As a speaker, OV\'s rhetoric reflects both established views on the nature of war and an awareness of its evolving characteristics. Additionally, OV is recognized as an author or organization that published a work in 2009. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">27431841e2c6fbfbbcda31bea529d948,972ad08450d40acba47394c99e434c56,9bccda96a6276236341ab0595d832858,9d078dbf3cd9f132d9d452509bd774f1,c6bceb66a3d2c04618fc4513ce73962c</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;ACADEMY OF THE GENERAL STAFF&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **Academy of the General Staff** is a prestigious institution within the Soviet Armed Forces. It serves as a hub for developing and sharing military expertise,  and it holds a high position of importance within the force structure. Notably, Kuralenko worked at the Academy as the chief of military art. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">27431841e2c6fbfbbcda31bea529d948,68e7972f85fd6fc2109534ff86630800,6e81ca9f9ef3229b5c0e79413b269e37,9bccda96a6276236341ab0595d832858,fd24a983ae975cadc842ce8fa5eea97c</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SOVIET ARMED FORCES&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The Soviet Armed Forces are the military force of the Soviet Union.  Under the leadership of Nikita Khrushchev, they were a powerful organization where individuals like Gen. Vladimir Kurasov held top positions. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">2090f56414eebaeb642f4296f8762613,27431841e2c6fbfbbcda31bea529d948,5fc5a6b5aebd3d100c1491fc135bc6da,6e81ca9f9ef3229b5c0e79413b269e37,9bccda96a6276236341ab0595d832858</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;STALIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Joseph Stalin was a key figure in Soviet military strategy whose ideas remain influential.  He dominated Soviet strategic thought due to his control of both the Communist Party and the military apparatus. Stalin viewed Clausewitz\'s ideas as already present in Marxist theory, and he criticized the premise that Clausewitz is obsolete, arguing for its relevance in Lenin\'s thought. His influence extended to the suppression of opposing viewpoints, such as those of Svechin, whose work he placed under restriction. Despite his death marking a potential shift in the relationship between military and political leadership, subordination of the military to political control persisted. Stalin\'s military art continues to be analyzed and discussed by historians. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">11b09d5fddbfffd21c2a75e43b225a4a,27431841e2c6fbfbbcda31bea529d948,38c01208da0359baa45c7640d7a2285c,9bccda96a6276236341ab0595d832858,cca1605d479526e189239aac472c3e7e,d1330c3cbc7e7877db9ba902371af4d9,ee2a956c830712b74c912b175f90afdd</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;VASILY SOKOLOVSKY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Vasily Sokolovsky is a prominent Soviet military theorist. He emphasized the importance of Marxist-Leninist dialectics in understanding war and defined it as armed violence between different groups for political goals.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">27431841e2c6fbfbbcda31bea529d948,3d90ffe5fbb2fe4d1036ef242b8830be,b90af97596777a0400f9c331a5d96a40,e8d8461aeecbc6801361ca4fa5c3e2e2</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SOVIET MILITARY SCIENCE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">Soviet Military Science is a field of study that focuses on developing methods and forms of armed conflict within the context of the Soviet Union.  It draws heavily upon the precepts of the Communist Party, incorporating dialectical materialism and historical analysis to form its system of knowledge about war. \n\nCharacterized by holism, Soviet military science emphasizes the interconnectedness of all aspects of war, recognizing that military success depends on a comprehensive understanding of political, economic, social, and technological factors.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">27431841e2c6fbfbbcda31bea529d948,2a4b75db8fdd23483fc6c4f097c7f56f,2be40bedc401aa74026067cbca67b681,4424ff0552ddcfee2317f7caf01db070,645ce27900f66a0b633be93f0e5d6399,8c7cf0e88b403959479bde7eb44c8654,b4cf9c163a2ba0d0db3385c6741457ac,e90da29be1148d9844e3ed777db08bf6</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MARXIST PHILOSOPHY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">Marxist philosophy, with its roots in Hegelian dialectics, is a foundational element of Soviet military science.  It heavily influences the development and application of military strategy and doctrine within the Soviet Union. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">27431841e2c6fbfbbcda31bea529d948,2be40bedc401aa74026067cbca67b681,4424ff0552ddcfee2317f7caf01db070</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;HEGELIAN DIALECTICS&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Hegelian Dialectics serves as the philosophical bedrock for Marxist philosophy, an influence that extends to Soviet military science.
