key="d6">6fe4faca1e39cc57f7c84b772a87fd4d</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;CROSS-DOMAIN COERCION&quot;" target="&quot;NGW&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Cross-domain Coercion is a key element of NGW (New Generation Warfare), which integrates military and non-military measures to achieve strategic objectives."</data>\n      <data key="d6">7ae0f631f330850ca53d02c933c953ce</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MILITARY-POLITICAL ADMINISTRATION&quot;" target="&quot;KRASNAYA ZVEZDA&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Voyennaya Mys"</data>\n      <data key="d6">6388873944a12dfd98e41c61c757f3d8</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;VOYENNAYA MYSL&quot;" target="&quot;GENERAL STAFF&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The General Staff is in charge of publishing Voyennaya Mysl."</data>\n      <data key="d6">5bc1d54f3233915280db63e273e03592</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;SOKOLOVSKY&quot;" target="&quot;VOYENNAYA STRATEGIYA (MILITARY STRATEGY)&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Sokolovsky wrote Voyennaya Strategiya, where he refuted claims about the nature of war."</data>\n      <data key="d6">2cb92533547d702e1894fcea545257ee</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;SOKOLOVSKY&quot;" target="&quot;WAR&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">3.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">Sokolovsky is a scholar who defines war narrowly, focusing solely on armed violence. He has also been known to refute claims about the nature of war that go beyond this definition. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d6">2cb92533547d702e1894fcea545257ee,313dc3be1190b1a10a2579c621091156,7be505fea57e0dbd921a3c195dd29aac</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;NIKOLSKY&quot;" target="&quot;WAR&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Nikolsky argued that war had ceased to be an instrument of policy."</data>\n      <data key="d6">2cb92533547d702e1894fcea545257ee</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;TALENSKY&quot;" target="&quot;WAR&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Talensky argued that war had ceased to be an instrument of policy."</data>\n      <data key="d6">2cb92533547d702e1894fcea545257ee</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;GARTHOFF&quot;" target="&quot;WAR&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Garthoff provided evidence for the claim that war had ceased to be an instrument of policy."</data>\n      <data key="d6">2cb92533547d702e1894fcea545257ee</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;KVACHKOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Kvachkov proposes a definition of war that includes non-military means."</data>\n      <data key="d6">c4d611eafc5e900466e378a2742c03bf</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;SEREBRYANNIKOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">2.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">Serebryannikov believes that armed conflict should be the defining characteristic of war, advocating for a clear distinction between war and peace.  He argues against blurring these lines, emphasizing the importance of military action in defining a state of war. However, his conclusions share similarities with Kvachkov\'s definition of war, which encompasses both military and non-military means. \n</data>\n      <data key="d6">48e310bd8a37fd938fc512819430d5f7,c4d611eafc5e900466e378a2742c03bf</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;GAREYEV&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">3.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">According to Gareyev, **War** is defined as an armed struggle and the use of military violence.  While Gareyev maintains that armed conflict is the defining factor of war, he also acknowledges the growing significance of non-military means in modern warfare.  Gareyev\'s definition of war extends beyond traditional notions of armed conflict, encompassing a broader understanding of the concept. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d6">7567750cec0624c2e9f362f989d8b1bc,c4d611eafc5e900466e378a2742c03bf,c8c68899e22ee8c693d6e73e47d38c9e</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;CLAUSEWITZ&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">5.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">Carl von Clausewitz is a prominent figure whose ideas about war continue to be analyzed and discussed.  He believed that **war is the continuation of politics by other means**. This definition, articulated by Clausewitz, is frequently referenced by scholars such as Kvachkov, Gareyev, Gorbunov, and Bogdanov in their examinations of war\'s nature and strategies for achieving victory.  Clausewitz\'s theories emphasize the importance of either destroying the enemy or weakening their resolve to resist as key factors in securing victory on the battlefield. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d6">37215a6c4810a7b385fb17417f94fbe0,4e2896fd5b6f31d006ca18e1a3299553,7aef3b8e0c0a9cd9f240dfbe12e02c38,bfa15fcd5d4a19aa65f946d1af780d5f,c4d611eafc5e900466e378a2742c03bf</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;MODERN CONDITIONS&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Modern conditions are said to have transformed the nature of war."</data>\n      <data key="d6">a5ccc3b4de720472fb0ba6dbc764cdba</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;ARMED STRUGGLE&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">2.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">War and armed struggle are closely related concepts.  The Ministry of Defense identifies armed struggle as the primary element of war. However, it\'s acknowledged that in modern warfare, armed conflict may not always be the most crucial factor. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d6">2836f2f0365794d9fae3abfa350f2311,a5ccc3b4de720472fb0ba6dbc764cdba</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;MILITARY THEORISTS&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Military theorists study and analyze war, including its various aspects such as nonmilitary means."</data>\n      <data key="d6">30386c4e76d744b895d430847b713f0a</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;KALISTRATOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">2.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">Kalistratov proposes a broader definition of WAR, encompassing elements beyond traditional notions of armed violence.  He suggests that war extends into various domains, highlighting its multifaceted nature. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d6">313dc3be1190b1a10a2579c621091156,7be505fea57e0dbd921a3c195dd29aac</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;PAVEL KAZARIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Kazarin argues that war should be understood as a sum of its total features, including economic and information warfare."</data>\n      <data key="d6">cfae2a9660e62a12a25d2678a2931f34</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;BURENOK&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Burenok believes that war has changed, focusing on influencing minds rather than physical conflict."</data>\n      <data key="d6">3060e5a3570413999878edce8065dc2b</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;PEACE&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">2.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">According to Gerasimov, the lines separating **war** and **peace** are becoming increasingly indistinct.  This perspective aligns with Lenin\'s view, which presents **peace** as an extension of political maneuvering. \n</data>\n      <data key="d6">8501d99fb9d704c9315278702413ee9e,beabdeed11a36088777fbee158b3a3f5</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;CARL VON CLAUSEWITZ&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Clausewitz believed that all wars are political in purpose."</data>\n      <data key="d6">c0ae1b35d101dd5c80796ebcaaa52998</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;MARX AND ENGELS&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">2.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">Marx and Engels viewed war as a continuation of political struggles between powers and classes, holding a different perspective on the subject compared to Lenin.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d6">342381013c3f61db48a3a2b2bc77370c,b1b64ef207d42a2b81118c978ce1f222</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;LENIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">2.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">Lenin redefined the concept of war, emphasizing its deep connection to a country\'s internal policies. He viewed war not merely as external conflict but as a reflection of pre-war internal politics.  This perspective presented a paradox for Lenin: he believed war was an inherently evil phenomenon that could only be eradicated through further acts of war. \n</data>\n      <data key="d6">3cd3649d4d82b16c6d105090d8081f6e,b1b64ef207d42a2b81118c978ce1f222</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;TROTSKY&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Trotsky saw violence as the defining feature of war, even in the context of technological advancements."</data>\n      <data key="d6">b1b64ef207d42a2b81118c978ce1f222</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;CHEKINOV AND BOGDANOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Chekinov and Bogdanov argue about the nature of modern war, including non-military measures."</data>\n      <data key="d6">68355cf380d714ea713e77efbe44d3ac</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;M-LENINIZM O VOINE I ARMII&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The book m-Leninizm o voine i armii defines war as the continuation of politics by means of armed force, emphasizing armed struggle as the defining factor."</data>\n      <data key="d6">d62c24f2a958cdd90af90b2fee315132</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;KHRUSHCHEV&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Khrushchev believed that war should be avoided and advocated for peaceful means of resolving conflict between social systems."</data>\n      <data key="d6">d62c24f2a958cdd90af90b2fee315132</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;COEXISTENCE&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Khrushchev saw coexistence as the continuation of the struggle between social systems, but without resorting to war."</data>\n      <data key="d6">d62c24f2a958cdd90af90b2fee315132</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;GORBUNOV AND BOGDANOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">2.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">WAR is a concept that Gorbunov and Bogdanov extensively analyze and discuss in their work.  They explore the evolving nature of war, delving into both traditional military strategies and the increasing importance of nonmilitary approaches within the realm of conflict. \n</data>\n      <data key="d6">37215a6c4810a7b385fb17417f94fbe0,7aef3b8e0c0a9cd9f240dfbe12e02c38</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;SUN TZU&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Sun Tzu\'s ideas on warfare are used by Gorbunov and Bogdanov to support their arguments about the evolving nature of conflict."</data>\n      <data key="d6">37215a6c4810a7b385fb17417f94fbe0</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;MARXIST-LENINIST&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Marxist-Leninist ideology views war as caused by economic factors driven by the ruling class."</data>\n      <data key="d6">ce0f551566143f746d8ff46f4a021065</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;B. K. KANEVSKY&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"B. K. Kanevsky argued that war includes nonmilitary means such as economic, diplomatic, intelligence, technological, and ideological."</data>\n      <data key="d6">39786aa4012dd6b57506633a91deaeca</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;WAR&quot;" target="&quot;P. N. SHABARDIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"P. N. Shabardin argued that war includes nonmilitary means such as economic, diplomatic, intelligence, technological, and ideological."</data>\n      <data key="d6">39786aa4012dd6b57506633a91deaeca</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MARXISM-LENINISM&quot;" target="&quot;MILITARY STRATEGY&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">2.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">Marxism-Leninism served as both the ideological and methodological foundation for military strategy in the Soviet Union.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d6">bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MARXISM-LENINISM&quot;" target="&quot;SOVIET MILITARY SCIENCE&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">3.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">**Marxism-Leninism** serves as the foundational ideology for **Soviet Military Science**.  All aspects of war and societal science within the Soviet Union are rooted in Marxism-Leninism, directly influencing the development and principles guiding Soviet military strategy and doctrine. This ideological framework became the driving force behind scientific advancements and research within the realm of Soviet military science. \n</data>\n      <data key="d6">2a4b75db8fdd23483fc6c4f097c7f56f,645ce27900f66a0b633be93f0e5d6399,e90da29be1148d9844e3ed777db08bf6</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;SOVIET IDEOLOGY&quot;" target="&quot;NATIONAL SECURITY CONCEPT&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">2.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">The disappearance of **Soviet Ideology** led to the introduction of new security policy documents, including the **National Security Concept**.  This shift in thinking signaled a move away from the previous ideological framework and towards new approaches to national security. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d6">bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;SOVIET IDEOLOGY&quot;" target="&quot;SOVIET WAY&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The Soviet way is a manifestation or application of Soviet ideology."</data>\n      <data key="d6">65a1bf9e5672afc1a7011ffa78b1c211</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;SOVIET IDEOLOGY&quot;" target="&quot;JUST AND UNJUST WARS&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The classification of just and unjust wars is a central tenet within Soviet ideology."</data>\n      <data key="d6">65a1bf9e5672afc1a7011ffa78b1c211</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MINISTRY OF DEFENSE&quot;" target="&quot;MILITARY DOCTRINE&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">4.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">The **Ministry of Defense** is responsible for creating, publishing, and providing information about the **Military Doctrine**. The doctrine itself was drafted exclusively by the Ministry of Defense.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d6">7357dc206ba88482f202ea79850252f2,9d9628ed6f319fa3c7a74e5a5971aad6,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,df2540cf569ce35f7b90708e5da0b01d</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MINISTRY OF DEFENSE&quot;" target="&quot;DOCTRINE&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">2.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">The MINISTRY OF DEFENSE is responsible for both creating and revising DOCTRINE.  They are the author and issuer of all doctrines. \n</data>\n      <data key="d6">0da7185a3277e6969d5f94e97613b636,390e6b6bbf2dbf4ee3678f7e9b5afaed</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MINISTRY OF DEFENSE&quot;" target="&quot;2010 MILITARY DOCTRINE&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The Ministry of Defense issued the 2010 Military Doctrine."</data>\n      <data key="d6">0e40df5d22db6584ec7e05b07c3d9b66</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MINISTRY OF DEFENSE&quot;" target="&quot;DEFENSE 2010&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The Ministry of Defense issued the Defense 2010 document."</data>\n      <data key="d6">927ecbbd9a7b08760bb62d394dcd75e9</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MINISTRY OF DEFENSE&quot;" target="&quot;MILITARY DOCTRINE 2000&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The Ministry of Defense is responsible for creating the Military Doctrine of 2000."</data>\n      <data key="d6">9976fb85179c1c48e3cfe309be6108c7</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MINISTRY OF DEFENSE&quot;" target="&quot;ENCYCLOPEDIA OF THE MINISTRY OF DEFENSE&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The Ministry of Defense published the Encyclopedia of the Ministry of Defense defining war in 2007."</data>\n      <data key="d6">287b17a01df64083a49c84828ae77591</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MINISTRY OF DEFENSE&quot;" target="&quot;BURENOK&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Vasily Burenok is a high-ranking official in the Ministry of Defense."</data>\n      <data key="d6">3060e5a3570413999878edce8065dc2b</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MINISTRY OF DEFENSE&quot;" target="&quot;2000 MILITARY DOCTRINE&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The Ministry of Defense created the 2000 Military Doctrine."</data>\n      <data key="d6">30ff2b3a1ac3fddc8b200986ef1f24f4</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MINISTRY OF DEFENSE&quot;" target="&quot;MILITARY DOCTRINE OF 2014&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The Ministry of Defense is the author or publisher of the Military Doctrine of 2014."</data>\n      <data key="d6">4c0b295b06b41e7a8105d7587f0ad731</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MINISTRY OF DEFENSE&quot;" target="&quot;SUBVERSION-WARS&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The Ministry of Defense defines Subversion-Wars as armed fighting by insurgent or rebel forces."</data>\n      <data key="d6">fdc2c2b29672f18ffe9ae9fb2f1da756</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;SECURITY COUNCIL&quot;" target="&quot;MILITARY DOCTRINE&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The Security Council was involved in producing the Military Doctrine."</data>\n      <data key="d6">fcbe7cb6c5543166265ebbc898ee34ba</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MINISTRY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS&quot;" target="&quot;FOREIGN POLICY CONCEPT&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">3.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">The **Foreign Policy Concept** is a document developed and published by the **Ministry of Foreign Affairs**. The Ministry is responsible for ensuring the publication of this important policy document. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d6">0fbf2c2d34dfce0579218bcd864902ec,5910165c2ae0e582998b2c2de2b57f54,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MINISTRY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS&quot;" target="&quot;MILITARY DOCTRINE&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The Ministry of Foreign Affairs produced the Foreign Policy Concept, which influenced the Military Doctrine."</data>\n      <data key="d6">fcbe7cb6c5543166265ebbc898ee34ba</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MINISTRY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS&quot;" target="&quot;FOREIGN POLICY CONCEPT OF 2000&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The Ministry of Foreign Affairs outlines the Foreign Policy Concept of 2000."</data>\n      <data key="d6">9976fb85179c1c48e3cfe309be6108c7</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MINISTRY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS&quot;" target="&quot;CONCEPT OF 2000&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">2.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">The **Ministry of Foreign Affairs** originated and published the **Concept of 2000**, a document outlining Russia\'s foreign policy.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d6">287b17a01df64083a49c84828ae77591,9a4e544128564ba75a290bb651a8ccfc</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MINISTRY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS&quot;" target="&quot;LAVROV&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Lavrov is associated with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, suggesting his position and influence within it."</data>\n      <data key="d6">c2324291b2afa91371cc2c27eeb6979e</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;NATIONAL SECURITY CONCEPT&quot;" target="&quot;RUSSIAN FEDERATION&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The National Security Concept is a document specific to the Russian Federation\'s security policy."</data>\n      <data key="d6">bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;NATIONAL SECURITY CONCEPT&quot;" target="&quot;MILITARY DOCTRINE&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">2.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">The **NATIONAL SECURITY CONCEPT** is a Foreign Policy Concept. It differs from **MILITARY DOCTRINE** in its approach to the threats facing Russia.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d6">da8ce201ab8466858c322bea48bb9804,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;NATIONAL SECURITY CONCEPT&quot;" target="&quot;BOGDANOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Bogdanov was influential in the debate surrounding the National Security Concept in the 2010s."</data>\n      <data key="d6">663fcd1c899cf2232bc4bbdebe560f19</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;NATIONAL SECURITY CONCEPT&quot;" target="&quot;RUSSIAN MILITARY THEORY&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The National Security Concept is influenced by and reflects Russian military theory."</data>\n      <data key="d6">663fcd1c899cf2232bc4bbdebe560f19</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;NATIONAL SECURITY CONCEPT&quot;" target="&quot;DEVELOPED WESTERN COUNTRIES&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The 2000 National Security Concept viewed \'attempts to create an international relations structure based on domination by developed Western countries\' as a threat."</data>\n      <data key="d6">663fcd1c899cf2232bc4bbdebe560f19</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;RUSSIAN FEDERATION&quot;" target="&quot;DEFENSE 2010&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Defense 2010 focuses on the internal military dangers facing the Russian Federation."</data>\n      <data key="d6">927ecbbd9a7b08760bb62d394dcd75e9</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;RUSSIAN FEDERATION&quot;" target="&quot;MILITARY DOCTRINE&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">2.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">The **Russian Federation**\'s **Military Doctrine** defines the country\'s military posture as a response to perceived threats.  Currently, the **Russian Federation** is in the process of updating its **Military Doctrine** to better address these evolving threats. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d6">841ac43154acf1df4c5e3af00e7d0360,da8ce201ab8466858c322bea48bb9804</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;RUSSIAN FEDERATION&quot;" target="&quot;FOREIGN POLICY CONCEPT&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The Foreign Policy Concept outlines strategies for the Russian Federation to address its perceived security challenges."</data>\n      <data key="d6">da8ce201ab8466858c322bea48bb9804</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;RUSSIAN FEDERATION&quot;" target="&quot;GULF WAR&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">3.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">The Gulf War influenced the thinking of Russian military theorists within the newly established Russian Federation. This influence extended to both theoretical frameworks and practical doctrines employed by the Russian military. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d6">2ced16684237fb065035dffff5afc8b4,e9def1a80602f476ecce04216e4a8a03,f6f3bf4797ee25c5c62c11e81fb4fa83</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;RUSSIAN FEDERATION&quot;" target="&quot;CHECHEN WARS&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">3.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">The Chechen Wars presented significant challenges to the Russian Armed Forces within the Russian Federation.  These conflicts caused difficulties and problems for the military, testing their capabilities and strategies. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d6">2ced16684237fb065035dffff5afc8b4,e9def1a80602f476ecce04216e4a8a03,f6f3bf4797ee25c5c62c11e81fb4fa83</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;RUSSIAN FEDERATION&quot;" target="&quot;GEN. Makhmut Gareyev is a military figure within the Russian Federation who expressed concerns about modern warfare tactics."</data>\n      <data key="d6">2ced16684237fb065035dffff5afc8b4</data>\n associations and groups are identified as a threat to the unity and territorial integrity of the Russian Federation."</data>\n      <data key="d6">cb233c91ebbe8b4085763d57986b71ca</data>\n They have co-authored multiple articles together, including one discussing modern warfare and another arguing for nonmilitary solutions over military ones.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d6">3e6ab14e2f0c4f2a8a611ac169b8dc44,8e59b8e09a13e3b59b06fd4c22fd9a1e,bd400dbd8e753ab71c9394fe8b1f07ce,e216e7f3ed5bf3208c1f51eaa41603b8</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;CHEKINOV&quot;" target="&quot;OREKHOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Chekinov and Orekhov collaborated on articles about modern warfare, suggesting a shared interest in the topic."</data>\n      <data key="d6">8e59b8e09a13e3b59b06fd4c22fd9a1e</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;BOGDANOV&quot;" target="&quot;SLIPCHENKO&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">2.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">Both Bogdanov and Slipchenko share similar perspectives on the nature of future warfare.  Bogdanov\'s theories on future war are heavily influenced by, and closely align with, Slipchenko\'s ideas. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d6">7be505fea57e0dbd921a3c195dd29aac,8e59b8e09a13e3b59b06fd4c22fd9a1e</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;BOGDANOV&quot;" target="&quot;FUTURE WAR&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">2.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">Bogdanov is a theorist who outlines his vision of Future War, emphasizing "contactless" methods and economic destruction. </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;THOMAS&quot;" target="&quot;RUSSIAN THOUGHT&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">2.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">Thomas asserts that the United States overlooks a crucial element of continuity within Russian thought when prioritizing the analysis of hybrid and gray area concepts.  He concludes that despite these contemporary trends, there exists a consistent thread running through Russian thought that the US may be neglecting in its assessments. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d6">46383c461d50b84aa5f19d44407b0924,d81d350aa6c9162a49b1eb526ae982b8</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;THOMAS&quot;" target="&quot;KARTAPOLOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Thomas wrote about Kartapolov and his role in the Russian military."</data>\n      <data key="d6">850631a820a8158d8c7bff68e8f7fea5</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;CHEKINOV &amp; BOGDANOV&quot;" target="&quot;WAR IN UKRAINE&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"The War in Ukraine occurred after the publication of Chekinov and Bogdanov\'s article."</data>\n      <data key="d6">3e6ab14e2f0c4f2a8a611ac169b8dc44</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;KIRSHIN&quot;" target="&quot;CLAUSEWITZ&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Kirshin participates in a debate about Clausewitz\'s definition of war."</data>\n      <data key="d6">3e6ab14e2f0c4f2a8a611ac169b8dc44</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;CLAUSEWITZ&quot;" target="&quot;WAR DEFINITION&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Clausewitz\'s definition of war is referenced and criticized by Kvachkov for being too focused on armed violence."</data>\n      <data key="d6">4640d14036dc3924713f8e3da33466d6</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;CLAUSEWITZ&quot;" target="&quot;KVACHKOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Kvachkov criticizes Clausewitz\'s definition of war."</data>\n      <data key="d6">e847464375c697471e8db8e76b49b6d1</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;CLAUSEWITZ&quot;" target="&quot;LENIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">4.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">Both **Clausewitz** and **Lenin** are prominent figures in military and political thought.  While **Lenin** acknowledged and appreciated **Clausewitz\'s** use of dialectics, he also criticized **Clausewitz\'s** definition of war for treating policy as solely the foreign policy interests of a unitary state. Despite this criticism, **Lenin** incorporated aspects of **Clausewitz\'s** theories into his own thinking and work. \n</data>\n      <data key="d6">2be40bedc401aa74026067cbca67b681,38c01208da0359baa45c7640d7a2285c,b1b64ef207d42a2b81118c978ce1f222,cca1605d479526e189239aac472c3e7e</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge Stalin provided a response to Rasin\'s question concerning the applicability of Clausewitz\'s ideas in modern times. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d6">38c01208da0359baa45c7640d7a2285c,cca1605d479526e189239aac472c3e7e</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;VASILY SOKOLOVSKY&quot;" target="&quot;SOVIET MILITARY SCIENCE&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Vasily Sokolovsky is a proponent of using Marxist-Leninist dialectics in Soviet military science."</data>\n      <data key="d6">27431841e2c6fbfbbcda31bea529d948</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;SOVIET MILITARY SCIENCE&quot;" target="&quot;MARXIST PHILOSOPHY&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Marxist philosophy and dialectics are seen as fundamental to the scientific basis of Soviet military science."</data>\n      <data key="d6">27431841e2c6fbfbbcda31bea529d948</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;SOVIET MILITARY SCIENCE&quot;" target="&quot;DIALECTICAL MATERIALISM&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">3.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">Soviet military science is fundamentally shaped by the principles of dialectical materialism.  Both Soviet military science and dialectical materialism are deeply intertwined, with the latter serving as the foundational framework for the former. \n</data>\n      <data key="d6">2a4b75db8fdd23483fc6c4f097c7f56f,2be40bedc401aa74026067cbca67b681,4424ff0552ddcfee2317f7caf01db070</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;SOVIET MILITARY SCIENCE&quot;" target="&quot;LENIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">3.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">Lenin believed that all scientific inquiry, encompassing both warfare and societal structures, should be grounded in the principles of Marxism-Leninism. This ideological stance significantly influenced the development of **Soviet Military Science**, establishing Marxism-Leninism as its foundational framework. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d6">2a4b75db8fdd23483fc6c4f097c7f56f,645ce27900f66a0b633be93f0e5d6399,e90da29be1148d9844e3ed777db08bf6</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;SOVIET MILITARY SCIENCE&quot;" target="&quot;HOLISM&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Soviet military science is founded upon holism."</data>\n      <data key="d6">2a4b75db8fdd23483fc6c4f097c7f56f</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;SOVIET MILITARY SCIENCE&quot;" target="&quot;MILITARY KNOWLEDGE&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Soviet Military Science aimed to develop \'scientifically\' developed military thought, which was considered a basic necessity by theorists like Tukhachevsky, Shaposhnikov, Frunze, Svechin, and Trotsky."</data>\n      <data key="d6">e90da29be1148d9844e3ed777db08bf6</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;MARXIST PHILOSOPHY&quot;" target="&quot;HEGELIAN DIALECTICS&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">1.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">"Marxist philosophy draws its roots from Hegelian dialectics."</data>\n      <data key="d6">2be40bedc401aa74026067cbca67b681</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;DIALECTICAL MATERIALISM&quot;" target="&quot;GEORG HEGEL&quot;">\n      <data key="d4">2.0</data>\n      <data key="d5">Dialectical Materialism is a philosophical concept that stands in contrast to Georg Hegel\'s idealistic metaphysics.  While Hegel\'s ideas were influential, they were ultimately rejected in favor of dialectical materialism, as highlighted by texts that directly compare and contrast the two philosophies. \n</data>\n      <data key="d6">645ce27900f66a0b633be93f0e5d6399,e8980bd806b32ffd5ad4b169a299338d</data>\n    </edge>\n    <edge source="&quot;DIALECTICAL MATERIALISM&quot;" target="&quot;RED ARMY&quot;">\n   <node id="&quot;US MILITARY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **US Military** is recognized for its technological superiority, particularly demonstrated during the Gulf War where it outmatched Iraqi forces.  Its MTR/RMA doctrine, later known as network-centric warfare (NCW), has been a subject of interest and debate within both Soviet and contemporary Russian military circles. Analyses comparing and contrasting the strategies employed by the **US Military** and the **Russian Military** further highlight its unique approach to warfare. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">00641f6f7299e02e813e3f9b6264b19e,a19173a530680219eb5e0efd973893c0,cf62fdb14a3fc4c98b15edb2ffdb6dd6,d0c05f8ec94cd42a4727a66ae84be4dd</data>\n      <data key="d6">1</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">2</data>\n      <data key="d5">d3835bf3dda84ead99deadbeac5d0d7d</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;HOFFMAN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Hoffman is a prominent figure in the study of modern conflict, particularly known for his contributions to the understanding of strategic communications and hybrid warfare.  He argues that the term "political war" is an oxymoron because war inherently involves violence, suggesting that the true gray zones exist within our flawed models and education about conflict. \n\nHoffman is cited as one of the originators of the term "hybrid warfare," alongside Mattis. Together, they proposed a four-block war model that incorporates psychological and information operations. Hoffman also summarized the use of "hybrid warfare" by US political and military leaders. His work has significantly shaped our understanding of how strategic communications can transform strategic affairs in contemporary conflicts. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0fa028b232510c552f26de29d99b145b,6cb6b290fc24699cc0581b793cb749cd,a19173a530680219eb5e0efd973893c0,c0ae1b35d101dd5c80796ebcaaa52998,c14363837da220e50f2cbf6793eb94d2,d81d350aa6c9162a49b1eb526ae982b8,ff33e904e4d9308ef4fac68e0de16f71</data>\n      <data key="d6">0</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">2</data>\n      <data key="d4">3</data>\n      <data key="d5">077d2820ae1845bcbb1803379a3d1eae</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;FREEDMAN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">FREEDMAN is an author who has written extensively about war and its evolving nature, particularly focusing on hybrid warfare and the Gerasimov doctrine.  He is widely cited for emphasizing the crucial role of strategic communications in shaping and transforming strategic affairs. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">597b96f29d47f44fa260f97ed43bcb31,6cb6b290fc24699cc0581b793cb749cd,74abf737631531a56e8f3e9456798f10,a19173a530680219eb5e0efd973893c0,c14363837da220e50f2cbf6793eb94d2,f3286050de3ac7fdc74f33ed1403c501</data>\n      <data key="d6">4</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">4</data>\n      <data key="d5">3671ea0dd4e84c1a9b02c5ab2c8f4bac</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SOVIET UNION&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The Soviet Union was a former communist state and a major geopolitical entity that existed from its establishment by Vladimir Lenin and Leon Trotsky until its dissolution in 1991. It was a key adversary of the United States during the Cold War, engaging in a nuclear arms race with NATO. The Soviet Union held a distinct understanding of war based on Marxist-Leninist ideology, which was firmly subordinated to the Communist Party. This understanding viewed war as an inevitable tool for accelerating the global communist transformation and as the continuation of class politics by violent means.  \n\nThe Soviet Union believed that all wars stemmed from class struggle and that actions could be justified if they furthered the revolutionary process, differing from Western just war theory. They established control over half of Central Europe during World War II and were a major player in both World Wars. The Soviet Union\'s rise is linked to the revolutionary context. \n\nThe Soviet Union laid the theoretical and methodological foundation for Russian military theory, which persists today.  This foundation was shaped by internal and external threats and heavily influenced by Marxist-Leninist theories about war. The text describes the Soviet Union as the location where understanding of war originated from the Communist Party. It discusses the history and characteristics of military thought within the Soviet Union, its foundational policy and military doctrine, and the nature of war within the context of the Soviet Union.  The dissolution of the Soviet Union led to a decline in Western interest in Russian military thought. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">00e7336d67609903b464740eecc2da73,046f04af090c144a8bd1403c6c5879a4,0b7f36c1efd528460ea8b64f4d00c6a9,0d5bebc49e84be0b136baa2a23ad6119,14442faf092eaecae58a72c1a981a33b,1b996f45c7b397759863385a53361eed,1b9b97610a4a892ffd4aa4057f98a99d,1d1f8fd7a97b7aca3ba71380fbbaa90c,1fdbdba8c71554268a8e4cacad9c056a,2090f56414eebaeb642f4296f8762613,2ced16684237fb065035dffff5afc8b4,31d8ac7fc85d988e67da2c6480208aad,32d948fc460c6d1bb1d9682bfd136dd3,355bb2e7269c004d598030ff8348dda0,39b41cfcdca61ad353853416d904417f,3cd3649d4d82b16c6d105090d8081f6e,4014059e72ca2fb658649cccba153f5e,43cb0f2a8f89f287a9fa0308ed110a3f,4a45316e71cd0e0104c26095efef1a8b,51ed05a44ffcb6ce215b22d1c327ef23,51eee122c2ebcb8b0ffd820ac78cdc7b,5c2f2ed6b167d0c17fcd87e51d62ab85,5f022b2409af8223bf100e9564e5f586,5fe78f79b74aaf92a89687fd492be682,62bc2728250038f93d0bc65c57c2385b,65495eb1bdee1fa1abc9d070c27380fa,67553bf934dfe54e134414e61479f4a5,68e4ed89f41a580e3c58f0f98434cc33,6a43992b9c939ecec99364c660c1ac68,6b7d21eb26a4ec94c42acbaaf3707f2e,6bb6801ed3016e00efcce4b92ed4763d,6bf1c34951771fcd9f2560d72d1dec62,70ffa305d793f894aff7641666c1ab03,73e9dd59e90139f5e98a1ec5152660fd,7457059c696ee5838f2b9889b1412e1f,7496af92a71655ac8c47de41bf43bb65,74b1bd908c22c236bcd8a776ad40cc37,80e2f294b065a7a45175fb7408358c76,83073afaa1def102babae9700cd63bba,8493f884b789159d96b7dab3a7202396,8510ea40cef51fcde12bd266cbc4b6b2,882b4c6f36a621d123f340e538aff0c0,8c7cf0e88b403959479bde7eb44c8654,93d35d9e3f3e82ed3b519b494edfd9b9,9521960b1adb4fffde0f8bca2df87bcb,9e53460bbd021fbbc0a4bc6a17b4286d,9f69cc7e34d605a68963e8a8a83e003f,a15ef9eda68738122db496f9962d6a9f,ad49a894ef8b75f1e79de5a63ec78b85,b1b64ef207d42a2b81118c978ce1f222,b3aa1ac66a5e25e270fce196c19d325e,b4cf9c163a2ba0d0db3385c6741457ac,b5e3ea78bd8f6699e982039ddaf0e2f6,b6c3e0690d7a726e219124a91c516e65,b8fd807f07f8a2af89aa236339a7bc45,b90af97596777a0400f9c331a5d96a40,bab940f0cf76af894b6edb440a57b5f8,c0ae1b35d101dd5c80796ebcaaa52998,c2792fdb292ab4fe367f71a4089bf78c,c57482161043b2c5d5a644c558fb2fa6,cb8b8a24ee435442f42e5aa0feacb291,cc801e9b36ee6b6cbcb589ad5d6eb592,dcb36e1f25d08b0eeffb649bc3a7860f,e3f78e84ba947ada447e7a0b46389605,ee04ae10c40b706b74a05b7fffa01876,fb8a4e3d89439bd18b6f6ecae81d6d7c,fc20acf548ac287cb2de74e6e1ea4d6e,ff33e904e4d9308ef4fac68e0de16f71</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">27</data>\n      <data key="d4">5</data>\n      <data key="d5">19a7f254a5d64566ab5cc15472df02de</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;RUSSIAN MILITARY THOUGHT&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">**RUSSIAN MILITARY THOUGHT** refers to the evolving ideas and strategies within Russia\'s military doctrine.  It encompasses both military and nonmilitary strategies, and is described as distinct from Western approaches, shaped by Soviet influences. Russian military thought emphasizes kinetic activity in competition, meaning it prioritizes direct military action over other forms of engagement. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">452741c3c9d866e070dc0fcef9650ce1,4ecd2e58c6e1a2b279d5f93a8f00f091,6a43992b9c939ecec99364c660c1ac68,6b408afcf04121f1365ead7989dc8265,83073afaa1def102babae9700cd63bba,8c989fc0d3fc136d27a9f97d0fe40c82,ef9b79c1a74e5e82e587612a6b3f3ada</data>\n      <data key="d6">2</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">8</data>\n      <data key="d4">6</data>\n      <data key="d5">e7ffaee9d31d4d3c96e04f911d0a8f9e</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;WESTERN EQUIVALENT&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"The text contrasts Russian military thought with its Western counterpart."</data>\n      <data key="d2">6a43992b9c939ecec99364c660c1ac68</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">7</data>\n      <data key="d5">f7e11b0e297a44a896dc67928368f600</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;VLADIMIROV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">VLADIMIROV is an author and expert on modern warfare.  He emphasizes the importance of consciousness and ideas in contemporary conflicts. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">636188fef27c7af85e7dda3cc59e512f,b885945824139b7bec06a1a78158b190,fdc2c2b29672f18ffe9ae9fb2f1da756</data>\n      <data key="d6">15</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">3</data>\n      <data key="d4">8</data>\n      <data key="d5">1fd3fa8bb5a2408790042ab9573779ee</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MESSNER&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">MESSNER is a military theorist and author whose ideas have significantly influenced Russian military thought. He specialized in propaganda during his time as a former military officer and developed the concept of "subversion-war" based on Trotsky\'s theories. MESSNER argues that modern warfare increasingly focuses on psychological dimensions, a concept he termed "myatezhvoina," which he differentiates from traditional guerrilla warfare and insurgencies. \n\nHis writings explore the blurring lines between war and peace in the context of "subversion-war" and provide insights into the nature of revolutions. MESSNER\'s theories have been influential in shaping perspectives on modern war, particularly within schools of thought like "wars of consciousness." His work is also cited by thinkers like Vladimirov, who draws upon MESSNER\'s ideas regarding the manipulation of mass consciousness.  MESSNER emphasizes the growing importance of psychological warfare and observes the changing nature of war, highlighting its increasingly psychological dimensions. He has even proposed ideas about state disintegration. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0fe8cfd6fb9698ac419d99a30f7c00d6,276f8550d758346b203160a32cd885b6,3090c7597ab8b380afd48c1498709019,39b41cfcdca61ad353853416d904417f,4731d7c63be856e43075fe3d3c707e95,5efb9f04dcb379bafb98f7295b6ee16c,636188fef27c7af85e7dda3cc59e512f,6750bb4a2ab8af556c6cade73a275a95,69ab3a134854d40cbd893d37335cd7a2,6f3507b03c5fb34990029b28366363fe,83b0087e03908565fbbc54e5d4e331b1,9b9ff0b9cc19b0ace380f06dff0ce7bd,be99ed0e0a0f22dc215ec3d77e26d299,c95f509936d591070b3df6db009432bc,d0b738b8d19afd8178c28b7e67d984cd,dc1e9a19fbd380396d94e6e7c3bc5a52,ed5d6fd72ab9c8ddfc773830620174ab,faeec4fac390184ebb4bfcfdefc13e11,fdc2c2b29672f18ffe9ae9fb2f1da756</data>\n      <data key="d6">15</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">8</data>\n      <data key="d4">9</data>\n      <data key="d5">27f9fbe6ad8c4a8b9acee0d3596ed57c</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;LEONID MALTSEV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Leonid Maltsev, the Belarusian Minister of Defense, argues that modern warfare has evolved beyond traditional forms. He is a speaker on nonclassical forms of warfare and presented on this topic at a recent event. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">636188fef27c7af85e7dda3cc59e512f,7ad7b26d5e91bbe2e2df1b6e7a30b199,f1ea10917ad6f50fda3a92586fe998dc</data>\n      <data key="d3">2</data>\n      <data key="d4">10</data>\n      <data key="d5">e1fd0e904a53409aada44442f23a51cb</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;PAVEL BRUNTALSKY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Pavel Bruntalsky is an author and frequent contributor to VPK. He is known for summarizing Leonid Maltsev\'s arguments in his articles. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">636188fef27c7af85e7dda3cc59e512f,7ad7b26d5e91bbe2e2df1b6e7a30b199,f1ea10917ad6f50fda3a92586fe998dc</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">11</data>\n      <data key="d5">de988724cfdf45cebfba3b13c43ceede</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;VPK&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">VPK is a publication that focuses on military and strategic affairs. It features articles on various military and strategic topics, providing a platform for discussions and analysis within these fields. Notably, VPK has published works by prominent figures such as Gareyev, who explored the evolving nature of warfare, and Pavel Bruntalsky, who wrote about Leonid Maltsev\'s arguments on military strategy. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">3335c606e0de431e14afc7e61f86dfa8,636188fef27c7af85e7dda3cc59e512f,7ad7b26d5e91bbe2e2df1b6e7a30b199,f1ea10917ad6f50fda3a92586fe998dc</data>\n      <data key="d3">2</data>\n      <data key="d4">12</data>\n      <data key="d5">96aad7cb4b7d40e9b7e13b94a67af206</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MODERN WARFARE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">"Modern Warfare" is described as a qualitatively new phenomenon. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">636188fef27c7af85e7dda3cc59e512f,cb9c7871784fe7e0541e9f25929b9435</data>\n      <data key="d6">15</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">13</data>\n      <data key="d5">c9632a35146940c2a86167c7726d35e9</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;BELARUSIAN MINISTER&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"The Belarusian minister is the speaker who sees \'bloodless clashes\' as efficient and impressive."</data>\n      <data key="d2">7ad7b26d5e91bbe2e2df1b6e7a30b199</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">14</data>\n      <data key="d5">9646481f66ce4fd2b08c2eddda42fc82</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;BRUNTALSKY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Bruntalsky is an author who believes that modern warfare has transformed and no longer solely relies on armed violence. This perspective aligns with Maltsev\'s view on the nature of war in contemporary times.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">a5ccc3b4de720472fb0ba6dbc764cdba,c2792fdb292ab4fe367f71a4089bf78c</data>\n      <data key="d6">3</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">2</data>\n      <data key="d4">15</data>\n      <data key="d5">d91a266f766b4737a06b0fda588ba40b</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MALTSEV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">MALTSEV is an author whose perspectives on the evolving nature of war align with those of Bruntalsky.  Both Maltsev and Bruntalsky offer insights into how warfare is transforming. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">a5ccc3b4de720472fb0ba6dbc764cdba,c2792fdb292ab4fe367f71a4089bf78c</data>\n      <data key="d6">3</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">2</data>\n      <data key="d4">16</data>\n      <data key="d5">bc0e3f075a4c4ebbb7c7b152b65a5625</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SERGEI BREZKUN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Sergei Brezkun is a professor at the Academy of Military Science who disagrees with Bruntalsky and Maltsev\'s perspective on modern warfare."</data>\n      <data key="d2">c2792fdb292ab4fe367f71a4089bf78c</data>\n      <data key="d6">3</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">2</data>\n      <data key="d4">17</data>\n      <data key="d5">254770028d7a4fa9877da4ba0ad5ad21</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;ACADEMY OF MILITARY SCIENCE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **Academy of Military Science** is a Russian military institution responsible for institutionalizing strategic thought in the officer corps.  It collaborates with the General Staff by contributing to the military journal *Voyennaya Mysl* and disseminating military-theoretical works. Notable individuals associated with the Academy include Vladimir Slipchenko, Sergei Brezkun, and Vladimir Mikryukov. In 2013, Chief of the General Staff Valery Gerasimov delivered a speech at the Academy about the changing nature of war.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">068fed974175a4460923174d7ce00bbf,071a706dfd6647edd4993031ec85beb9,2629bcda8b7f4f253acfd0d116bd739d,36344580abcc867bedcaf20027655b68,389e48907c50cbd0638418cda16b9938,5b098687cb656d98c6bb419d0ec6fd75,5bc1d54f3233915280db63e273e03592,5cd9f4f78cb2dfdfcb512cc36ac0202f,8501d99fb9d704c9315278702413ee9e,c2792fdb292ab4fe367f71a4089bf78c,da02795f9d537326bfadcd006a8bcc92,e0053ef676c35b3b5e2e0225190d6463</data>\n      <data key="d6">3</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">4</data>\n      <data key="d4">18</data>\n      <data key="d5">4a67211867e5464ba45126315a122a8a</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;WARFARE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">Warfare is a term sometimes used interchangeably with "struggle" by Russian experts.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">4ecd2e58c6e1a2b279d5f93a8f00f091,c2792fdb292ab4fe367f71a4089bf78c</data>\n      <data key="d6">3</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">3</data>\n      <data key="d4">19</data>\n      <data key="d5">04dbbb2283b845baaeac0eaf0c34c9da</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;BRUNTALSKY &amp; MALTSEV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1" />\n      <data key="d2">c2792fdb292ab4fe367f71a4089bf78c</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">20</data>\n      <data key="d5">1943f245ee4243bdbfbd2fd619ae824a</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;AGGRESSOR&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"**AGGRESSOR**" refers to the party that initiates a conflict, potentially violating international law.  This entity, which can be a country or other organization, engages in hostile actions such as manipulating international relationships and launching attacks. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">98af93d8eaa2b05d821947ec140a3584,b5e3ea78bd8f6699e982039ddaf0e2f6</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">21</data>\n      <data key="d5">273daeec8cad41e6b3e450447db58ee7</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;BREZKUN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Brezkun is an author and expert who specializes in hybrid warfare.  He published work on the subject in 2007 and argues that the Soviet Union could be a result of a nonclassical war. Brezkun emphasizes the importance of classical military means in countering aggression, presenting the argument about the Soviet Union\'s origins as a case study. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">b5e3ea78bd8f6699e982039ddaf0e2f6,f9cd1d8b7cbb13deeabb75de223a5c6c,fc20acf548ac287cb2de74e6e1ea4d6e</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">22</data>\n      <data key="d5">e69dc259edb944ea9ea41264b9fcfe59</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;GERASIMOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Valery Gerasimov is a high-ranking officer in the Russian Armed Forces and the Chief of the General Staff. He is a prominent figure in Russian military theory, known for his concept of the "adaptive approach to warfare" and emphasizing non-military means.  Gerasimov argues that the nature of war has changed, with non-military means becoming as important as traditional military force. He believes the lines between war and peace are blurring due to the effectiveness of these non-military tactics, such as "color revolutions," which he views as a new form of warfare instigated by the West. \n\nGerasimov\'s writings and speeches have significantly influenced the understanding of modern warfare, particularly his concept of "hybrid warfare" which combines both military and non-military means. He is considered a key figure in expressing Russia\'s stance on information warfare and advocates for changes in the laws of war to reflect this evolving landscape. His ideas have been referenced by other prominent figures like Andrew Korybko and Bartles, solidifying his influence within military theory circles. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0020352f5979749f81254faea53ba1dd,0130a2e44046b07aa1a2eac85562f8aa,0ac95daa24b8448799785bd3afba6112,0b053af0a82e321c5ad32e0e5014114d,0f6caa8f2e4b146cbd71b583add938f8,17ec79bdb3de589c18eab04fab860d2c,22b661e49114bda37400701e79292197,26bcdb76c6596b963d2e36a4147ef816,273d16ede7c2ef0b280a8c35ddd2ad71,29af440463776490596d1cedcfe1b068,2a095cc3e0a26865ad75d88bf966ff8e,2d96d25d0022a1193382ea88b904435a,2d9ebc26c09a31bc04991b6efe8272bf,330a15c48db3e65aec3147e6dd5632c9,358c867d3a7c5e13a54f3d519fad1603,35fa4f03c6bbb412d22ff5f494e83329,36344580abcc867bedcaf20027655b68,38bf7298856b8fd4341bb0998b803ee0,3a60589a99ac9cde8a25daf1571620f6,4988f2a5f074560f53ed5ddfe5e100b2,4a396711762b9d23dfa301a027d2737e,4f7f4f6fe9d288255da50532faa25f53,5001e715f5ba5243fcabb020b7615069,54e5f6035998ada7e8e6f4188995aec5,5bb2f411436cd9fd01cf7697e33fec75,5c79cd610c718db1aa2cf27f837d00c8,68355cf380d714ea713e77efbe44d3ac,6e050b4fa47547d59d934e304f199d4a,6e49482d37bfe8a11381f5fd9b2bf9ab,7762d8e435ee0e72467ae2468b71323e,7cc72471bf4edd02ae4d6b43dd505467,803cf3c02920d14a7bb0447fc1c76140,81610c5774616913fcb1d17e45b9c19b,83d8321db4baeb9dd56aa1e91eb29a39,84b65c4d676043766aeebfc93b776ae6,8501d99fb9d704c9315278702413ee9e,850631a820a8158d8c7bff68e8f7fea5,94a2bf999aec8597aae3db5d3633891d,988cfd2c3c636c6bc23a2455381cfe57,a1d5b70180c35b1c12fa0a5a6e0f0a8a,a3a7513f41e4fd6cb9e4f0decdbc615d,a8ab56e6e419d570a195fd2ea167899d,aa5d990b03c9214c4c3a37412d5cf0d1,ac08e98f560a5dcdd378a622eca69f06,b04e155024b2e24838d7dba80a934c81,b11c3e5c041763bf480a5b17676c7ef3,bd400dbd8e753ab71c9394fe8b1f07ce,c06a4e03818e9f2586a6cd014a2408b7,d494718117eae6e351eff5873eca32c0,d8383d735e3d4dedd141bc4b08e3eeaa,db7fc162ad9590d171cb7d6fc1ef0fc2,dd68126420b24cd563d457fdb5356a33,ddd0a3f72f4191a04998e4fe73f788b7,e0927b91be8f756165d5fca82ca84107,e422579fa9c3017302c510d218e0fc09,f6e01d03f8c01910c2d8de5e8dd3a40f,fa6f1322c861f018219ae4741df2bae1</data>\n      <data key="d6">3</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">27</data>\n      <data key="d4">23</data>\n      <data key="d5">e2f5735c7d714423a2c4f61ca2644626</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;ARAB SPRING&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"EVENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **Arab Spring** refers to a series of pro-democracy uprisings and protests that occurred across the Middle East and North Africa in 2010-2011. These events, initially perceived as successful "color revolutions," involved both peaceful protests and instances of violence. The Arab Spring significantly influenced Russia\'s initial reaction towards the West, prompting concern and suspicion from Russian officials who viewed it as a potential threat.  \n\nThe Arab Spring is cited as a catalyst for renewed concerns about color revolutions within Russia, influencing their perceptions of such movements and contributing to the 2011-12 Russian elections and the Euromaidan revolt. It is also mentioned as a potential example of a new type of warfare in the 21st century, characterized by nonmilitary means and disruptive technologies used by the West.  \n\nFurthermore, the Arab Spring is presented as a significant historical event used to illustrate the nature of 21st-century warfare, highlighting the impact of information warfare and regime change on global power dynamics. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">127b37863425efc735533b75512a27a3,158ce52b95681a52d3cd554e67e50c0b,1b2ff8a47843f9eaa296b8dbc90d9179,2528b45270d95680a57bc9094766201c,273d16ede7c2ef0b280a8c35ddd2ad71,2ed01d91a2d5804af478b65fbd4fff17,330a15c48db3e65aec3147e6dd5632c9,3567049070ba54eb1c8cfbc3d5aef2b3,3972337bda3ba01f49da971ec696ce50,46a8120d658a422a13cbf4af4bac874c,47cbbe56d55fbd552f238ecfef64e24b,4988f2a5f074560f53ed5ddfe5e100b2,4ff9923cce9727a0cb4b60f7ec70b2cc,68d539054aaa9dcc75ed59e59850468c,79642481b2ae6a1e1e62350b8f9872b5,841ac43154acf1df4c5e3af00e7d0360,8501d99fb9d704c9315278702413ee9e,882b4c6f36a621d123f340e538aff0c0,8c989fc0d3fc136d27a9f97d0fe40c82,a7f0f3bd43f5142bb1728f4adacde5b0,a8ab56e6e419d570a195fd2ea167899d,b04e155024b2e24838d7dba80a934c81,b27bfe84ab787e179b1320553dc4146a,ba4314d7dde31a9a3de140b03d964db0,be14354d183b860e7bd2a06d1c731a17,c06a4e03818e9f2586a6cd014a2408b7,d0c05f8ec94cd42a4727a66ae84be4dd,e216e7f3ed5bf3208c1f51eaa41603b8,f04349eccb7697c6652f0d01b6622514,f35ced22e0b916ab11822dd7acc16502,f377212178ff5952443726ce112faac6,f5693f51d4c418b01643d1524837e46b,fcf6292acd4060dcb8b6f555eeebabe3,ff779b872510c138da68523b69265b0e</data>\n      <data key="d6">6</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">11</data>\n      <data key="d4">24</data>\n      <data key="d5">deece7e64b2a4628850d4bb6e394a9c3</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;UKRAINE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"GEO"</data>\n      <data key="d1">## Ukraine: A Country at the Center of Conflict and Geopolitical Tensions\n\nUkraine is a country located in Eastern Europe that has become a focal point for international conflict and geopolitical tensions.  Since 2014, Ukraine has experienced significant unrest and political instability, culminating in a war initiated by Russia. This conflict has been widely described as an example of "hybrid warfare," which capitalizes on indirect action, informational campaigns, and the use of non-state actors like NGOs and private military companies.\n\nThe events in Ukraine have been interpreted differently by various parties. While some view the Ukrainian situation as a "color revolution" instigated by external forces, others see it as a legitimate struggle for self-determination against Russian aggression.  Russia has accused Ukraine of receiving support from the US and EU, further escalating tensions. \n\nThe conflict in Ukraine has had a profound impact on global discourse. It has brought attention to the work of military theorists like Chekinov and Bogdanov, who have analyzed the evolving nature of warfare. Additionally, Ukraine serves as a testing ground for Russia\'s military capabilities and a site where its military theories are being applied. \n\nThe ongoing conflict in Ukraine highlights the country\'s geopolitical significance and its role as a flashpoint between Russia and the West.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">00a8e6977b8cc35ff2706d718367759f,02a6df0665914ec51da4921e5dd94d40,09d7c6af55f6f4b82f041f3f22e4670b,16a295a1b82cfcc452e208d5c3376783,181231ad89fa361ed50977f8c31ba68e,2cb1e7782df146c829e143995efaa5ea,30032f8bc461471f2472db1803deb493,358c867d3a7c5e13a54f3d519fad1603,36f660fdb6caa5548aa91058f2a84b25,3858893d4e6c348056e49fd3ae011704,398eeca696092e2043e85b335804a06b,3e06cb0ad46a2e027bad24715e248b03,4124151e2fc00b9b0fa6084138b8a7ef,536b48540ca934fd046a103198ab417e,5e6fb3a3adc710bacf237b23b8de5cdb,61ac280201ff550c532fdc0a622b220c,66363736a89b60d4a0809ceb037cbec1,6868f009e28c0d98518a108a15141a47,68d539054aaa9dcc75ed59e59850468c,78e0d14c1d381cdf093e4f7873c77b1c,79642481b2ae6a1e1e62350b8f9872b5,806203f9ac3bb5daf5713237ac7d114e,841ac43154acf1df4c5e3af00e7d0360,882b4c6f36a621d123f340e538aff0c0,8ff158575b84b0887eb77b85bf41802d,931a3799d962bbcfc294a670caa94cdc,94a2bf999aec8597aae3db5d3633891d,9a094936a37bf4a3f685de90bc51b680,a43f5e6fd71202a7ed7c45243f550e1e,ac08e98f560a5dcdd378a622eca69f06,ad3a9a7eec5a9d65028ce8f7f95ab827,b04e155024b2e24838d7dba80a934c81,b11c3e5c041763bf480a5b17676c7ef3,b27bfe84ab787e179b1320553dc4146a,b97617707d0f13c32b85f07ae1407b77,c06a4e03818e9f2586a6cd014a2408b7,c2736d15fad21b52584eeabefdf7f2da,d7db417821a9ecdbb04ad34de78b0244,e0927b91be8f756165d5fca82ca84107,e0bc114dfaebe00d71bbcf19b4d41f1d,e8b2ce2c1fd2c098e0876122cefde0bb,e9def1a80602f476ecce04216e4a8a03,ed5d6fd72ab9c8ddfc773830620174ab,ee01bd14651295a2b77fcb67ebdc098b,f131e67e4b2ea2d98c5968dd6c57cda5,fa1f745b441f0a8da9c96e5184733ab7</data>\n      <data key="d6">6</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">12</data>\n      <data key="d4">25</data>\n      <data key="d5">e657b5121ff8456b9a610cfaead8e0cb</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;LIBYA&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"GEO"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Libya is a country in North Africa that has been cited as an example of a "color revolution" escalating into large-scale military action.  \n\nThe country experienced internal instability provoked through subversive actions and "controlled chaos," which was further destabilized by the use of "soft power" against the government. Information warfare, specifically targeting Libya, was used to promote civil war. This ultimately led to a Western military intervention following the color revolution, events that were significant for Russia. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">127b37863425efc735533b75512a27a3,16a295a1b82cfcc452e208d5c3376783,330a15c48db3e65aec3147e6dd5632c9,4a4127fa2d140cfe4bba76e93169d035,4ff9923cce9727a0cb4b60f7ec70b2cc,84b65c4d676043766aeebfc93b776ae6,84fbeb27b48ec1426740369d4f5b851e,9a094936a37bf4a3f685de90bc51b680,c06a4e03818e9f2586a6cd014a2408b7,e0927b91be8f756165d5fca82ca84107</data>\n      <data key="d6">8</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">3</data>\n      <data key="d4">26</data>\n      <data key="d5">bf4e255cdac94ccc83a56435a5e4b075</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SYRIA&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"GEO"</data>\n      <data key="d1">## Syria: A Geopolitical Flashpoint\n\nSyria is a country that has become a significant geopolitical flashpoint, drawing international attention and involvement.  It is frequently mentioned as an example of a "color revolution" &#8211; a popular uprising often fueled by external actors &#8211; which escalated into large-scale military conflict. This conflict has seen the involvement of both Russian and Western forces, generating considerable tension between the two sides. \n\nRussia\'s military intervention in Syria, first initiated in 2015, has been cited as an example of "cross-domain coercion" and a new type of warfare outlined by General Valery Gerasimov.  Gerasimov\'s speech highlights the use of various tools beyond traditional military force, including NGOs, private military companies, and information warfare, to achieve strategic objectives. \n\nSyria has also been described as a location where "soft power" was allegedly used to influence events, and where "controlled chaos" tactics were employed. The country\'s ongoing instability and the presence of armed groups have created a volatile environment marked by threats and challenges for both regional and international actors.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">00a8e6977b8cc35ff2706d718367759f,127b37863425efc735533b75512a27a3,2ed01d91a2d5804af478b65fbd4fff17,330a15c48db3e65aec3147e6dd5632c9,358c867d3a7c5e13a54f3d519fad1603,3fe4dd62a032b1a281c925fbec9cbc6a,4a4127fa2d140cfe4bba76e93169d035,61ac280201ff550c532fdc0a622b220c,68355cf380d714ea713e77efbe44d3ac,841ac43154acf1df4c5e3af00e7d0360,84b65c4d676043766aeebfc93b776ae6,84fbeb27b48ec1426740369d4f5b851e,94a2bf999aec8597aae3db5d3633891d,9a094936a37bf4a3f685de90bc51b680,acb49396b9072d77515a295d612faf84,b04e155024b2e24838d7dba80a934c81,b27bfe84ab787e179b1320553dc4146a,ba6cc1cd4e196ad5c9a6ed672f497d19,c06a4e03818e9f2586a6cd014a2408b7,d7db417821a9ecdbb04ad34de78b0244,f131e67e4b2ea2d98c5968dd6c57cda5</data>\n      <data key="d6">3</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">7</data>\n      <data key="d4">27</data>\n      <data key="d5">3b040bcc19f14e04880ae52881a89c1c</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;ZARUDNITSKY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Zarudnitsky is the Chief of the Main Operational Directorate of the General Staff. He is an expert who analyzes "color revolutions" and their impact on warfare, believing they represent a significant change in world politics. Zarudnitsky compares these revolutions to military aggression in his analyses. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">053fc6b7d54ff33c0865e0ad0ff30b52,5aee82bdd503dba2501bafd6ec8b2ccd,9a094936a37bf4a3f685de90bc51b680,c06a4e03818e9f2586a6cd014a2408b7,eaaa469362a385cbba23c49fc926a216</data>\n      <data key="d6">6</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">28</data>\n      <data key="d5">3d6b216c14354332b1bf1927ba168986</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;COLOR REVOLUTIONS&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">"Color Revolutions" are a series of political upheavals perceived by Russia as engineered by Western states. These events involve popular uprisings, often fueled by ideological and social movements, that aim to overthrow governments through nonviolent protests and information campaigns. \n\nThe term "Color Revolutions" was first used to describe the events in Georgia (Rose Revolution), Ukraine (Orange Revolution), and Kyrgyzstan (Tulip Revolution) between 2003 and 2005.  They are characterized as a "soft coup," a method for regime change involving political, economic, and humanitarian pressure, often with external support from Western powers.\n\nColor Revolutions are seen as a significant threat by Russian leadership, who view them as a form of Western aggression aimed at destabilizing their influence and undermining traditional military power.  They are described as a major shift in global security threats, involving political-diplomatic, economic, and information influence, and are considered a tool used within hybrid warfare strategies. \n\nThe concept of Color Revolutions has gained prominence on the Russian agenda since the early 2000s, becoming mainstream among military theorists by the mid-2010s.  They are understood as a nonmilitary form of action that significantly impacts the Russian understanding of war and poses a perceived threat to their national interests.\n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">053fc6b7d54ff33c0865e0ad0ff30b52,0ac95daa24b8448799785bd3afba6112,0f6caa8f2e4b146cbd71b583add938f8,127b37863425efc735533b75512a27a3,17ec79bdb3de589c18eab04fab860d2c,181231ad89fa361ed50977f8c31ba68e,19d9f093df260f1df1d036a42926a00d,1b2ff8a47843f9eaa296b8dbc90d9179,1c170b6b1c8851bba14e24b8af15b481,22b661e49114bda37400701e79292197,273d16ede7c2ef0b280a8c35ddd2ad71,29af440463776490596d1cedcfe1b068,2cb1e7782df146c829e143995efaa5ea,34b0078e74299e6a200a4ef43f0bdc9c,3567049070ba54eb1c8cfbc3d5aef2b3,3747b8d7981bef88cd93023a9282583b,3a60589a99ac9cde8a25daf1571620f6,3d9254865502f679af6fa7a0b77a6cbe,4a396711762b9d23dfa301a027d2737e,4b3b407bbe1ac2b90a3980545cb66a39,4f7f4f6fe9d288255da50532faa25f53,54e5f6035998ada7e8e6f4188995aec5,5aee82bdd503dba2501bafd6ec8b2ccd,5bb2f411436cd9fd01cf7697e33fec75,5eebe2681ef1e72ddfec4046d181b179,641dba1d5b7b52f8b0e286f427afecc3,677c7a0f4f60503badb0a4d899c21d74,68355cf380d714ea713e77efbe44d3ac,6b82eafaf18f777bfa19dd36a0a5c327,6d223c86a361242683a4bd296d60b502,752e31eca4dc5d94da820c3cb84cf6e9,7762d8e435ee0e72467ae2468b71323e,7e6f4059311f39a717a9ef7d076868ad,806203f9ac3bb5daf5713237ac7d114e,8196d4fb9caac5c7ffd87f465eac8c12,8beec46e554e40907188a8b4eadfb7f8,8cbc35e22aa8edad712072d4efe491f1,903acba04eef215a12972c10ee95560b,972ad08450d40acba47394c99e434c56,98d0fa6298be2a61d9cff2a2acb23924,9a094936a37bf4a3f685de90bc51b680,9a2dcbe9b0d27f8917dd3fe660260425,9c59a1134d84949c9c4c2d4510c2fbfb,9d078dbf3cd9f132d9d452509bd774f1,a1c7cc7a633d4eb0010929797ae264c5,a1d5b70180c35b1c12fa0a5a6e0f0a8a,a65201d3ece3a85bc85fabedd884b7e7,a66026abef50d4b6b00ca0f933f6be0f,ad3a9a7eec5a9d65028ce8f7f95ab827,bb79f01fab18fe7d28c221337b6e09c0,c06a4e03818e9f2586a6cd014a2408b7,c57482161043b2c5d5a644c558fb2fa6,c6f139f4eaa3828baab624dad7b83c88,cb50fafd31d07b9e8f9e52f658937913,d0c05f8ec94cd42a4727a66ae84be4dd,d42e19095522f9d2df7dc1499cedc5ca,eaaa469362a385cbba23c49fc926a216,ef9b79c1a74e5e82e587612a6b3f3ada,f35ced22e0b916ab11822dd7acc16502,f9b181b3ff2171e547897575c5e4d562,fcf6292acd4060dcb8b6f555eeebabe3</data>\n      <data key="d6">6</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">22</data>\n      <data key="d4">29</data>\n      <data key="d5">1c109cfdc370463eb6d537e5b7b382fb</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;THE WEST&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The West, a geopolitical entity often referring to a collective of countries primarily including the United States and European Union states, though sometimes solely meaning the United States, is a key actor in international relations.  It is portrayed as viewing color revolutions as a nonviolent tool for regime change and responds to actions taken by Moscow, potentially contributing to miscommunication in the process. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">3567049070ba54eb1c8cfbc3d5aef2b3,5aee82bdd503dba2501bafd6ec8b2ccd,f131e67e4b2ea2d98c5968dd6c57cda5</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">30</data>\n      <data key="d5">3d0dcbc8971b415ea18065edc4d8c8ef</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;WESTERN MILITARY THOUGHT&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Western Military Thought refers to the ideas and strategies employed by Western militaries.  This school of thought places a strong emphasis on kinetic activity during periods of competition. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">4ecd2e58c6e1a2b279d5f93a8f00f091,6b408afcf04121f1365ead7989dc8265</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">31</data>\n      <data key="d5">68105770b523412388424d984e711917</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;STRUGGLE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"STRUGGLE" refers to a broad range of strategic interactions that encompass various domains such as information, diplomacy, and economics.  As understood by Russian experts, "STRUGGLE" holds a broader meaning than just wartime conflict and relates to comprehensive competition across multiple spheres. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">245c8a66b7fbfb155c4ea1253d66dad9,4ecd2e58c6e1a2b279d5f93a8f00f091</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">32</data>\n      <data key="d5">85c79fd84f5e4f918471c386852204c5</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;CROSS-DOMAIN COERCION&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">**CROSS-DOMAIN COERCION** is a military strategy employed by Russia that integrates conventional, cyber, and nuclear capabilities to achieve its strategic objectives.  \n\nIt involves exerting pressure on adversaries across multiple domains, encompassing both deterrence and compulsion tactics. This approach, described as the most recent evolution in Russian strategy, aims to influence and deter opponents through a combination of informational warfare, conventional military force, and nuclear threats. While initially a Western concept, "cross-domain coercion" aligns with Russian notions of "struggle" and "strategic deterrence."  It is presented as an alternative term to strategic deterrence, emphasizing its focus on non-nuclear aspects. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0f11f27d252b4419076b47cf4dfcb20d,23a741082731d52f254cf6d6f54eb58c,39936b87b632c096c061641c0490c2af,4ecd2e58c6e1a2b279d5f93a8f00f091,59f9360f2decd637139d6b869529c2ad,6fe4faca1e39cc57f7c84b772a87fd4d,7513c4dbf8819739ed9f826ecda085dc,76815ae7d94d779bb7060d241c9903fc,7ae0f631f330850ca53d02c933c953ce,85f4f3b5379c5738a70e9fb5bc359ae0,8651bdb6a227bf3bca82a80a06ed712a,cf70ea3dd32b83dd2249d0d0987956a7,d872d9d72fd45f9dfaac95c56c2b8b39,d9cfb6f6d55260607c7b88c1f675e224,eaf0d08dbd97c1a7311aa7c886044509</data>\n      <data key="d6">10</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">7</data>\n      <data key="d4">33</data>\n      <data key="d5">eae4259b19a741ab9f9f6af18c4a0470</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;COMPETITIVE STRATEGY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Competitive strategy envisions long-term competition in both peace and war."</data>\n      <data key="d2">4ecd2e58c6e1a2b279d5f93a8f00f091</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">34</data>\n      <data key="d5">3138f39f2bcd43a69e0697cd3b05bc4d</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;RUSSIAN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">**RUSSIAN** refers to the geopolitical entity of Russia, a nation often described as an "adversary" employing strategic influence tools.  The term also encompasses a distinct cultural sphere and military thought analyzed in the text. Discussions within the text include Russian military strategies and tactics, further solidifying the context of "Russian" as referring to the nation of Russia and its associated aspects. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">46560acff919ef6253fd1d861d00ae9c,7513c4dbf8819739ed9f826ecda085dc,8af314428c563e0a26a74d9083e89198,d760565312fa739ff154c8ebd38fe95d,d872d9d72fd45f9dfaac95c56c2b8b39,ddb28f923ecb6b1e19f7dff7c9b34211,f1a146e421e297be23156a46a12345c5</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">35</data>\n      <data key="d5">dde131ab575d44dbb55289a6972be18f</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;ADMINISTRATIVE ORGANS DEPARTMENT&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **Administrative Organs Department** was responsible for controlling all appointments of military and security personnel. This role highlighted its importance in ensuring party influence over the military apparatus.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">6388873944a12dfd98e41c61c757f3d8,6ea7bd4508f84402392b3119dfa1aa6d,ee2a956c830712b74c912b175f90afdd</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">36</data>\n      <data key="d5">de9e343f2e334d88a8ac7f8813a915e5</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MILITARY-POLITICAL ADMINISTRATION&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **Military-Political Administration** wielded significant power by controlling military messages and dispensing party patronage. This influence extended to both internal affairs, shaping communication within the organization, and external audiences, disseminating information and favors to those outside its ranks.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">6388873944a12dfd98e41c61c757f3d8,6ea7bd4508f84402392b3119dfa1aa6d,ee2a956c830712b74c912b175f90afdd</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">37</data>\n      <data key="d5">e2bf260115514fb3b252fd879fb3e7be</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;KGB\'S THIRD CHIEF DIRECTORATE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"The KGB\'s Third Chief Directorate used informant networks to control the military covertly."</data>\n      <data key="d2">6ea7bd4508f84402392b3119dfa1aa6d</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">38</data>\n      <data key="d5">b462b94ce47a4b8c8fffa33f7242acec</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;KRASNAYA ZVEZDA&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"GEO"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Krasnaya Zvezda" is a weekly military newspaper controlled by the Military-Political Administration.  Its role as a journal indicates its influence in shaping military discourse. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">389e48907c50cbd0638418cda16b9938,6388873944a12dfd98e41c61c757f3d8,6ea7bd4508f84402392b3119dfa1aa6d</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">39</data>\n      <data key="d5">17ed1d92075643579a712cc6c29e8ddb</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;VOYENNAYA MYSL&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"GEO"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"**Voyennaya Mysl (Military Thought)**" is a military journal established in the late nineteenth century. Published by the General Staff, it serves as the primary platform for military-theoretical works and is controlled by the Military-Political Administration.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">389e48907c50cbd0638418cda16b9938,5b098687cb656d98c6bb419d0ec6fd75,5bc1d54f3233915280db63e273e03592,6ea7bd4508f84402392b3119dfa1aa6d</data>\n      <data key="d6">3</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">40</data>\n      <data key="d5">3ce7c210a21b4deebad7cc9308148d86</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SOKOLOVSKY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">SOKOLOVSKY is a Soviet military theorist who authored influential works such as "Voyennaya strategiya" and "Marksizm-leninizm o voine i armii," providing authoritative perspectives on war within the Soviet Union.  He emphasizes the principle of complete subordination of military strategy to policy, refuting claims that war had ceased to be an instrument of policy. While SOKOLOVSKY acknowledges that nuclear weapons represent a change in the character of war, he maintains that they do not fundamentally alter its nature, as opposed to those who argue for a complete shift in the definition of war.  SOKOLOVSKY holds a narrower view of war, defining it solely by armed violence. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">1b996f45c7b397759863385a53361eed,2cb92533547d702e1894fcea545257ee,313dc3be1190b1a10a2579c621091156,489aeca592784f5f7be0a754beb4f575,4d3bd4beec226501211dcd3560fd6fba,6ea7bd4508f84402392b3119dfa1aa6d,7be505fea57e0dbd921a3c195dd29aac,ee2a956c830712b74c912b175f90afdd</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">3</data>\n      <data key="d4">41</data>\n      <data key="d5">d64ed762ea924caa95c8d06f072a9a96</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;NIKOLSKY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Nikolsky is cited as an author who argued that war had ceased to be an instrument of policy."</data>\n      <data key="d2">2cb92533547d702e1894fcea545257ee</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">42</data>\n      <data key="d5">adf4ee3fbe9b4d0381044838c4f889c8</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;TALENSKY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Talensky is cited as an author who argued that war had ceased to be an instrument of policy."</data>\n      <data key="d2">2cb92533547d702e1894fcea545257ee</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">43</data>\n      <data key="d5">32ee140946e5461f9275db664dc541a5</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;GARTHOFF&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Garthoff is cited as an author who provided evidence for the claim that war had ceased to be an instrument of policy."</data>\n      <data
