key="d2">2cb92533547d702e1894fcea545257ee</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">44</data>\n      <data key="d5">c160b9cb27d6408ba6ab20214a2f3f81</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;VOYENNAYA STRATEGIYA (MILITARY STRATEGY)&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"EVENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"**VOYENNAYA STRATEGIYA (MILITARY STRATEGY)**" is a seminal work by **Vasily Sokolovsky**.  In this book, Sokolovsky refutes existing claims about the nature of war and defines it as armed violence employed between different groups to achieve political objectives. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">2cb92533547d702e1894fcea545257ee,b90af97596777a0400f9c331a5d96a40,e8d8461aeecbc6801361ca4fa5c3e2e2</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">45</data>\n      <data key="d5">23527cd679ff4d5a988d52e7cd056078</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;WAR&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">## War: A Multifaceted Concept\n\n**War**, transliterated as \'voina\' in this book, is a central concept explored throughout the text.  It is defined and analyzed from various perspectives, highlighting its complexity and multifaceted nature. \n\nWhile often understood as a conflict involving armed force, as defined by Kvachkov and Gareyev, war encompasses a broader range of activities beyond physical violence. Soviet scholars, as well as other sources, define war as "the continuation of politics by means of armed force," emphasizing its strategic and political dimensions.  \n\nThe text presents diverse interpretations of war. It is discussed both as an evil to be eradicated and as a necessary tool for achieving communist goals. Additionally, it is presented as an instrument of politics, strategically employed by the Soviets. \n\nAuthors like Malyshev delve into various forms of warfare, including economic, psychological, and information warfare, expanding the traditional understanding of armed conflict.  Gorbunov and Bogdanov argue that the nature of war is constantly evolving, while Kazarin focuses on defining and analyzing its core characteristics. Clausewitz\'s ideas on achieving victory are discussed within the context of war, further emphasizing its strategic significance. \n\n\nUltimately, "War" refers to armed conflict between nations or groups, but the text delves deeper into its complexities, exploring its political, social, economic, and ideological implications.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">08b5b9a81f792e1a63e929dc06a81d50,112509ae19803edd47655e5f2fc22ae1,1507b417cf61f29030428f95a1c2dc08,1a860ae7b783d3a1eb78fb862dd64138,1b996f45c7b397759863385a53361eed,266688aac47e8134554bad1ee6e6ccba,2836f2f0365794d9fae3abfa350f2311,2cb92533547d702e1894fcea545257ee,2ed01d91a2d5804af478b65fbd4fff17,30386c4e76d744b895d430847b713f0a,3060e5a3570413999878edce8065dc2b,313dc3be1190b1a10a2579c621091156,31d8ac7fc85d988e67da2c6480208aad,342381013c3f61db48a3a2b2bc77370c,37215a6c4810a7b385fb17417f94fbe0,39786aa4012dd6b57506633a91deaeca,3bd04ac8a624fe79e353bb14221b8554,3cd3649d4d82b16c6d105090d8081f6e,48e310bd8a37fd938fc512819430d5f7,4e2896fd5b6f31d006ca18e1a3299553,51eee122c2ebcb8b0ffd820ac78cdc7b,68355cf380d714ea713e77efbe44d3ac,7567750cec0624c2e9f362f989d8b1bc,7aef3b8e0c0a9cd9f240dfbe12e02c38,7be505fea57e0dbd921a3c195dd29aac,7e482cb10632a3cf72d58679114ee7f7,81610c5774616913fcb1d17e45b9c19b,84ac1ed20f03c3394c67671cb479f7db,8501d99fb9d704c9315278702413ee9e,96de73e76077a8dbde7d1d4e185a69bb,a5ccc3b4de720472fb0ba6dbc764cdba,b04e155024b2e24838d7dba80a934c81,b1b64ef207d42a2b81118c978ce1f222,b39e3b697d5d9ed3835d622486095c96,be99ed0e0a0f22dc215ec3d77e26d299,beabdeed11a36088777fbee158b3a3f5,bfa15fcd5d4a19aa65f946d1af780d5f,c0ae1b35d101dd5c80796ebcaaa52998,c4d611eafc5e900466e378a2742c03bf,c8c68899e22ee8c693d6e73e47d38c9e,ce0f551566143f746d8ff46f4a021065,cfae2a9660e62a12a25d2678a2931f34,d62c24f2a958cdd90af90b2fee315132,f6e8b902329dc6f6dbef5fc7fd397474</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">30</data>\n      <data key="d4">46</data>\n      <data key="d5">f1c6eed066f24cbdb376b910fce29ed4</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MARXISM-LENINISM&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Marxism-Leninism is a political and economic ideology that served as the foundational ideology for military strategy in the Soviet Union.  It shaped both tactical approaches and overall worldview, becoming the basis for all war and society science within the country. Lenin himself desired Marxism-Leninism to be the foundation for Soviet military science. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">2a4b75db8fdd23483fc6c4f097c7f56f,645ce27900f66a0b633be93f0e5d6399,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,e90da29be1148d9844e3ed777db08bf6,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967</data>\n      <data key="d6">12</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">2</data>\n      <data key="d4">47</data>\n      <data key="d5">83a6cb03df6b41d8ad6ee5f6fef5f024</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SOVIET IDEOLOGY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Soviet ideology encompassed the beliefs, principles, and values that guided the Soviet Union. It referred to the political, economic, and social beliefs that dominated the country.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">65a1bf9e5672afc1a7011ffa78b1c211,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967</data>\n      <data key="d6">1</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">3</data>\n      <data key="d4">48</data>\n      <data key="d5">147c038aef3e4422acbbc5f7938c4ab8</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;NATIONAL SECURITY CONCEPT OF THE RUSSIAN FEDERATION&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"DOCUMENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"**NATIONAL SECURITY CONCEPT OF THE RUSSIAN FEDERATION**" is a document that outlines Russia\'s security policy.  It details the nation\'s national security priorities and strategies. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">49</data>\n      <data key="d5">b7702b90c7f24190b864e8c6e64612a5</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MILITARY DOCTRINE OF THE RUSSIAN FEDERATION&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"DOCUMENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **Military Doctrine of the Russian Federation** is a document that outlines Russia\'s military strategy. It defines Russia\'s military objectives, principles, and methods of warfare.  This doctrine serves as a guide for the country\'s military strategy and aims to achieve its strategic goals through defined principles and approaches. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">ade36c9f71918172a6ce043f5b3b2dc8,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">50</data>\n      <data key="d5">de6fa24480894518ab3cbcb66f739266</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;FOREIGN POLICY CONCEPT OF THE RUSSIAN FEDERATION&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"DOCUMENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **FOREIGN POLICY CONCEPT OF THE RUSSIAN FEDERATION** outlines Russia\'s goals and approaches in international relations. This document articulates Russia\'s vision for its role on the global stage and how it intends to interact with other countries.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">51</data>\n      <data key="d5">6fae5ee1a831468aa585a1ea09095998</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;COMMONWEALTH OF INDEPENDENT STATES (CIS)&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"The CIS is a political and economic union of former Soviet republics."</data>\n      <data key="d2">bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">52</data>\n      <data key="d5">ef32c4b208d041cc856f6837915dc1b0</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MINISTRY OF DEFENSE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The MINISTRY OF DEFENSE is a governmental organization responsible for Russia\'s military affairs. It defines military doctrine and strategy, outlining the core tasks for the armed forces and issuing military doctrines.  \n\nThe Ministry is considered the source of information about military dangers, capabilities, doctrine, and political goals. It published the 2000 Military Doctrine and the 2010 Military Doctrine, as well as a Military Encyclopedic Dictionary defining terms like "myatezhvoina." The Ministry also provided a definition of war in 2007, emphasizing its characteristics and core content.  \n\nFurthermore, the Ministry defines subversion-wars as armed fighting by insurgent or rebel forces. Vasily Burenok is a high-ranking official within the Ministry of Defense. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">00e7336d67609903b464740eecc2da73,0da7185a3277e6969d5f94e97613b636,0e40df5d22db6584ec7e05b07c3d9b66,10779701d4d4bad771a7c8e3bdf664e0,1838769a055e042d335b716b927ac517,2528b45270d95680a57bc9094766201c,276f8550d758346b203160a32cd885b6,2836f2f0365794d9fae3abfa350f2311,287b17a01df64083a49c84828ae77591,3060e5a3570413999878edce8065dc2b,30ff2b3a1ac3fddc8b200986ef1f24f4,390e6b6bbf2dbf4ee3678f7e9b5afaed,4c0b295b06b41e7a8105d7587f0ad731,5430e32b1beaf2a36fbde8a1b9b3074f,606328f81d69fee27f0d5b308252d4db,7021759b813120aabd337b4757a1e83a,7357dc206ba88482f202ea79850252f2,927ecbbd9a7b08760bb62d394dcd75e9,9976fb85179c1c48e3cfe309be6108c7,9d9628ed6f319fa3c7a74e5a5971aad6,a9f11317bfb1cbac1d72052738a6bfd0,b39e3b697d5d9ed3835d622486095c96,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,d3c8f104bbf738655c44e9993cb8f0f7,df2540cf569ce35f7b90708e5da0b01d,fdc2c2b29672f18ffe9ae9fb2f1da756</data>\n      <data key="d6">1</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">10</data>\n      <data key="d4">53</data>\n      <data key="d5">07b2425216bd4f0aa4e079827cb48ef5</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SECURITY COUNCIL&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **Security Council** of Russia is an organization that advises the President on national security matters. It is also involved in producing military doctrines and documents, as evidenced by its adoption of a document outlining Russia\'s long-term vision for information security until 2020.  Furthermore, the Security Council held a session to discuss the essence of war, highlighting its role in shaping strategic thinking within the Russian government. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">26fe7e732ff9b3d2e54b43110076216a,7cc72471bf4edd02ae4d6b43dd505467,94bbacb0bb8aa50088b2c5d541d33537,997fce38d3477147a111b2fbe4e1433a,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,fcbe7cb6c5543166265ebbc898ee34ba</data>\n      <data key="d6">3</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">2</data>\n      <data key="d4">54</data>\n      <data key="d5">2670deebfa3f4d69bb82c28ab250a209</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MINISTRY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **MINISTRY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS** is the primary institution responsible for handling Russia\'s diplomatic relations and shaping its information security policy.  It plays a crucial role in outlining Russia\'s foreign policy goals and strategies, as evidenced by its publication of the Foreign Policy Concept in 2000 and the updated version in 2008. The Ministry is also involved in producing various documents related to foreign policy, including concepts and strategies. It serves as the source for quotes attributed to Lavrov, who represents the Ministry within international affairs.  The Ministry\'s activities and publications are considered key sources of information regarding Russia\'s approach to global security policy. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0fbf2c2d34dfce0579218bcd864902ec,20d87cdf1f465c50311a5731b700eb92,26fe7e732ff9b3d2e54b43110076216a,287b17a01df64083a49c84828ae77591,55c4942e8de72064af2356010994efd9,5910165c2ae0e582998b2c2de2b57f54,9976fb85179c1c48e3cfe309be6108c7,997fce38d3477147a111b2fbe4e1433a,9a4e544128564ba75a290bb651a8ccfc,b39e3b697d5d9ed3835d622486095c96,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,c2324291b2afa91371cc2c27eeb6979e,c243ab6f4e5afba61f79b9d15e7dc288,c67d4ba720d6b7d15c6d3b4c82538634,fcbe7cb6c5543166265ebbc898ee34ba</data>\n      <data key="d6">8</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">5</data>\n      <data key="d4">55</data>\n      <data key="d5">404309e89a5241d6bff42c05a45df206</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MILITARY STRATEGY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">Military Strategy refers to the planning and execution of military operations, encompassing both traditional and non-traditional methods.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">3bd04ac8a624fe79e353bb14221b8554,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967</data>\n      <data key="d6">12</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">56</data>\n      <data key="d5">b785a9025069417f94950ad231bb1441</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;NATIONAL SECURITY CONCEPT&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">The **National Security Concept** is a document outlining Russia\'s security strategy.  Two notable versions were discussed: one from the late 1990s and another adopted in 2000. Unlike Military Doctrine, which primarily focuses on external threats, the National Security Concept emphasizes internal threats such as terrorism and ethnonational struggles. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">28cb703fdc157a4e1b984d6601e37170,3f1469dfb6c218c8c3c64069b7a2495c,663fcd1c899cf2232bc4bbdebe560f19,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,da8ce201ab8466858c322bea48bb9804,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967</data>\n      <data key="d6">1</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">6</data>\n      <data key="d4">57</data>\n      <data key="d5">3b6cd96a27304614850709aba1c9598b</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;RUSSIAN FEDERATION&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">The Russian Federation, emerging from the dissolution of the Soviet Union,  inherited military thinking from its predecessor. While seeking to establish new security policies, it faces both military and nonmilitary threats according to documents like the Military Doctrine and National Security Concept. The country identifies itself as a target of potential hostilities and destabilization, as outlined by Gareyev.  \n\nThe Russian Federation\'s military doctrine is subject to analysis and undergoes significant changes in structure and capabilities.  Internal military dangers and long-term information security are also discussed within the context of the nation\'s evolving security landscape. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">00e7336d67609903b464740eecc2da73,28cb703fdc157a4e1b984d6601e37170,2ced16684237fb065035dffff5afc8b4,31d8ac7fc85d988e67da2c6480208aad,38a5a22d04aa221997f0aa343f0a29ac,74b1bd908c22c236bcd8a776ad40cc37,78e0d14c1d381cdf093e4f7873c77b1c,841ac43154acf1df4c5e3af00e7d0360,927ecbbd9a7b08760bb62d394dcd75e9,94bbacb0bb8aa50088b2c5d541d33537,9a10a038173b1ded524749f03c661495,b150f2af73252fedbdd595a3de157238,b27bfe84ab787e179b1320553dc4146a,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,beb665481df870fd27048e10898e8bac,cb233c91ebbe8b4085763d57986b71ca,cdb1d6abbb222058b92413663953ef84,da8ce201ab8466858c322bea48bb9804,e9def1a80602f476ecce04216e4a8a03,ed99845841304bd47e2d825a071ab187,ef02fb1d1f0e7f58d70ebfec17d8b392,f6f3bf4797ee25c5c62c11e81fb4fa83</data>\n      <data key="d6">1</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">13</data>\n      <data key="d4">58</data>\n      <data key="d5">d54956b79dd147f894b67a8b97dcbef0</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MILITARY DOCTRINE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">## MILITARY DOCTRINE\n\nMilitary Doctrine is a formal document outlining Russia\'s military strategy and objectives. It serves as a key document that defines Russia\'s understanding of war and security, encompassing strategic principles and guidelines governing military action.  \n\nFirst established in the Soviet Union, the doctrine has been updated several times, most notably in 2000 and 2010. The 2010 Military Doctrine, for example, defines five concepts of war and conflict: military conflict, armed conflict, local war, regional war, and large-scale war. It also outlines the objectives, methods, and characteristics of contemporary military conflicts.  \n\nPrevious iterations of the doctrine held a traditional view on military threats facing Russia, including local wars, weapons proliferation, and terrorism. However, the document is continually being updated in response to perceived threats and evolving geopolitical landscapes. \n\nThe Military Doctrine closely aligns with Russia\'s Foreign Policy Concept of 1993 and includes references to non-nuclear deterrence as a key aspect of its strategy. Notably, it also acknowledges the potential for protest within the Russian population.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0b053af0a82e321c5ad32e0e5014114d,26bcdb76c6596b963d2e36a4147ef816,28cb703fdc157a4e1b984d6601e37170,38a5a22d04aa221997f0aa343f0a29ac,48406587f16687aac4c95e6b442fc461,5bb2f411436cd9fd01cf7697e33fec75,63ae1b36ecf8efb01b9a95f7abdd4033,68a51313b3812e3e2ae80473d4579a10,7357dc206ba88482f202ea79850252f2,81610c5774616913fcb1d17e45b9c19b,833fcef2d336802f17cac21855d9386e,841ac43154acf1df4c5e3af00e7d0360,997fce38d3477147a111b2fbe4e1433a,9d9628ed6f319fa3c7a74e5a5971aad6,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,c243ab6f4e5afba61f79b9d15e7dc288,c57764869d0b7caa0abcd0a9e7b856aa,c6f139f4eaa3828baab624dad7b83c88,cc801e9b36ee6b6cbcb589ad5d6eb592,da8ce201ab8466858c322bea48bb9804,df2540cf569ce35f7b90708e5da0b01d,ed75045fde0e8bf203850ee3b096166f,ee529e2d08063744d6a3cc51b8b4775b,f543dfa25bae5f5d9d2649da77965967,fcbe7cb6c5543166265ebbc898ee34ba</data>\n      <data key="d6">1</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">21</data>\n      <data key="d4">59</data>\n      <data key="d5">958beecdb5bb4060948415ffd75d2b03</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;FOREIGN POLICY CONCEPT&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">**FOREIGN POLICY CONCEPT**\n\nForeign Policy Concept defines a country\'s goals and objectives in its relations with other nations.  Specifically, it outlines Russia\'s foreign policy strategy and goals within international relations. The concept is considered an official document, first established in 1993, which emphasizes traditional views on military threats as outlined in the Foreign Policy Concept of 1993. It serves as a guide for Russia\'s interactions with other countries, defining its perspectives and approaches to global affairs.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0fbf2c2d34dfce0579218bcd864902ec,5910165c2ae0e582998b2c2de2b57f54,833fcef2d336802f17cac21855d9386e,bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f,c243ab6f4e5afba61f79b9d15e7dc288,da8ce201ab8466858c322bea48bb9804,ee529e2d08063744d6a3cc51b8b4775b</data>\n      <data key="d6">8</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">6</data>\n      <data key="d4">60</data>\n      <data key="d5">b999ed77e19e4f85b7f1ae79af5c002a</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SOVIET TIMES&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1" />\n      <data key="d2">bd18c35385f699b28185f0270112773f</data>\n      <data key="d6">1</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">61</data>\n      <data key="d5">48c0c4d72da74ff5bb926fa0c856d1a7</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SOVIET MILITARY ENCYCLOPEDIA&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"EVENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **SOVIET MILITARY ENCYCLOPEDIA** acknowledged the possibility of war despite advocating for peaceful coexistence.  It served as a significant source of information for the development of the 1993 Russian Military Doctrine, influencing its content and shaping its perspective. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">91056b62e7f13dbe730a526d696cbf28,997fce38d3477147a111b2fbe4e1433a,ce0f551566143f746d8ff46f4a021065,fcbe7cb6c5543166265ebbc898ee34ba</data>\n      <data key="d6">14</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">2</data>\n      <data key="d4">62</data>\n      <data key="d5">4f3c97517f794ebfb49c4c6315f9cf23</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;CHEKINOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">CHEKINOV is a military theorist and analyst who emphasizes the importance of unconventional warfare and controlled chaos in international relations. He co-authored several articles with Bogdanov, including "The Nature and Content of a New-Generation War," focusing on the nature of modern warfare and arguing that military security is intertwined with other forms of security, particularly information security. \n\nChekinov believes that information resources are effective weapons in modern warfare and advocates for the use of propaganda and information operations as key to victory. He also argues that nonmilitary means, such as color revolutions, should be prioritized over traditional military force.  His work explores the impact of informatization and automatization on conventional armed forces and highlights the shifting understanding of war in the contemporary world. Chekinov\'s ideas are influenced by Slipchenko and he is considered a relevant figure in discussions about modern warfare strategies. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0f6caa8f2e4b146cbd71b583add938f8,3e06cb0ad46a2e027bad24715e248b03,3e6ab14e2f0c4f2a8a611ac169b8dc44,5599962db5be274ac157280f1faa4590,677c7a0f4f60503badb0a4d899c21d74,82893599bbdf88d7635db30797b87987,8e59b8e09a13e3b59b06fd4c22fd9a1e,988cfd2c3c636c6bc23a2455381cfe57,a3a7513f41e4fd6cb9e4f0decdbc615d,a8ab56e6e419d570a195fd2ea167899d,b45be955e924377403f02def4244bbcf,ba4314d7dde31a9a3de140b03d964db0,bd400dbd8e753ab71c9394fe8b1f07ce,d8383d735e3d4dedd141bc4b08e3eeaa,db7fc162ad9590d171cb7d6fc1ef0fc2,e216e7f3ed5bf3208c1f51eaa41603b8,fa6f1322c861f018219ae4741df2bae1</data>\n      <data key="d6">7</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">3</data>\n      <data key="d4">63</data>\n      <data key="d5">1745a2485a9443bab76587ad650e9be0</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;BOGDANOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">**BOGDANOV** is a prominent Russian military theorist and strategist who has significantly contributed to the discourse surrounding modern warfare.  He is known for his co-authorship with **Chekinov** on numerous articles and studies exploring the nature of new-generation warfare, emphasizing the importance of information operations and unconventional strategies in achieving strategic goals. \n\nBogdanov\'s views have evolved over time, reflecting a shift towards recognizing the impact of informatization and automatization on conventional armed forces. He argues that nonmilitary means, such as color revolutions, can effectively address military threats, a perspective he shares with **Chekinov**.  \n\nHis work has been influential in shaping Russian military theory, particularly during the 2010s when he played a key role in debates surrounding National Security Concepts and unconventional warfare. Bogdanov\'s research at the Center for Military-Strategic Studies further highlights his expertise in contemporary armed conflict. He is also recognized as an analyst who discusses the influence of technology on military strategies and a researcher who explores 21st-century armed confrontations.  \n\nBogdanov\'s writings have been cited by other scholars, solidifying his position as a key figure in understanding the evolving landscape of warfare. His work has been influenced by **Slipchenko**, demonstrating the interconnectedness of ideas within Russian military thought.\n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0f6caa8f2e4b146cbd71b583add938f8,2a095cc3e0a26865ad75d88bf966ff8e,3e06cb0ad46a2e027bad24715e248b03,3e6ab14e2f0c4f2a8a611ac169b8dc44,5599962db5be274ac157280f1faa4590,663fcd1c899cf2232bc4bbdebe560f19,677c7a0f4f60503badb0a4d899c21d74,6e49482d37bfe8a11381f5fd9b2bf9ab,7be505fea57e0dbd921a3c195dd29aac,82893599bbdf88d7635db30797b87987,8b92cdcfa04a1ea8203cde59478b7bf8,8e59b8e09a13e3b59b06fd4c22fd9a1e,94370d1d5947827c2063332f75adfb60,988cfd2c3c636c6bc23a2455381cfe57,a3a7513f41e4fd6cb9e4f0decdbc615d,a8ab56e6e419d570a195fd2ea167899d,b45be955e924377403f02def4244bbcf,ba4314d7dde31a9a3de140b03d964db0,bd400dbd8e753ab71c9394fe8b1f07ce,d8383d735e3d4dedd141bc4b08e3eeaa,db7fc162ad9590d171cb7d6fc1ef0fc2,e216e7f3ed5bf3208c1f51eaa41603b8,e76184cff7bad45cbad7c9b1d3777f30,e89037639c79dd9077a756282d6c2a7d,ef55602335bea29d08150b6649fad897,fa6f1322c861f018219ae4741df2bae1,fc20acf548ac287cb2de74e6e1ea4d6e</data>\n      <data key="d6">7</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">9</data>\n      <data key="d4">64</data>\n      <data key="d5">32e6ccab20d94029811127dbbe424c64</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SLIPCHENKO&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">**SLIPCHENKO** is a significant Russian military theorist who is widely recognized as a key figure in the development of concepts surrounding sixth-generation warfare.  \n\nHe first introduced his ideas on generations of war in 1989, and his work has heavily influenced prominent military thinkers like Bogdanov, Chekinov, and Orekhov. Slipchenko\'s writings focus on the evolving nature of conventional warfare, particularly emphasizing the increasing importance of high-precision, long-range weapons and reconnaissance-strike systems. He argues that these systems hold overwhelming superiority in modern conflict. \n\nSlipchenko is also a leading proponent of "remote/contactless war," defining it as warfare conducted through precision strikes and information manipulation, viewing information itself as a destructive weapon. His theories on non-contact warfare and information dominance have been influential in shaping Russian military doctrine.  He is considered a significant expert on military history and the concept of generations of warfare, with his work cited extensively in academic and military circles. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">04b87a5b565ec557540bb2b0bf38763f,068fed974175a4460923174d7ce00bbf,0ac95daa24b8448799785bd3afba6112,12575d1b6f02a59280ed0326b418f907,12ae590d68b54130fcdd8b11cda495b2,276f8550d758346b203160a32cd885b6,2d96d25d0022a1193382ea88b904435a,3ff11360ddc5bd1fa296a784da747a6e,51b868d40e3701709987e796369fbf69,5599962db5be274ac157280f1faa4590,59b16bcd3d0d008e7066303a0111b65a,6cd14cb301caba80aed605f5aad6fc2e,7be505fea57e0dbd921a3c195dd29aac,83d8321db4baeb9dd56aa1e91eb29a39,85e4e298e365df474828bb853c808db1,8b92cdcfa04a1ea8203cde59478b7bf8,8c989fc0d3fc136d27a9f97d0fe40c82,8e59b8e09a13e3b59b06fd4c22fd9a1e,988cfd2c3c636c6bc23a2455381cfe57,a1fc196183277908b1cc6e1504847875,ac08e98f560a5dcdd378a622eca69f06,b29675ce5cc82b245a129a47bcd9a3d5,b7d2323e75cae9a4221b0eb05c65b171,ba4314d7dde31a9a3de140b03d964db0,c1fde4292cf13cc0042a258ed0932fb6,cd472d2664acb377dd498e88b7ed8d58,d494718117eae6e351eff5873eca32c0,d8383d735e3d4dedd141bc4b08e3eeaa,dcdc940fd2d0b50a2cd9e38ec0d2d76f,e216e7f3ed5bf3208c1f51eaa41603b8,ee529e2d08063744d6a3cc51b8b4775b,f773883fc42cbafe5e0268d526176d80,fb8a4e3d89439bd18b6f6ecae81d6d7c</data>\n      <data key="d6">7</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">18</data>\n      <data key="d4">65</data>\n      <data key="d5">94a964c6992945ebb3833dfdfdc8d655</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;THOMAS&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Thomas is a Western scholar and analyst who has been specializing in Russian information warfare since 1996. He is known for his research on Russian military thought, particularly focusing on continuity within it. Thomas argues that the US often neglects this continuity when analyzing Russia\'s approach to conflict through the lens of hybrid and gray area concepts.  \n\nHis work delves into the writings of prominent Russian military theorists like Chekinov and Bogdanov, identifying Slipchenko as a key influence. He has also examined the concept of Non-Governmental Warfare (NGW) in Russian military literature, noting its apparent disappearance from recent texts. Thomas\'s publications cover a range of topics related to Russia\'s view of warfare, including propaganda, hybrid warfare, and the Gerasimov doctrine.  He is recognized as an expert who has contributed significantly to understanding the evolution of war and Russia\'s role within it. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0a127d33c040b6f998a650ee92decc96,0d5bebc49e84be0b136baa2a23ad6119,3ac56cedae22345797ec130c512cc5b9,46383c461d50b84aa5f19d44407b0924,597b96f29d47f44fa260f97ed43bcb31,61fe19114215de9edf4b2df2fb6f0fb0,74abf737631531a56e8f3e9456798f10,850631a820a8158d8c7bff68e8f7fea5,ba4314d7dde31a9a3de140b03d964db0,d81d350aa6c9162a49b1eb526ae982b8,e216e7f3ed5bf3208c1f51eaa41603b8,e97880df6b33eecb3147aea6e798be7d,f3286050de3ac7fdc74f33ed1403c501</data>\n      <data key="d6">10</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">5</data>\n      <data key="d4">66</data>\n      <data key="d5">1eb829d0ace042089f0746f78729696c</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;CHEKINOV &amp; BOGDANOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1" />\n      <data key="d2">3e6ab14e2f0c4f2a8a611ac169b8dc44,db7fc162ad9590d171cb7d6fc1ef0fc2,e216e7f3ed5bf3208c1f51eaa41603b8</data>\n      <data key="d6">10</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">6</data>\n      <data key="d4">67</data>\n      <data key="d5">015e7b58d1a14b44beab3bbc9f912c18</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;KIRSHIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">KIRSHIN is an author who critiques traditional definitions of war, arguing that they are insufficient for comprehending modern global issues.  Their work centers on a debate surrounding Clausewitz\'s definition of war and its perceived limitations. KIRSHIN proposes a new understanding of war in their text, directly challenging existing paradigms. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">3e06cb0ad46a2e027bad24715e248b03,3e6ab14e2f0c4f2a8a611ac169b8dc44,82893599bbdf88d7635db30797b87987,f008ece3160552dbbd23842a0d13f1f7</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">68</data>\n      <data key="d5">26f88ab3e2e04c33a459ad6270ade565</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;CLAUSEWITZ&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">## Clausewitz: A Military Theorist Whose Ideas Continue to Spark Debate\n\nClausewitz, a Prussian general and military theorist, is widely recognized for his influential ideas on war. He is best known for his dictum, "war is merely a continuation of politics by other means," which suggests that war is an extension of political objectives pursued through violence. Clausewitz defined war as "an act of force to compel the enemy to do your will," emphasizing the use of force to achieve desired outcomes. \n\nHis work has been both praised and criticized by subsequent military theorists. While some, like Lenin and Stalin, found his emphasis on the relationship between politics and war influential, others, such as Kirshin, Kvachkov, and Orekhov, considered his definition too narrow.  Soviet theorists, while acknowledging Clausewitz\'s influence, often contrasted his traditional understanding of war with their own Marxist-Leninist perspectives. \n\nClausewitz\'s ideas continue to be debated and analyzed today. His work is referenced in discussions about modern warfare concepts, and his views on achieving victory in war are still considered relevant by military scholars like Gorbunov and Bogdanov. Despite the passage of time, Clausewitz remains a significant figure in military history, whose theories continue to shape our understanding of war and its relationship to politics. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">046f04af090c144a8bd1403c6c5879a4,08b5b9a81f792e1a63e929dc06a81d50,0b7f36c1efd528460ea8b64f4d00c6a9,11b09d5fddbfffd21c2a75e43b225a4a,135bc11aa823b69772040362565fae86,137a23ec0a6c30f2d104480a42ca716b,1b996f45c7b397759863385a53361eed,1cce175e6c7003db4a0791abde031a39,1d746c1fd3ea7d25a42568701611f772,2999e2ab9620ec881fdf22361f3bb121,2be40bedc401aa74026067cbca67b681,2f7216242ac705ab8c989c77c74d477b,3215346816955c73a119fe8038088c8e,37215a6c4810a7b385fb17417f94fbe0,38c01208da0359baa45c7640d7a2285c,3e06cb0ad46a2e027bad24715e248b03,3e6ab14e2f0c4f2a8a611ac169b8dc44,4424ff0552ddcfee2317f7caf01db070,4640d14036dc3924713f8e3da33466d6,4d3bd4beec226501211dcd3560fd6fba,4e2896fd5b6f31d006ca18e1a3299553,54841d8827acc62d9af1b1f976a8c99f,5f022b2409af8223bf100e9564e5f586,7aef3b8e0c0a9cd9f240dfbe12e02c38,82893599bbdf88d7635db30797b87987,83d8321db4baeb9dd56aa1e91eb29a39,86135dd72edc8f7cfa522d2093158942,897b3e3eedf4e832571846d6ff67fabe,962347193b87926e833cb5e1de7ff4e2,a15ef9eda68738122db496f9962d6a9f,b1b64ef207d42a2b81118c978ce1f222,bab940f0cf76af894b6edb440a57b5f8,bfa15fcd5d4a19aa65f946d1af780d5f,c4d611eafc5e900466e378a2742c03bf,cca1605d479526e189239aac472c3e7e,d1330c3cbc7e7877db9ba902371af4d9,db7fc162ad9590d171cb7d6fc1ef0fc2,e847464375c697471e8db8e76b49b6d1,f008ece3160552dbbd23842a0d13f1f7,f196fc7516d60a5e95b2a477d1f0b3f7,f1ea10917ad6f50fda3a92586fe998dc,fb8a4e3d89439bd18b6f6ecae81d6d7c</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">13</data>\n      <data key="d4">69</data>\n      <data key="d5">babe97e1d9784cffa1c85abc1e588126</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;CRIMEAN OPERATION&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"EVENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"The Crimean operation is described as an example of new-generation warfare."</data>\n      <data key="d2">3e06cb0ad46a2e027bad24715e248b03</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">70</data>\n      <data key="d5">1033a18c45aa4584b2aef6ab96890351</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;CHEKINOV AND BOGDANOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Chekinov and Bogdanov are a pair of authors and scholars who have significantly contributed to the evolving understanding of modern warfare. They argue that the nature of war has shifted, emphasizing unconventional tactics, information warfare, and psychological operations as crucial elements in contemporary military strategy. \n\nTheir work highlights the importance of information operations and reconnaissance-strike systems, contending that wars in recent decades have been characterized by "controlled chaos."  They believe that information-psychological warfare will be increasingly vital in future conflicts, aiming to influence populations, erode morale, and control troops. Chekinov and Bogdanov also explore the role of foreign grants in potentially destabilizing a country\'s social system through attacks. \n\nInfluenced by Slipchenko\'s ideas, they have published articles and conducted research on these topics, contributing to the broader discourse on security doctrines and the changing face of warfare.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0d5bebc49e84be0b136baa2a23ad6119,1907c51ffd4a90ea75fb1ba62cee3e69,2d96d25d0022a1193382ea88b904435a,38bf7298856b8fd4341bb0998b803ee0,3bd04ac8a624fe79e353bb14221b8554,406ecd4768447aa06d26731538246770,4f7f4f6fe9d288255da50532faa25f53,68355cf380d714ea713e77efbe44d3ac,68e4ed89f41a580e3c58f0f98434cc33,6b6ac6cc3ec6eac44948fcf6afcb38d9,757d82782cf6930b803cbaa29e0f5a1a,8107ca436cb6585337e956c4238a346c,8196d4fb9caac5c7ffd87f465eac8c12,83d8321db4baeb9dd56aa1e91eb29a39,b29675ce5cc82b245a129a47bcd9a3d5,b3066af57efb89b0569dbadaba8b79bc,bd0d9bfb86c0dbbc88767c3e5a743934,beb665481df870fd27048e10898e8bac,cb50fafd31d07b9e8f9e52f658937913,d494718117eae6e351eff5873eca32c0,ff55559376e5dd4c5e5cb9f53d33e241,ff779b872510c138da68523b69265b0e</data>\n      <data key="d6">6</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">12</data>\n      <data key="d4">71</data>\n      <data key="d5">c9b8ce91fc2945b4907fe35519339cac</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;INSTITUTIONS&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">## Institutions\n\nInstitutions are established organizations with a defined purpose. They often play a role in shaping strategies and can encompass a wide range of entities.  Some institutions, particularly those involved in research, may receive funding from foreign sources and could potentially participate in distributed attacks. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">8107ca436cb6585337e956c4238a346c,8c89f749cd4aa8e422be2a970f803bec</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">72</data>\n      <data key="d5">fa3c4204421c48609e52c8de2da4c654</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SCHOLARS&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Scholars are individuals who conduct research and analysis in the field of strategic theory. They are experts who agree on the effectiveness of limited nuclear use in deterring conventional hostilities, often engaging in research on foreign grants and their potential impact.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">37a79c861cb20a05659b6f1b76b007ba,5df832f6cec6c27ae77e370f07cac8d6,8107ca436cb6585337e956c4238a346c</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">73</data>\n      <data key="d5">53af055f068244d0ac861b2e89376495</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;ARAB SPRING REVOLUTIONS&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"EVENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **Arab Spring Revolutions** are described as both applications of Western technology and spontaneous uprisings, reflecting conflicting perspectives on their nature. Some argue that they serve as evidence for a new military age characterized by "high-tech wars," citing the use of advanced technology in these uprisings.  Others emphasize the organic and grassroots nature of the revolutions, suggesting they were primarily driven by popular discontent rather than sophisticated military strategies. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0d5bebc49e84be0b136baa2a23ad6119,465274671b741f3ad76a316d27207a5f,8107ca436cb6585337e956c4238a346c</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">74</data>\n      <data key="d5">c03ab3ce8cb74ad2a03b94723bfab3c7</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;OV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">OV is a commandant at the Academy of the General Staff and holds a high position within the Soviet Armed Forces.  As a speaker, OV\'s rhetoric reflects both established views on the nature of war and an awareness of its evolving characteristics. Additionally, OV is recognized as an author or organization that published a work in 2009. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">27431841e2c6fbfbbcda31bea529d948,972ad08450d40acba47394c99e434c56,9bccda96a6276236341ab0595d832858,9d078dbf3cd9f132d9d452509bd774f1,c6bceb66a3d2c04618fc4513ce73962c</data>\n      <data key="d6">3</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">3</data>\n      <data key="d4">75</data>\n      <data key="d5">ed6d2eee9d7b4f5db466b1f6404d31cc</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;ACADEMY OF THE GENERAL STAFF&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **Academy of the General Staff** is a prestigious institution within the Soviet Armed Forces. It serves as a hub for developing and sharing military expertise,  and it holds a high position of importance within the force structure. Notably, Kuralenko worked at the Academy as the chief of military art. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">27431841e2c6fbfbbcda31bea529d948,68e7972f85fd6fc2109534ff86630800,6e81ca9f9ef3229b5c0e79413b269e37,9bccda96a6276236341ab0595d832858,fd24a983ae975cadc842ce8fa5eea97c</data>\n      <data key="d6">3</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">2</data>\n      <data key="d4">76</data>\n      <data key="d5">fc01e9baa80e417c9206f941bb279407</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SOVIET ARMED FORCES&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The Soviet Armed Forces are the military force of the Soviet Union.  Under the leadership of Nikita Khrushchev, they were a powerful organization where individuals like Gen. Vladimir Kurasov held top positions. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">2090f56414eebaeb642f4296f8762613,27431841e2c6fbfbbcda31bea529d948,5fc5a6b5aebd3d100c1491fc135bc6da,6e81ca9f9ef3229b5c0e79413b269e37,9bccda96a6276236341ab0595d832858</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">2</data>\n      <data key="d4">77</data>\n      <data key="d5">56d0e5ebe79e4814bd1463cf6ca21394</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;STALIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Joseph Stalin was a key figure in Soviet military strategy whose ideas remain influential.  He dominated Soviet strategic thought due to his control of both the Communist Party and the military apparatus. Stalin viewed Clausewitz\'s ideas as already present in Marxist theory, and he criticized the premise that Clausewitz is obsolete, arguing for its relevance in Lenin\'s thought. His influence extended to the suppression of opposing viewpoints, such as those of Svechin, whose work he placed under restriction. Despite his death marking a potential shift in the relationship between military and political leadership, subordination of the military to political control persisted. Stalin\'s military art continues to be analyzed and discussed by historians. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">11b09d5fddbfffd21c2a75e43b225a4a,27431841e2c6fbfbbcda31bea529d948,38c01208da0359baa45c7640d7a2285c,9bccda96a6276236341ab0595d832858,cca1605d479526e189239aac472c3e7e,d1330c3cbc7e7877db9ba902371af4d9,ee2a956c830712b74c912b175f90afdd</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">4</data>\n      <data key="d4">78</data>\n      <data key="d5">7c49f2710e8b4d3b8dc9310834406ea5</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;VASILY SOKOLOVSKY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Vasily Sokolovsky is a prominent Soviet military theorist. He emphasized the importance of Marxist-Leninist dialectics in understanding war and defined it as armed violence between different groups for political goals.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">27431841e2c6fbfbbcda31bea529d948,3d90ffe5fbb2fe4d1036ef242b8830be,b90af97596777a0400f9c331a5d96a40,e8d8461aeecbc6801361ca4fa5c3e2e2</data>\n      <data key="d6">12</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">79</data>\n      <data key="d5">c6d1e4f56c2843e89cf0b91c10bb6de2</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SOVIET MILITARY SCIENCE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">Soviet Military Science is a field of study that focuses on developing methods and forms of armed conflict within the context of the Soviet Union.  It draws heavily upon the precepts of the Communist Party, incorporating dialectical materialism and historical analysis to form its system of knowledge about war. \n\nCharacterized by holism, Soviet military science emphasizes the interconnectedness of all aspects of war, recognizing that military success depends on a comprehensive understanding of political, economic, social, and technological factors.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">27431841e2c6fbfbbcda31bea529d948,2a4b75db8fdd23483fc6c4f097c7f56f,2be40bedc401aa74026067cbca67b681,4424ff0552ddcfee2317f7caf01db070,645ce27900f66a0b633be93f0e5d6399,8c7cf0e88b403959479bde7eb44c8654,b4cf9c163a2ba0d0db3385c6741457ac,e90da29be1148d9844e3ed777db08bf6</data>\n      <data key="d6">12</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">7</data>\n      <data key="d4">80</data>\n      <data key="d5">0adb2d9941f34ef7b2f7743cc6225844</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MARXIST PHILOSOPHY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">Marxist philosophy, with its roots in Hegelian dialectics, is a foundational element of Soviet military science.  It heavily influences the development and application of military strategy and doctrine within the Soviet Union. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">27431841e2c6fbfbbcda31bea529d948,2be40bedc401aa74026067cbca67b681,4424ff0552ddcfee2317f7caf01db070</data>\n      <data key="d6">12</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">2</data>\n      <data key="d4">81</data>\n      <data key="d5">6b02373137fd438ba96af28f735cdbdb</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;HEGELIAN DIALECTICS&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Hegelian Dialectics serves as the philosophical bedrock for Marxist philosophy, an influence that extends to Soviet military science.  Its historical significance is underscored by its recognition as a precursor to Marxist dialectics. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">2be40bedc401aa74026067cbca67b681,4424ff0552ddcfee2317f7caf01db070</data>\n      <data key="d6">12</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">82</data>\n      <data key="d5">36a4fcd8efc144e6b8af9a1c7ab8b2ce</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;DIALECTICAL MATERIALISM&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">Dialectical Materialism is a philosophical system that serves as a foundational principle for Soviet military science.  It emphasizes historical analysis and change, acting as a key element in the Soviet understanding of war. This influence extends to their holistic approach to politics and conflict, shaping their view of war as an interconnected phenomenon. Dialectical materialism is presented as a philosophical system with three basic laws that guide this understanding. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">2a4b75db8fdd23483fc6c4f097c7f56f,2be40bedc401aa74026067cbca67b681,3cd3649d4d82b16c6d105090d8081f6e,4424ff0552ddcfee2317f7caf01db070,645ce27900f66a0b633be93f0e5d6399,8493f884b789159d96b7dab3a7202396,e8980bd806b32ffd5ad4b169a299338d,e90da29be1148d9844e3ed777db08bf6</data>\n      <data key="d6">12</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">4</data>\n      <data key="d4">83</data>\n      <data key="d5">fbeef791d19b413a9c93c6608286ab63</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;KVACHKOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">KVACHKOV is an author and military theorist who proposes a new conception of war, emphasizing non-military means. He presents a new classification of war that includes both military and non-military means,  differing from Clausewitz\'s definition while sharing similarities with Serebryannikov\'s views on war. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">1507b417cf61f29030428f95a1c2dc08,4640d14036dc3924713f8e3da33466d6,86135dd72edc8f7cfa522d2093158942,990f73c5f878701d1f0eda068b4141f2,c4d611eafc5e900466e378a2742c03bf,e847464375c697471e8db8e76b49b6d1</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">5</data>\n      <data key="d4">84</data>\n      <data key="d5">d2b629c0396f4180a03e16ddf3818589</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SEREBRYANNIKOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Serebryannikov is a military theorist and scholar whose views on war are often compared to those of Kvachkov. He emphasizes the importance of armed conflict in warfare, believing that information-psychological warfare holds significant potential for influencing citizens.  Serebryannikov\'s conclusions align with Kvachkov\'s, suggesting both scholars prioritize the role of physical violence in achieving military objectives. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">2ea3da30a4c11ce53e27f0d4b749018c,4640d14036dc3924713f8e3da33466d6,489aeca592784f5f7be0a754beb4f575,48e310bd8a37fd938fc512819430d5f7,57424d7973e0b0ad452fc6115605d61f,818993a678a84051e60563bfd33f106a,c4d611eafc5e900466e378a2742c03bf,e847464375c697471e8db8e76b49b6d1</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">5</data>\n      <data key="d4">85</data>\n      <data key="d5">6102fc6619ed422ebc42588bfa97355d</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;GAREYEV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Mikhail Gareyev is a prominent Russian military theorist and expert on military science. He is recognized for his contributions to the understanding of war\'s evolution, particularly in light of modern non-military means of confrontation.  \n\nGareyev argues for a traditional definition of war while acknowledging the increasing importance of non-military forms of struggle, such as information warfare and "soft power," which he views as threats to Russia. He emphasizes the need to reevaluate the definition of war in the 21st century due to these evolving threats.  \n\nHis book, "Battles on the Military-Historical Front," endorsed by General Gerasimov, reflects Russia\'s perspective on information warfare. Gareyev has also written extensively about the changing nature of war, including the blurring of lines between military and non-military means, and the significance of moral superiority, technology, and doctrine in modern warfare. He is considered a leading figure in Russian military thought, comparable to Kartapolov and Gerasimov. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">068fed974175a4460923174d7ce00bbf,0e40df5d22db6584ec7e05b07c3d9b66,112509ae19803edd47655e5f2fc22ae1,147e97078c17806ecd33780d6451826f,26bcdb76c6596b963d2e36a4147ef816,2ed01d91a2d5804af478b65fbd4fff17,3335c606e0de431e14afc7e61f86dfa8,35f2eda2e0dde94f12831c18a3f5fa57,35fa4f03c6bbb412d22ff5f494e83329,3722261684591ed62374be49eb1b29a9,38e06a95c9c0cfb7005614fb378b4a28,3fe4dd62a032b1a281c925fbec9cbc6a,4640d14036dc3924713f8e3da33466d6,46560acff919ef6253fd1d861d00ae9c,483f10acb5879df6406474c706388bbb,4a4127fa2d140cfe4bba76e93169d035,4f7f4f6fe9d288255da50532faa25f53,518267175ed2900e7e23fd3a54bdf33f,5c79cd610c718db1aa2cf27f837d00c8,5cd9f4f78cb2dfdfcb512cc36ac0202f,62f74165e5942d3e5a65f9812140f735,651d70f1b96f83fb3e8a870528879b0f,68d539054aaa9dcc75ed59e59850468c,6bacaefd10a9194c28dfbec9e59620a1,7357dc206ba88482f202ea79850252f2,752e31eca4dc5d94da820c3cb84cf6e9,7567750cec0624c2e9f362f989d8b1bc,76afbf3e037f83e305f2431eddf52e38,803cf3c02920d14a7bb0447fc1c76140,84b65c4d676043766aeebfc93b776ae6,84fbeb27b48ec1426740369d4f5b851e,850631a820a8158d8c7bff68e8f7fea5,8beec46e554e40907188a8b4eadfb7f8,93ae7eb8b09d8dba110ee24dc8c2544c,9d9628ed6f319fa3c7a74e5a5971aad6,a8ab56e6e419d570a195fd2ea167899d,abe7dca7f715b3a56df70fa74b56aa30,ac4e19c9709c97775be647ede43818b5,b150f2af73252fedbdd595a3de157238,b561bc3a166d627669a12364a4a320b1,bbe1de76c191cb2a1148f1c4cc547644,bc02775c6811de9ca81bfb2af4207e24,bd400dbd8e753ab71c9394fe8b1f07ce,bfbbd058526ebede84405e2e4e3f47b5,c4d611eafc5e900466e378a2742c03bf,c57482161043b2c5d5a644c558fb2fa6,c6557d1800561000ed6c8db91857d73e,c8c68899e22ee8c693d6e73e47d38c9e,cdb1d6abbb222058b92413663953ef84,d67b112a958502c163b1c99c7ba13f8f,df08541749dd65fc3af06e736fdc5203,e0053ef676c35b3b5e2e0225190d6463,e0927b91be8f756165d5fca82ca84107,e847464375c697471e8db8e76b49b6d1,fa1f745b441f0a8da9c96e5184733ab7,fcf6292acd4060dcb8b6f555eeebabe3</data>\n      <data key="d6">5</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">30</data>\n      <data key="d4">86</data>\n      <data key="d5">8d141c0b80f74b79a05eed7fe161fe49</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;OTSTAIVAYA NATSIONALNYYE INTERESY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"EVENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Otstaivaya natsionalnyye interesy" is a 2005 article by Gareyev, likely exploring the topic of national interests in relation to war."</data>\n      <data key="d2">62f74165e5942d3e5a65f9812140f735</data>\n      <data key="d6">5</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">87</data>\n      <data key="d5">e22d1d1cd8d14f12b81828d940f40d70</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;KAZARIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Kazarin is an author who, in his work, argues that information struggle is a unique type of warfare inherent in all other forms of conflict. He first introduced this concept in 2002.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">41577e491a1539dcefa344bdfe5ecdf6,48e310bd8a37fd938fc512819430d5f7,60642b4264405ef39d55111c2feff3c4</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">88</data>\n      <data key="d5">9ab48505fb1b487babd0d1f6d3a3f980</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;VLADIMIR SEREBRYANNIKOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Lieutenant General Vladimir Serebryannikov argues against expanding the concept of "information struggle" because he believes it would blur the lines between war and peace.  He warns that including information warfare under the umbrella of war could have detrimental consequences for distinguishing peaceful activities from acts of aggression. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">48e310bd8a37fd938fc512819430d5f7,cfae2a9660e62a12a25d2678a2931f34</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">89</data>\n      <data key="d5">148fffeb994541b2b4b6dcefda7001a8</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SUN TZU&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Sun Tzu is a historical military strategist from ancient times. His ideas on warfare are widely referenced, particularly by Gorbunov and Bogdanov who cite his writings.  Serebryannikov also mentions Sun Tzu as an authority figure, highlighting his suggestion about achieving victory in war without fighting. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">37215a6c4810a7b385fb17417f94fbe0,48e310bd8a37fd938fc512819430d5f7,5497fc2e9ef0c53f1b17d4b901c85832,6c276ef5c88e4f06e651dfab52e4f31a</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">3</data>\n      <data key="d4">90</data>\n      <data key="d5">89c08e793298442686292454a1abff31</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;INFORMATION STRUGGLE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0" />\n      <data key="d1">"Information Struggle" is a concept that has gained popularity alongside "Armed Struggle".  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">48e310bd8a37fd938fc512819430d5f7,b477b517d309b8c0ead048c621cce8c7</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">91</data>\n      <data key="d5">0467928aa65e4a4fba62bdb1467e3a54</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;ARMED VIOLENCE&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Armed Violence is widely recognized as a key element in defining war.  While various scholars emphasize its importance, there\'s also recognition that it\'s not the sole defining factor. Kalistratov argues that armed violence is a component of war but not the only one. Gerasimov and Serebryannikov both highlight armed violence as a crucial aspect of warfare. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">2ea3da30a4c11ce53e27f0d4b749018c,305962ed9f6bc11996bd9bee0803ed4f,313dc3be1190b1a10a2579c621091156,81610c5774616913fcb1d17e45b9c19b</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">92</data>\n      <data key="d5">43c3390303c6476cb65f584e37c3e81c</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;WARFARE PROPER&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Warfare proper refers to traditional military conflict involving armed forces."</data>\n      <data key="d2">2ea3da30a4c11ce53e27f0d4b749018c</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">93</data>\n      <data key="d5">fa14b16c17e3417dba5a4b473ea5b18d</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;NONMILITARY ACTION&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Nonmilitary action encompasses strategies and tactics that do not involve direct combat."</data>\n      <data key="d2">2ea3da30a4c11ce53e27f0d4b749018c</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">94</data>\n      <data key="d5">7cc3356d38de4328a51a5cbcb187dac3</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;MOSCOW&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"GEO"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Moscow is the capital of Russia and a key player in strategic decision-making. It is presented as the center of Russian decision-making regarding national security and military strategy, and the location from which hostile actions could be assessed. Moscow is also mentioned as a geopolitical entity whose efforts are being analyzed, and a location where the Russian military has demonstrated its capabilities. \n\nAs a key actor in international relations, Moscow engages in deterrence and coercion strategies, expressing frustration with Western perceptions and actions, as well as misperceptions. It perceives informational struggle as a way to counter US information warfare.  Moscow is also mentioned as the place of publication for K Novoi Redaktsii Voennoi Doktriny. The city serves as a point of interaction with the West, representing the Russian government or military leadership and its strategic community. \n\n\nPolicymaking discourse takes place in Moscow, and it is considered a location where actions can be assessed.  Moscow is also home to a strategic community, highlighting its geopolitical significance. Finally, Moscow is mentioned as the location or origin of the strategic calculus being discussed. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">00a8e6977b8cc35ff2706d718367759f,0f97ca1859706e3c7adde28565dbdfc9,1422855893cd2f75b13c9945dc9b4499,26123c88ed4eb5080379f3088a3359d6,2eec4248a3431cdb2dccff5f1d3bac61,317fb77f10175bd5aa2b7ba8103b25ad,3f38017cf23bc7563f3f91672438843d,4029a673e4a82185b802f0ac1cd07c9c,54c29f07a55c22a9e00bc4e9dc3677da,55dbadef5c541e211456244efc6a8b5d,61ac280201ff550c532fdc0a622b220c,8ae47a9c81c4c6fbf931669abf14bb19,8e19a67a1ae3b88f93b6c2d0e4c861c7,a4f7f4b3c3aaa2c4a28a4f9fc0d813a1,b396d1fc4c58ebeaf31c106290ae5cee,bcc65b2e28c6961542c9ec3723d8eed0,cf5dcbae87f58f73dad6c1bfbd73256a,d7db417821a9ecdbb04ad34de78b0244,dbec7ffa34212bcbbf7129724563c4f8,e2a5e39382c16958dda0da6127375f20,e39fb7abe3971a7b1e2ec226eb9a1e1f,f131e67e4b2ea2d98c5968dd6c57cda5</data>\n      <data key="d6">11</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">6</data>\n      <data key="d4">95</data>\n      <data key="d5">bef16fb5fd7344cca5e295b13ef3e0cd</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;URSS&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The URSS is a publishing house responsible for publishing "K Novoi Redaktsii Voennoi Doktriny".  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">1422855893cd2f75b13c9945dc9b4499,2eec4248a3431cdb2dccff5f1d3bac61</data>\n      <data key="d6">11</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">96</data>\n      <data key="d5">bb9e01bc171d4326a29afda59ece8d17</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;VIKTOR LITOVKIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Viktor Litovkin is a person and an author who wrote articles for NVO. He is also mentioned as a source of information. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">1422855893cd2f75b13c9945dc9b4499,2eec4248a3431cdb2dccff5f1d3bac61</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">97</data>\n      <data key="d5">3c063eea52e94164b70c99431ea30bae</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;NVO&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">NVO is an organization, likely a news outlet or publication, where Viktor Litovkin works.  It is also the publication where Viktor Litovkin published his articles. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">1422855893cd2f75b13c9945dc9b4499,2eec4248a3431cdb2dccff5f1d3bac61</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">98</data>\n      <data key="d5">252cc8452bfc4c2aa58cab68d8b61879</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;ANDREI KOKOSHIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Andrei Kokoshin is a prominent Russian defense intellectual known for his critiques of Russian military theory.  A former high-ranking civilian official in the Ministry of Defense and former head of the Security Council, Kokoshin advocated for non-nuclear deterrence strategies. He is recognized as a leading figure who popularized the term "asymmetrical approach" within Russian military discourse. \n\nKokoshin\'s work, including his book "Asimetrichnyi otvet na SOI," focuses on highlighting the shortcomings of traditional Russian military theory in addressing strategic gestures.  He argues that Russian military theory requires greater elaboration on this crucial aspect of modern warfare. His insights have been widely cited and discussed, notably in Viktor Litovkin\'s articles and works. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0f97ca1859706e3c7adde28565dbdfc9,1422855893cd2f75b13c9945dc9b4499,1838769a055e042d335b716b927ac517,2eec4248a3431cdb2dccff5f1d3bac61,32552e34b76feed065cdc69c8ac456eb,4c204df8ad672f0ac08e5f67507eaf18,9e035904f808f85d23d4e5ec8791c76d,eaf0d08dbd97c1a7311aa7c886044509</data>\n      <data key="d6">5</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">99</data>\n      <data key="d5">7e2c84548fb94ee395ba8588d8f2a006</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;IGOR\' VARFOLOMEEV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Igor\' Varfolomeev is an author known for writing articles for KZ. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">1422855893cd2f75b13c9945dc9b4499,2eec4248a3431cdb2dccff5f1d3bac61</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">100</data>\n      <data key="d5">f034618dde7948beb6dab30176d0fc87</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;KZ&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"KZ" is a publication where Igor\' Varfolomeev published his articles. It is also mentioned as a potential news outlet or publication serving as a source for information.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">1422855893cd2f75b13c9945dc9b4499,2eec4248a3431cdb2dccff5f1d3bac61</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">101</data>\n      <data key="d5">5c41f96be13e49dba649454297834546</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;VIKTOR RUCHKIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Viktor Ruchkin is an author who wrote articles for KZ."</data>\n      <data key="d2">2eec4248a3431cdb2dccff5f1d3bac61</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">102</data>\n      <data key="d5">7ea4afbf8a264f29af29950ce98105ba</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;V.V. MATVICHIUK&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"V.V. Matvichiuk is an author who co-wrote a paper titled \'Sistema strategicheskogo sderzhivaniia\' with A.L. Khriapin."</data>\n      <data key="d2">049bb8a8d8e442cd08b522c3502de46b</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">103</data>\n      <data key="d5">91ff849d12b24574b0691dbddf44968b</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;A.L. KHRIAPIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">A.L. Khriapin is an author who co-wrote the paper "Sistema strategicheskogo sderzhivaniia" with V.V. Matvichiuk. The paper was published in VM.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">049bb8a8d8e442cd08b522c3502de46b,35a12b9e620c419b9d3709d8310e4e44</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">104</data>\n      <data key="d5">d73c1f2fb3094d8dace42ad2a76e9a52</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;S.A. BOGDANOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"S.A. Bogdanov is an author who co-wrote a paper with V.N. Gorbunov."</data>\n      <data key="d2">049bb8a8d8e442cd08b522c3502de46b</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">105</data>\n      <data key="d5">cdc8901e668749889bd49bebdc4ff1f6</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;V.N. GORBUNOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"V.N. Gorbunov is an author who co-wrote a paper with S.A. Bogdanov."</data>\n      <data key="d2">049bb8a8d8e442cd08b522c3502de46b</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">106</data>\n      <data key="d5">36084a9fab53433493f079e97e68bf65</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SISTEMA STRATEGICHESKOGO SDERZHIVANIIA&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"EVENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Sistema strategicheskogo sderzhivaniia\' is the title of a paper co-authored by V.V. Matvichiuk and A.L. Khriapin."</data>\n      <data key="d2">049bb8a8d8e442cd08b522c3502de46b</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">107</data>\n      <data key="d5">eebcc7ec8e3e4df7aea83659bbdc2199</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;LENIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">## Lenin: A Revolutionary Redefining War\n\nLenin is a key figure in Marxist-Leninist theory, renowned for his contributions to shaping the Soviet understanding of war. He is cited as an authority on the militarization of social life under socialism and emphasized the connection between war and revolution.  Lenin viewed war as a necessary instrument for societal transformation and achieving socialism, arguing that imperialist wars are inevitable under capitalism. \n\nHe built upon the ideas of Marx and Engels, incorporating "violent" into the definition of war and defining it as the continuation of politics by violent means. This perspective, while influential, has been critiqued by scholars like Kirshin.  Lenin incorporated Clausewitz\'s ideas into Marxist theory, appreciating his use of dialectics and agreeing with his view that politics are superior to strategy. He also supported Svechin\'s similar stance on the primacy of politics over strategy. \n\nLenin\'s early writings serve as a foundational starting point for understanding Soviet military thought. His ideology emphasizes that peace is as much a continuation of politics as war, a notion further highlighted in The Soviet Military Encyclopedia.  His definition of war as an instrument of politics heavily influenced Soviet thought throughout history, even as the definition of war expanded to include non-military means. Lenin\'s writings on war became foundational for understanding warfare in both the Soviet Union and Russia. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">046f04af090c144a8bd1403c6c5879a4,11b09d5fddbfffd21c2a75e43b225a4a,137a23ec0a6c30f2d104480a42ca716b,13bea8189beda5cf3f185fddbe60600a,14442faf092eaecae58a72c1a981a33b,1b996f45c7b397759863385a53361eed,1cce175e6c7003db4a0791abde031a39,1d746c1fd3ea7d25a42568701611f772,2a4b75db8fdd23483fc6c4f097c7f56f,2be40bedc401aa74026067cbca67b681,2f7216242ac705ab8c989c77c74d477b,342381013c3f61db48a3a2b2bc77370c,38c01208da0359baa45c7640d7a2285c,3cd3649d4d82b16c6d105090d8081f6e,43cb0f2a8f89f287a9fa0308ed110a3f,4a45316e71cd0e0104c26095efef1a8b,51ed05a44ffcb6ce215b22d1c327ef23,51eee122c2ebcb8b0ffd820ac78cdc7b,62bc2728250038f93d0bc65c57c2385b,645ce27900f66a0b633be93f0e5d6399,6b7d21eb26a4ec94c42acbaaf3707f2e,82893599bbdf88d7635db30797b87987,897b3e3eedf4e832571846d6ff67fabe,9828b2e8c4e512e6982ce69d321d187b,a15ef9eda68738122db496f9962d6a9f,ad49a894ef8b75f1e79de5a63ec78b85,b161f86472b14d8aafd5240f60c4d0ea,b1b64ef207d42a2b81118c978ce1f222,b3aa1ac66a5e25e270fce196c19d325e,b8fd807f07f8a2af89aa236339a7bc45,bab940f0cf76af894b6edb440a57b5f8,beabdeed11a36088777fbee158b3a3f5,bfa15fcd5d4a19aa65f946d1af780d5f,c03cb503d15d806465177d74c09c8bbc,c4d14adb7bf6e96f2bcbd4de5958dcd8,cb8b8a24ee435442f42e5aa0feacb291,cc801e9b36ee6b6cbcb589ad5d6eb592,cca1605d479526e189239aac472c3e7e,d1330c3cbc7e7877db9ba902371af4d9,e54ed249cf4a821abfd0eec3959426c8,e90da29be1148d9844e3ed777db08bf6,f008ece3160552dbbd23842a0d13f1f7,fb8a4e3d89439bd18b6f6ecae81d6d7c,fb99597f638ca7706b382f31de64c0a7</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">18</data>\n      <data key="d4">108</data>\n      <data key="d5">ceadf262ef834e9ab146b20650912cae</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;TROTSKY&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">**TROTSKY** was a prominent Soviet military theorist and politician who significantly influenced early Soviet military thought. He held a deep admiration for Carl von Clausewitz, agreeing with his perspective on war as an extension of politics. Trotsky believed that the primary objective of war was to destroy the enemy\'s manpower through decisive blows, emphasizing the physically violent aspect of conflict.  \n\nHe is also recognized for his contributions to the concept of "not peace and not war," highlighting the interconnectedness of peace and war, a notion that influenced Messner\'s ideas on the blurring of lines between these two states. Trotsky saw violence as the defining characteristic of war, even in light of technological advancements, a view he shared with Lenin.  \n\nWhile emphasizing the importance of physical violence, Trotsky also recognized the artistic element inherent in military strategy, contrasting this with the scientific approach advocated by some theorists like Aleksandr Svechin, whom he acknowledged as influential. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0b7f36c1efd528460ea8b64f4d00c6a9,1d746c1fd3ea7d25a42568701611f772,3215346816955c73a119fe8038088c8e,39b41cfcdca61ad353853416d904417f,43cb0f2a8f89f287a9fa0308ed110a3f,69ab3a134854d40cbd893d37335cd7a2,6e81ca9f9ef3229b5c0e79413b269e37,962347193b87926e833cb5e1de7ff4e2,9b9ff0b9cc19b0ace380f06dff0ce7bd,b1b64ef207d42a2b81118c978ce1f222,bfa15fcd5d4a19aa65f946d1af780d5f,c4d14adb7bf6e96f2bcbd4de5958dcd8,eedc4b402e5b2b94dc3ffc578b96791b</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">6</data>\n      <data key="d4">109</data>\n      <data key="d5">7f65feab75424b53b24470d305ba331a</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SVECHIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">SVECHIN is a seminal Soviet military theorist known for his emphasis on historical analysis in military theory.  His most notable work, *Strategiya* (Strategy), solidified his position as a leading figure in the field. Svechin believed that war is fundamentally a conflict characterized by violence and argued that it is waged on both armed and economic fronts. He stressed the crucial role of military history in understanding strategy, advocating for a deep understanding of past conflicts to inform present-day military planning. While recognizing the importance of strategy, Svechin ultimately placed politics above strategic considerations, believing them to be the driving force behind warfare. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">11b09d5fddbfffd21c2a75e43b225a4a,1d746c1fd3ea7d25a42568701611f772,2be40bedc401aa74026067cbca67b681,2e7d136c6f4eaf9ce15bbde35a5bda23,6bb6801ed3016e00efcce4b92ed4763d,bfa15fcd5d4a19aa65f946d1af780d5f,e76184cff7bad45cbad7c9b1d3777f30</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">2</data>\n      <data key="d4">110</data>\n      <data key="d5">fd9cb733b28d420cb5cef01e545a132c</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;ALEKSANDR SVECHIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Aleksandr Svechin was a leading Soviet military theorist known for his influential work, "Strategiya" (Strategy). He is widely recognized for his belief that politics hold supremacy over strategy in the realm of military affairs.  Svechin advocated for a scientifically developed approach to military thought, emphasizing the importance of political considerations in shaping strategic decisions. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">0b7f36c1efd528460ea8b64f4d00c6a9,2553587dc45018c99ef96b7e7bb2637d,3215346816955c73a119fe8038088c8e,6e81ca9f9ef3229b5c0e79413b269e37,d1330c3cbc7e7877db9ba902371af4d9,eedc4b402e5b2b94dc3ffc578b96791b</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">111</data>\n      <data key="d5">0fbcca3f17c649a08aea64b5a7d9ef36</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;SOVIET&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"ORGANIZATION"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Soviet refers to the former Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR), highlighting its historical and geopolitical context.  The Soviet perspective on war and peace is presented, emphasizing their distinct understanding of these concepts as inherently political. The text also indicates that the Soviet Union held a deep understanding of Western military-technological innovations and had a different view on war compared to the 1993 doctrine. \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">004c0e044652c7853c755fca938857f2,08b5b9a81f792e1a63e929dc06a81d50,1cce175e6c7003db4a0791abde031a39,3215346816955c73a119fe8038088c8e,5430e32b1beaf2a36fbde8a1b9b3074f,beabdeed11a36088777fbee158b3a3f5,c14363837da220e50f2cbf6793eb94d2,c224c7a93362b03f8db7d3e34d1bffc1,e8d8461aeecbc6801361ca4fa5c3e2e2</data>\n      <data key="d6">9</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">1</data>\n      <data key="d4">112</data>\n      <data key="d5">482027a59f32484c9c44fd700615c1b6</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;PUTIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">## Vladimir Putin: A Leader Focused on Security and Information Warfare\n\nVladimir Putin, the President of Russia, has been a key figure in shaping Russia\'s political landscape since assuming the office of presidency in 1999. He is deeply concerned about external threats to Russia\'s security and stability, viewing Western influence and "color revolutions" as significant dangers.  Putin believes that information warfare can be used to manipulate values, culture, and ultimately lead to political or economic crises. He has criticized foreign governments for using NGOs and democracy promotion as tools to destabilize post-Soviet states, arguing that these actions often exceed legal and constitutional boundaries.\n\nPutin\'s vision for Russia emphasizes a strong national defense, outlining his strategy in an article titled "Byt silnymi: Garantii natsionalnoy bezopasnosti dlya Rossii" (Being Strong: Guaranteeing National Security for Russia). He sees information technology as crucial to modern conflict, equating its importance to new military means.  \n\nPutin has been vocal about his disapproval of Western interventions, particularly the 2011 intervention in Libya, which he labeled a "crusade." He also expressed disagreement with former Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev regarding this intervention. Putin has accused the US of interfering in Russia\'s domestic policies and criticized their role in events like the Orange Revolution.  \n\nWhile cautious about directly blaming Western governments for "color revolutions," Putin believes they are orchestrated by external forces, often using NGOs as proxies. He sees election monitors as a potential threat to Russian elections, believing they are used to disrupt the democratic process. \n\n\nPutin\'s leadership has faced criticism for its increasingly autocratic nature and his actions in Ukraine, including the annexation of Crimea and the ongoing invasion.  \n</data>\n      <data key="d2">02a6df0665914ec51da4921e5dd94d40,046b1edf8fbc5d1fbd1a79f8a887a374,0a20fca212149a5c275431feaaf62872,181231ad89fa361ed50977f8c31ba68e,19d9f093df260f1df1d036a42926a00d,1b2ff8a47843f9eaa296b8dbc90d9179,1c170b6b1c8851bba14e24b8af15b481,1dabe4b6c1c6784c25fb3e21c5e41d22,20d87cdf1f465c50311a5731b700eb92,21a07c1b9dcad76a185aa038ee84add1,29a46f13633e4ddfb2338626c0e0a4c8,2b383cf8d68e36bef55be0a53df63999,3060e5a3570413999878edce8065dc2b,34b0078e74299e6a200a4ef43f0bdc9c,3747b8d7981bef88cd93023a9282583b,3972337bda3ba01f49da971ec696ce50,3f1469dfb6c218c8c3c64069b7a2495c,41e4c3296d7d78d51200037f4bccd7ff,47cbbe56d55fbd552f238ecfef64e24b,4f7f4f6fe9d288255da50532faa25f53,5049e837c0dd71c0a6348a2bf0eb1d93,5140c89116bf2a284b9b14b06732515a,6868f009e28c0d98518a108a15141a47,68e7972f85fd6fc2109534ff86630800,74fc1d4777e569e70cae27ded8161c9c,7f0ec47ed2088572385dcc53d6704c97,80977716c22c59d3eca92f04f08f0a53,8178d352e32cb271d8f2c52c29bf60a3,85e5e3514a004553e41c0c93fc4c5f0a,90103cb4f23e3f665cb8e7a0b7cc6bf1,947a8459acffd10caa21cb928f64a02c,9a2dcbe9b0d27f8917dd3fe660260425,9efadc7c0ff965fcd39d3ba70a376642,b3066af57efb89b0569dbadaba8b79bc,b50799a7304451430d84c0212b504cf4,ba4314d7dde31a9a3de140b03d964db0,c3a70df47396b839b38318aa06ce1cab,c8abe64a0759c36ce7cef99c1d6d8e62,cdb1d6abbb222058b92413663953ef84,d47f2d497de875578bdabc88b41d9d6d,dccb84a71d03372398587d309d2898aa,e0d765d0aa64f3c5fa134e12f9523747,f1524ed26c5d48cf8a616bb767a51ee4,f3489109e196578634fad718c775549e,f377212178ff5952443726ce112faac6,f9e4382c52fba95f15cc189f5e210b03,fd24a983ae975cadc842ce8fa5eea97c</data>\n      <data key="d6">0</data>\n      <data key="d7">0</data>\n      <data key="d3">16</data>\n      <data key="d4">113</data>\n      <data key="d5">de837ff3d626451282ff6ac77a82216d</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;VIKTOR YUSHCHENKO&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Viktor Yushchenko was elected president of Ukraine in 2004 after a rerun of the second round of voting. He served as president during the Orange Revolution, a period marked by pro-democracy protests and political upheaval.  While Yushchenko himself was not directly involved with Russian opposition groups, Putin claimed that some members of the Russian opposition had advised him during this time. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">046b1edf8fbc5d1fbd1a79f8a887a374,2b383cf8d68e36bef55be0a53df63999,85e5e3514a004553e41c0c93fc4c5f0a,931a3799d962bbcfc294a670caa94cdc,c8abe64a0759c36ce7cef99c1d6d8e62</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">114</data>\n      <data key="d5">460295fed3ae4cd39f9f274cec9c2506</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;HILLARY CLINTON&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">Hillary Clinton, who served as the US Secretary of State at the time, was accused by Vladimir Putin of signaling to Russian opposition protesters.  Putin alleged that Clinton\'s actions conveyed a message of support to the demonstrators. \n\n\n</data>\n      <data key="d2">2b383cf8d68e36bef55be0a53df63999,85e5e3514a004553e41c0c93fc4c5f0a,c8abe64a0759c36ce7cef99c1d6d8e62</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">115</data>\n      <data key="d5">553b285bba60460ab1ed8341ae61282b</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;BORIS NEMTSOV&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Boris Nemtsov was a Russian opposition leader who participated in the Orange Revolution."</data>\n      <data key="d2">2b383cf8d68e36bef55be0a53df63999</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">116</data>\n      <data key="d5">cec95bf17e7e4c939b56c9c6f402a29f</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;ILYA YASHIN&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"PERSON"</data>\n      <data key="d1">"Ilya Yashin was a Russian opposition leader who participated in the Orange Revolution and became the leader of Oborona."</data>\n      <data key="d2">2b383cf8d68e36bef55be0a53df63999</data>\n      <data key="d3">0</data>\n      <data key="d4">117</data>\n      <data key="d5">599164aead034bc19446efacc77554d2</data>\n    </node>\n    <node id="&quot;ORANGE REVOLUTION&quot;">\n      <data key="d0">"EVENT"</data>\n      <data key="d1">The **Orange Revolution** was a significant pro-democracy movement in Ukraine that took place in 2004, leading to a change in government.  It is considered a historical event that has influenced the passing of new laws and is often referenced as a potential model for color revolutions, both admired and feared by various parties.
